The next 10 feet of trail cover a 5-10%-grade increase to the 30-foot bridge over Taft Creek. There is an 8-inch step off the far end of the bridge onto sloping ground for 10 more feet.

At 650 feet, the trail narrows to 4 feet wide and climbs at a steep 9-14% grade. There is an exterior handrail along the trail starting at 650 feet and ending at 900 feet. The trail turns to the left and continues uphill at steeper grades from 17-22% for 70 feet, before reaching the start of a loop that circles through a forest of bigleaf maple trees. Turn left at the intersection and continue uphill. From 970 feet to 1,020 feet is the steepest part of the trail at 24% for 30 feet, followed by 20 feet at 12%.

From 1,020 to 1,050 feet, the trail goes downhill at a 15% grade, followed by another 40 feet downhill at 9%. Following a small step down at 1,110 feet, the grade drops to under 5% for the next 700 feet. At 1,805 feet there is a 200-foot spur trail to the left. The spur, under 5% grade, is fenced on either side and ends at a fenced area with views of a group of moss-covered bigleaf maples. Continuing back along the main trail from the spur, the trail remains under 5% grade to 2,210 feet. Those seeking the least-strenuous version of this hike may wish to go back along the same route at this point, as the east side of loop is more rugged than the portion already traveled. The trail begins to climb uphill at 10-14% grade from 2,210 feet to 2,990 feet. From 2,990 feet to 2,390 feet, the trail continues uphill, fluctuating from 7-14% before reaching a 30-foot stretch dense with large roots. There is a brief, level spot at 2,440 feet before a 16% uphill increase that includes 6 steps interspersed with roots and rocks.

The trail remains rocky and begins sloping back downhill at 9-12%, interspersed with a few gentler areas to 2,645 feet. From 2,645 to 2,735 feet the grade sharply increases to 20%, then reduces to 8% from 2,735 to 2,810 feet. Continue down 7 stairs at a 10% grade to 2,850 feet. This concludes the most difficult section of the east side of the loop. There are many amazing sights along the remainder of the loop, including examples of mature trees grown from nurse logs and fallen giants on the trail side. The trail tread again becomes wide, smooth and under 5% grade from 2,850 feet to 3,355 feet. At 3,355 feet there is a 30-foot downhill at 15-20% with numerous roots and rocks. From 3,385 to 3,900 feet, grades remain under 5% until reaching five stairs climbing a 15% grade increase for 45 feet. From 3,945 feet the trail is again smooth and level until a 25-foot uphill increase of 10-12% at 4,380 feet. The final gentle stretch extends from 4,405 feet to 4,500 feet. At 4,500 feet, continue down a steep hill at 20-25% grade to reach the beginning of the loop. Retrace the initial approach to return to the parking area at 5,515 feet.
audioDescription: Hall of Mosses Trailhead. 30 seconds At a fork in the Hoh River Trail, a brown and white sign with a left pointing arrow reads: Hall of Mosses. The dirt trail surface is mostly flat. Up trail, a wooden plank bridge with short side bumpers and no hand railings crosses a creek. On the other side of the bridge the trail becomes rough. In places rocks and tree roots protrude through the surface and wooden timbers lay across the trail creating uneven steps. Overhead, downed trees may cross the trail creating places where head room is reduced. The trail passes through the lush rain forest of old, towering trees hanging with moss, and young trees with bright green pine needles. Moss and ferns carpet the ground.

title: Hartzell Creek Boat Launch
listingDescription: A popular boat launch for boaters and anglers.

images.altText: A rocky bank along a calm river. Evergreen trees grow tall on the opposite bank.
images.title: Hartzell Creek Boat Launch
images.caption: A quiet day on the Queets at Hartzell Creek Boat Launch

bodyText: A popular boat launch for boaters and anglers.
audioDescription: Hartzell Creek Boat Launch. 30 seconds At a road intersection is a brown sign with white text that reads, Hartzell Creek Boat Ramp. A second sign reads, No camping or overnight parking. The boat ramp is down the dirt side road. Just before the ramp on the left is a bulletin board with posted fishing and park regulations. Other notices read, no fireworks allowed, and no pets allowed on trails. Beyond the board, the road descends a slight hill to the wide, gravel and mud riverbank where boats are launched. Tall, thin birch trees with white bark line the riverbank. Behind them is a forest of green pine trees.

title: Hartzell Creek Restroom

images.altText: Black and white symbol for restroom with male and female figures separated by a wall.

bodyText: Restroom near Hartzell Creek
audioDescription: Hartzell Creek Restroom. 45 seconds In front of a parking area is an all gender, single stall, accessible restroom building with a vault toilet area atop a concrete pad. The front of the restroom faces left. A narrow dirt trail marked on each side by a large boulder leads to the front entrance of the restroom. Enter on the left side beneath an open alcove. The door to the restroom is on the right. On the right side of the parking area is a roof covered bulletin board with posted notices about preservation, fishing, and in an emergency, contact a park ranger or dial 911. A sign attached to the bulletin board frame reads, No camping or overnight parking.

title: Heart O' The Forest Trailhead
listingDescription: This 2.3 mile (3.7) km one way trail is a lovely, level trek through the forest. Starts at Loop E in the Heart O' the Hills campground.

images.altText: A trail through the forest.
images.caption: Photo by E. Goode/NPS.

bodyText: This 2.3 mile (3.7) km one way trail is a lovely, level trek through the forest. Starts at Loop E in the Heart O' the Hills campground.
audioDescription: Heart O’ The Forest Trailhead. 45 seconds At the trailhead, a brown rectangular sign with white text reads, Heart O’ the Forest Trail. Trail end 2 miles. This smooth, dirt trail passes through a lush forest of towering pines and an understory of younger trees, shrubs, ferns, and ground cover plants. Green moss hangs from branches and clings to tree trunks. Be advised, a two-foot-tall log post stands vertical in the center of the trail approximately 10 feet beyond the trailhead sign. Beyond the log post on the left side of the trail is a three-foot-tall post supporting a square brown box with a lid. Inside are trail guides.

title: Heart O' The Hills Amphitheater

images.altText: Black and white symbol for amphitheater with the figure of a person at the front and bench seating facing them.

bodyText: Heart O’ The Hills Campground Amphitheater.
audioDescription: Heart O’ The Hills Campground Amphitheater. 1 minute A brown and white sign at the entrance to the amphitheater includes an icon of a person from the waist up wearing a wide brimmed hat, arms at their sides, above three upward curving thick lines. Next to the icon, an arrow points up. Below the icon, the word, Programs, is followed by the starting time and days of the week when programs occur. A path leads to the amphitheater. Here, on a downward sloping surface, are eight rows of wooden bench seats, separated into three sections by aisles. In front of these benches are four more rows of benches with no aisles. At the bottom of the slope, a green wooden building with a flat roof sits atop a two-foot-high concrete stage. The center of the building is recessed toward the back with two doors that open to reveal a projection screen. The projection booth is in the back of the amphitheater at the top of the slope. To the right of the stage is a round, stone edged fire ring with a semicircular bench. The amphitheater is surrounded by a forest of tall trees.

title: Heart O' The Hills Entrance Station

images.altText: Black and white symbol for entrance station with a narrow booth and a sign.

bodyText: Entrance station located on Hurricane Ridge Road.
audioDescription: Heart O’ The Hills Entrance Station. 1 minute The right lane of the roadway passes through a tall, square opening in the center of this entrance station which is topped by an A-shaped peaked roof. The left side of the building, which sits on a grass island in the center of the two-lane road, is a small fee and information booth with windows on three sides. One window slides open for communication between park staff and vehicles. Attached to the wall next to this window is a self-pay station for times when the booth is closed, and a sign stating the visitor center hours, road conditions and who to contact in case of emergency. The right side of the building sits on the shoulder of the road and has a similar glass booth but with a low rectangular building extending off the back. The National Park Service arrowhead logo is attached to the face of the building near the peak of the roof. A sign on the right shoulder of the road in front of the station lists the costs for entrance fees, annual passes, and lifetime passes.

title: Heart o' The Hills Restroom and Campground Registration - Loops B & D

images.altText: Black and white symbol for restroom with male and female figures separated by a wall.

bodyText: Campground registration and restrooms.
audioDescription: Campground Registration - Loops B & D. 1 minute In the campground along the loop road is a rectangular restroom building with a brown metal roof, grey wooden sides and yellow doors. The long side of the building faces the road. The restroom entrance doors are located on each short side of the building, the women’s room on the left and the men’s room on the right. A flat patio surrounds the building. Attached to the front of the restroom building is the campground registration board, two vertical framed boxes divided into rows of individual square sections. Each square is numbered and corresponds to a campsite. Each row is covered by a hard, clear plastic strip with a slot for dropping one of two registration payment receipts into an individual square. Low and to the right of the registration boards is a brown box with a lid holding campground registration envelopes. Standing in front of the board is a 3-foot-tall cannister for depositing the envelope with payment. On the face of the cannister, at the top, is a slot for slipping in the envelope. In front of the restroom building is a roof-covered bulletin board with information about the campground and park regulations.

title: Heart o' the Hills Restroom and Campground Registration - Loop A

images.altText: Black and white symbol for restroom with male and female figures separated by a wall.

bodyText: Campground registration and restrooms.
audioDescription: Campground Registration – Loop A. 2 minutes In the campground along the loop road is a rectangular restroom building with a brown metal roof, grey wooden sides and yellow doors. The long side of the building faces the road. The restroom entrance doors are located on each short side of the building, the women’s room on the left and the men’s room on the right. The restroom sits atop a flat, hard surfaced area. Attached to the front of the restroom building is the campground registration board, a framed box divided into rows of individual square sections. Each square is numbered and corresponds to a campsite. Each row is covered by a hard, clear plastic strip with a slot for dropping one of two registration payment receipts into an individual square. Low and to the right of the registration boards is a brown box with a lid holding campground registration envelopes. Standing in front of the board is a 3-foot-tall cannister for depositing the envelope with payment. On the face of the cannister, at the top, is a slot for slipping in the envelope. In front of the restroom building is a roof-covered bulletin board with changing information about the campground, Ranger programs, park preservation messages, safety notices, and park regulations.

title: Heart o' the Hills Restroom and Campground Registration-Loops C&E

images.altText: Black and white symbol for restroom with male and female figures separated by a wall.

bodyText: Campground registration and restrooms.
audioDescription: Campground Registration - Loops C & E 2 minutes In the campground along the loop road is a rectangular restroom building with a brown metal roof, grey wooden sides and yellow doors. The long side of the building faces the road. The restroom entrance doors are located on each short side of the building. A level path leads to the women’s room on the left and a level path leads to the men’s room on the right. The path spans the front of the building forming a U-shaped walkway. Attached to the front of the restroom building is the campground registration board, two vertical framed boxes divided into rows of individual square sections. Each square is numbered and corresponds to a campsite. Each row is covered by a hard, clear plastic strip with a slot for dropping one of two registration payment receipts into an individual square. Low and to the right of the registration boards is a brown box with a lid holding campground registration envelopes. Standing in front of the board is a 3-foot-tall cannister for depositing the envelope with payment. On the face of the cannister, at the top, is a slot for slipping in the envelope. In front of the restroom building are two brown metal four-foot-tall food lockers.

title: Hoh Amphitheater

images.altText: Black and white symbol for amphitheater with the figure of a person at the front and bench seating facing them.

bodyText: Amphitheater for Hoh Rain Forest Campground
audioDescription: Hoh Amphitheater. 1 minute On a downward sloping hard surface are nine rows of wooden bench seats, separated into three sections by aisles. In front of these benches are four more rows of benches with no aisles. At the bottom of the slope, a green wooden building with a flat roof sits atop a two-foot-high concrete stage. The center of the building is recessed toward the back with two doors that open to reveal a projection screen. Painted on the doors is a black, green, and red American Indian bird symbol, its wide head looking forward. Tail feathers above the head point upward and are flanked on either side by feather designs. Curved black talons facing inward are in each corner at the bottom. To the right of the stage is a round, stone edged fire ring with a semicircular bench. The projection booth is in the back of the amphitheater at the top of the slope. The amphitheater is surrounded by a forest of tall trees.

title: Hoh Campground Picnic Area

images.altText: A picnic table in a sunny green clearing
images.title: Hoh Campground Picnic Area
images.caption: A picnic spot in the Hoh

bodyText: Enjoy a picnic near the Hoh Rain Forest Campground
audioDescription: Hoh Campground Picnic Area. 30 seconds Scattered around this flat, grassy area are sites with picnic tables, metal pedestal grills, and in-ground metal fire rings.

title: Hoh Campground RV Dump Station

images.altText: A black and white symbol of an RV dumping waste.

bodyText: RV dump station for Hoh Rain Forest Campground
audioDescription: RV Dump Station. 90 seconds Off the loop road is a side road that leads to the dump station. On a post is a brown sign with white text that reads, RV Septic Dump Station. $10 per use. $5 with Interagency Senior or Access Pass. Not included in camping fee. Below the sign is an open fronted box with a metal box inside holding payment envelopes. To the left of the post is a three-foot-tall metal cannister with a slot at the top for depositing payment envelopes. To the right of the payment center is the ground level drain area and a hose attached to a tall red pole. A sign behind the hose provides dumping station instructions. Text reads, 1. Connect your hose to trailer holding tank. 2. Insert hose end securely into drain, holding cover open with a foot. Open trailer drain valve. 3. Wash any spillage into the drain using water provided. Water unsafe to drink. No washing of vehicles. To the left of the payment station is a hose attached to a blue pole. A sign to the left reads, Clean water. Use this hose for filling domestic tank only.

title: Hoh Entrance Station

images.altText: Black and white symbol for entrance station with a narrow booth and a sign.

bodyText: Entrance Station for the Hoh Rain Forest area of the park
audioDescription: Hoh Entrance Station. 2 minutes The entrance station is a small light brown shingled building with a high-pitched roof, a window on each side, and an American flag. The building sits in the center of the road on a rectangular island placing both the building and island parallel to the roadway. Vehicles approach the long side of the building with a sliding glass window where a park staff assists with entrance fees and park passes. A sign on the station has the National Park Service arrowhead logo and the text, U.S. Fee Area. A small sign near the ground at the front edge of the island reads, Pass Holders Photo ID Required. A larger upright sign behind it reads: Olympic National Park Entrance Fees-Valid 7-days with receipt Private Vehicle, 30 dollars Bicycles and Walk-ins per person, 15 dollars Motorcycles, 25 dollars Annual Passes - Photo ID required Interagency including all National Parks, 80 dollars Olympic National Park, 55 dollars Senior Annual, 62 years and older, 20 dollars Active U.S. Military, free Lifetime Passes - U.S. Citizens and Permanent Residents Senior Lifetime, 62 years and older, 80 dollars Access, permanently disabled, free Below the sliding glass window, a sign reads, Debit or Credit Only. Please show ID with Pass. A sign to the right of the window reads, Welcome to the Hoh Rainforest. Visitor Center and Campground 6 miles. Visitor Center hours open 9 to 5. Nature Trails, Hall of Mosses, point eight mile. Spruce Trail one-point-two mile. Restrooms at Visitor Center. A notice posted on the window reads, No Pets on Trails.

title: Hoh Entrance Station Restroom

images.altText: Black and white symbol for restroom with male and female figures separated by a wall.

bodyText: Restroom at Hoh Rain Forest entrance station
audioDescription: Hoh Entrance Station Restroom. 15 seconds At the left end of the parking lot is a sidewalk leading to a small, brown, wooden restroom building with a peaked roof. A dark brown and white sign attached to the front of the building indicates the restroom is an all-gender accessible restroom with a vault toilet. The sidewalk leads to the open left side of the building. The single restroom door is on the right.

title: Hoh Fishing Access Parking

images.altText: A P symbol denoting a parking area
images.title: Parking Lot
images.caption: Parking

bodyText: Parking for fishing access on the Hoh River
audioDescription: Hoh Fishing Access Parking. 15 seconds Along the front edge of the parking lot is a 4-inch-high curb and sidewalk. On the opposite side of the sidewalk is the trail leading to the fishing area. Here, posted on a brown board are current fishing regulations. Be advised. The trail surface is extremely uneven with rocks and tree roots protruding through the surface.

title: Hoh Rain Forest Entrance Sign

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Hoh Rain Forest park entrance sign
audioDescription: Hoh Rainforest Entrance Sign. 1 minute Be advised, a line of rocks separates the car pull off area from the grassy area where the sign is located. Attached to log posts of varying heights, is a dark brown horizontal wooden sign with white text that reads, Olympic National Park, Hoh Rain Forest. On a log post to the right of the sign is the National Park Service arrowhead logo atop a larger white arrowhead shaped base. The logo itself is shaped like an arrowhead with a scalloped edge, pointed at the bottom, with sides that widen out toward the top, before curving slightly inward, then flaring out and up to create a rounded top. The arrowhead is brown with etched words and images. On the right side are the words, National Park Service, in white letters. To the left, in green, a tall tree towers above smaller trees and the ground below, and a section of lake in white. Behind the tree, a white outline of snowcapped mountains. Below the trees, text in white reads, Department of the Interior, and below this, an outline of a bison in profile facing left with a large head and shoulders and smaller hind area.

title: Hoh Restrooms and Campground Registration - Loop A

images.altText: Black and white symbol for restroom with male and female figures separated by a wall.

bodyText: Restrooms and campsite registration for Loop A of Hoh Rain Forest Campground
audioDescription: Hoh Campground Registration Loop A. 90 seconds Along the loop road is a concrete plaza with a roof covered bulletin board, water station, garbage receptacle and restrooms. On the bulletin board is the campground registration board, a vertical framed box divided into rows of individual square sections. Each square is numbered and corresponds to a campsite. Each row is covered by a hard, clear plastic strip with a slot for dropping one of two registration payment receipts into an individual square. To the left of the board is a brown box with a lid holding campground registration envelopes. Standing in front of the board on the left is a 3-foot-tall metal cannister for depositing the envelope with payment. On the face of the cannister, at the top, is a slot for slipping in the envelope. Posted notices on the bulletin board include campground registration instructions, campground regulations, a campground map, pet regulations, a warning about Elk, and to contact a ranger or dial 911 in an emergency. Posted on the back of the bulletin board is information about campfire wood, fishing, backcountry safety, cougars and bears, ranger programs, and a notice stating fireworks are prohibited. Behind the bulletin board is a rectangular building with a covered breezeway left of center. A women’s restroom is located inside the breezeway on the right. The men’s restroom is on the far-right short side of the building. On the left side of the concrete plaza is a water station and garbage receptacle.

title: Hoh Restrooms and Campground Registration - Loop B
listingDescription:
Location: The Hoh Rain Forest Area
Description: The Hoh Campground is located in the Hoh Rain Forest, near the banks of the Hoh River. Some sites are right next to the river! 88 campsites, one accessible, fire pits with grates, accessible restrooms, water, animal-proof food storage.
Open: Year-round.
Accessibility: One wheelchair accessible campsite, accessible restrooms.
RVs: Sites can accommodate 21-foot RVs, and a few can accommodate 35-foot RVs. No dump station.

images.altText: A picnic table in a mossy green rain forest setting
images.title: Hoh Campground Loop D
images.caption: A campsite in the Hoh

bodyText: Restrooms and campsite registration for Loop B of the Hoh Rain Forest Campground.
audioDescription: Hoh Campground Registration Loop B. 2 minutes On a paved area is a roof covered kiosk with park information on both sides. Attached on the left front side of the kiosk is the campground registration board, a vertical box with 20 numbered square sections, each corresponding to an individual campsite. The squares are covered by a hard, clear plastic sheet with slots for dropping one of two registration payment receipts into an individual square. Low and to the left of the registration board is a brown lidded box holding campground registration envelopes. A 3-foot-tall cannister for depositing the payment envelope stands alone within the footprint of the kiosk on the far left. On the face of the cannister at the top is a slot for slipping in the envelope. Behind the kiosk is a rectangular restroom building with a brown metal roof, grey wooden sides and yellow doors. The long side of the building faces the road. The restroom entrance doors are located on each short side of the building. The women’s room is on the left and the men’s room is on the right. The paved surface surrounds the restroom.

title: Hoh Restrooms and Campground Registration - Loop C

images.altText: Black and white symbol for restroom with male and female figures separated by a wall.

bodyText: Restrooms and campsite registration for Loop C of Hoh Rain Forest Campground
audioDescription: Hoh Campground Registration Loop C. 1 minute On a concrete pad is a roof covered bulletin board with park information on both sides. Attached in the center of the front side is the campground registration board, a rectangular box with 35 numbered square sections, each corresponding to an individual campsite. The squares are covered by a hard, clear plastic sheet with slots for dropping one of two registration payment receipts into an individual square. In the bottom right corner of the bulletin board is a brown lidded box holding campground registration envelopes. A 3-foot-tall cannister for depositing the payment envelope stands alone in front of the bulletin board. On the face of the cannister at the top is a slot for slipping in the envelope.

title: Hoh River Trail junction
listingDescription: The Hoh River Trail (17.3 miles/27.8 km one way) is a starting point for backpackers headed toward Mount Olympus, but there's no rule that says you have to go that far! (If you do want to, contact the Wilderness Information Center to make a backpacking plan. www.nps.gov/olym/planyourvisit/wilderness.htm has locations and hours). For a peaceful out-and-back day hike (aka just turn around and come back when you're ready), the first section of the Hoh River Trail is mostly level

images.altText: A creek runs through a rain forest
images.title: Taft Creek in the Hoh Rain Forest
images.caption: Taft Creek in the Hoh Rain Forest

bodyText: The Hoh River Trail (17.3 miles/27.8 km one way) is a starting point for backpackers headed toward Mount Olympus, but there's no rule that says you have to go that far! (If you do want to, contact the Wilderness Information Center to make a backpacking plan. www.nps.gov/olym/planyourvisit/wilderness.htm has locations and hours). For a peaceful out-and-back day hike (aka just turn around and come back when you're ready), the first section of the Hoh River Trail is mostly level and often much quieter than other, more bustling areas of the park, the only sounds coming from bird songs and rushing water. Look for the beautiful, 60-foot (18 meter) cascade of Mineral Creek falls 2.8 miles (4.5 km) in!
audioDescription: Hoh River Trail Junction. 45 seconds Along the Spruce River Trail is a trail junction. A brown sign on the left reads: Hoh River Trail. Glacier Meadows 17.5 miles. Backcountry camping permit required. Obtain at Visitor Center. Another sign warns of coyotes stealing food at several campsites along the trail and to secure your food. The trail may be rocky and uneven, and in places, log timbers have been placed across the trail as steps. The trail passes through a lush forest of young and old trees, many draped with green moss. Ferns and other low growing plants create a carpet of green on either side of the trail.

title: Hoh River Trailhead
listingDescription: Three trails begin just outside the Hoh Rain Forest Visitor Center: The Hoh River Trail (17.4 miles/28 km one way), a starting point for backpackers headed toward Mount Olympus or for a longer day hike, and two short loop trails, the Hall of Mosses and the Spruce Nature Trail. The Hoh is a wildlife hot spot - within just a few steps of the trailhead, you might see Roosevelt elk, river otters, birds, Coho salmon, black bears, or even a bobcat! In winter when the Coho return fr

images.altText: A trail through a forest of ferns and mossy trees
images.title: Hoh River Trail
images.caption: The Hoh River Trail

bodyText: Three trails begin just outside the Hoh Rain Forest Visitor Center: The Hoh River Trail (17.4 miles/28 km one way), a starting point for backpackers headed toward Mount Olympus or for a longer day hike, and two short loop trails, the Hall of Mosses and the Spruce Nature Trail. The Hoh is a wildlife hot spot - within just a few steps of the trailhead, you might see Roosevelt elk, river otters, birds, Coho salmon, black bears, or even a bobcat! In winter when the Coho return from the ocean to spawn, you might even spot an otter or bobcat fishing.
audioDescription: Hoh River Trailhead. 90 seconds On the right side of the parking area before reaching the Visitor Center is the flat, gravel and dirt trail. Here, a brown and white sign with an upward pointing arrow reads: Mini Trail. Hall of Mosses. Spruce Trail. Hoh River Trail. On the left side of the trail is a roof covered bulletin board with posted notices about wilderness regulations, pet regulations; alerts about cougars, elk, and bears; backcountry safety; in an emergency, contact a ranger or dial 911; Ranger programs; Hoh River trails; weather; fishing; and nearest services. In the center of the bulletin board is a map of the area. Up the trail are two roof covered kiosks with interpretive panels, the first on the right side of the trail, the second further up on the left. A brown sign on the right of trail reads: No Pets. Weapon Use, or Wheeled Devices. About 20 feet up trail, there is a low wooden railing along the right edge that follows the trail as it curves to the left. Here, tree roots protrude onto the trail on the left. The trail moves through a forest of pines trees, many old and large. Green moss clings to tree trunks and hangs like tattered curtains from branches.

title: Hoh Stock Corral

images.altText: Black and white symbol for stock corral with a horse in a partially covered structure.

bodyText: Stock corral for the Hoh Rain Forest area
audioDescription: Hoh Stock Corral. 30 seconds Wooden split rail fencing with gates create two corrals separated by a central path. On the outside of the corrals to the left and right are hitching posts. On the right is a covered bulletin board with information about horse use in the park. A sign below reads, do not tie horses to fence rails. The area is flat with a grass surface.

title: Hoh Visitor Center Mini-Trail Trailhead

images.altText: Two hikers looking at a kiosk with posted signs next to a rainforest trailhead.
images.title: Visitors at Hoh Information Kiosk
images.caption: Checking for posted information before hitting the trail

bodyText:
Perhaps the shortest trail in the park!
 

Full Accessibility Description:

Length: 800 feet
Surface Type: Compacted gravel
Typical Trail Width: 4-6 feet
Typical Running Slope: Under 5%
Typical Cross Slope: Less than 1%
Elevation Gain/Loss: Less than 15 feet
Accessible Parking: Van-accessible parking immediately across from park information boards
Description: The Hoh parking area has five van-accessible parking spaces. From the parking area, cross the crosswalk and turn right to reach the trailhead where several boards display information about the area. From the park information boards, proceed forward for 310 feet and then follow to the left at the intersection. Trailside benches can be found at 200 feet on the left and at 360 feet on the right. Continue to the next intersection at 450 feet and turn left again. At 475 feet, cross an 8-foot long bridge. Continue forward for 70 feet to a second bridge that is 25-feet long with a 2-inch drop when going off the other end. At 605 feet, there is a tree root across most of the trail, 1-2 inches high. Continue forward to reach the visitor center at 660 feet. To complete the loop, follow the sidewalk around the visitor center towards the parking area.
audioDescription: Visitor Center Mini-Trail Trailhead. 10 seconds From the Visitor Center, the dirt trail passes between two ancient, towering trees, their roots protruding into the trail. As the trail curves left, a brown sign on the right of trail reads: No Pets. Weapon Use, or Wheeled Devices.

title: Hoh Visitor Center Picnic Area

images.altText: A picnic table near some dumpsters
images.title: Hoh VC picnic area
images.caption: Picnic area near Hoh Rain Forest Visitor Center

bodyText: Picnic area near the Hoh Rain Forest Visitor Center
audioDescription: Hoh Visitor Center Picnic Area. 15 seconds This picnic area is located on the grassy island in the middle of the parking area for the Hoh Visitor Center and trailheads. The surface is dirt with tree roots protruding above ground in places. There are picnic tables and garbage receptacles.

title: Hoodsport Wilderness Information Center
listingDescription: Rangers present intermittently in summer. Located inside the Hoodsport Visitor Information Center, the Hoodsport Wilderness Information Center issues back-country permits and bear cans for safe food storage, and provides current trail and in-depth backpacking information. Get a head start by visiting https://www.nps.gov/olym/planyourvisit/wic.htm

images.altText: A sign reads "Hood Canal Visitor Center, Olympic National Forest and National Park"

bodyText: Rangers present intermittently in summer. Located inside the Hoodsport Visitor Information Center, the Hoodsport Wilderness Information Center issues back-country permits and bear cans for safe food storage, and provides current trail and in-depth backpacking information. Get a head start by visiting our Wilderness Information Center website.
audioDescription: Hood Canal Wilderness Information Center. 2 minutes In the parking lot on a grassy median strip is a U.S. Forest Service sign atop a 3-foot-high stone pedestal. The sign is square, though slightly broader at the top, with rounded corners. The top third of the sign is white with words in brown that read, Hood Canal Visitor Center. The bottom portion is brown with words in white that read, Olympic National Forest and Olympic National Park. At the end of the parking lot is a brown mileage sign for campgrounds that reads: Big Creek 9 miles and Staircase 16 miles. The Visitor Center is a one-story, white rectangular building with a gray shingled roof that faces the parking lot. The entry area and front door are in the center of the building under a small roof set perpendicular to the main roof. To access the building from the parking lot, cross a narrow road between the Visitor Center and the parking lot. There is one deep step before the step up to the entry area. Ramp access is to the left of the front door entry. On the right-side wall of the entry area is information about current weather conditions, trail conditions and visitor center hours. There is also a Hiker’s Message Board with changing information. The Wilderness Information Center is in this building. Inside the visitor center is a large wall mounted map of the Olympic Peninsula that includes trails, roads, and park, forest and wilderness boundaries. Locations of campgrounds, picnic areas, boat launches, points of interest, ranger stations, and vehicle ferries are marked on the map.

title: Hurricane Hill Picnic Area A
listingDescription: Open only in summer, located one mile (1.6 km) beyond the visitor center. Lovely meadow area with mountain views, restrooms, water, and paved trails to tables.

images.altText: A picnic table with a view of distant mountains.
images.caption: Hurricane Hill Picnic Area A. Photo by E. Goode/NPS.

bodyText: Open only in summer, located one mile (1.6 km) beyond the visitor center. Lovely meadow area with mountain views, restrooms, water, and paved trails to tables.
audioDescription: Hurricane Hill Picnic Area A. 20 seconds A path leads to a mowed area with picnic tables, log benches, and a trash can. A meadow, shrubs, and tall trees surround the area.

title: Hurricane Hill Picnic Area B
listingDescription: Open summer only, located one mile (1.6 km) beyond the visitor center, with restrooms, water and paved trails to tables. The parking area doubles as overflow parking for the Hurricane Hill Trail, just a short walk through the forest away.

images.altText: A road branches into a small parking area, surrounded by tall trees.
images.caption: Parking for Picnic Area B doubles as overflow parking for the Hurricane Hill Trail. Photo by D. Sullivan/NPS.

bodyText: Open summer only, located one mile (1.6 km) beyond the visitor center, with restrooms, water and paved trails to tables. The parking area doubles as overflow parking for the Hurricane Hill Trail, just a short walk through the forest away.
audioDescription: Hurricane Hill Picnic Area B. 20 seconds A path leads to a mowed area with picnic tables, log benches, and a trash can. A meadow, shrubs, and tall trees surround the area.

title: Hurricane Hill Trailhead
listingDescription: One of the most popular day hikes is the Hurricane Hill trail, about 3 miles (4.8 km) round trip and climbing 700 feet (213 meters) to a high point with 360-degree views in clear weather. The trailhead is at the end of the road, just 1.3 miles (2.1 km) past the Hurricane Ridge Visitor Center. Overflow parking is available at Picnic Area B.

images.altText: A hiker and wheelchair user on a paved trail with mountains in the background.
images.title: Hurricane Hill Trail
images.caption: A wheelchair user and hiker on Hurricane Hill

bodyText:
One of the most popular day hikes is the Hurricane Hill trail, about 3 miles (4.8 km) round trip and climbing 700 feet (213 meters) to a high point with 360-degree views in clear weather. The trailhead is at the end of the road, just 1.3 miles (2.1 km) past the Hurricane Ridge Visitor Center. Overflow parking is available at Picnic Area B.
 

Full Accessibility Description

Length: 8,600 feet, 1.63 miles
Surface Type: Asphalt pavement
Typical Trail Width: 8 Feet
Typical Running Slope: First 2,700 feet under 5% with one 150 foot stretch from 7-9%. From 2,700-8,550 feet very steep with many sections 15-20%.
Typical Cross Slope: Less than 1%
Elevation Gain/ Loss: First 2,700 feet: net gain 10 feet, maximum gain/ loss 20 feet. Entire Trail: 645 feet
Accessible Parking: Van-accessible parking immediately across from the trailhead
Description: The Hurricane Hill trailhead is at the end of the Hurricane Hill Road, 2 miles past the Hurricane Ridge Visitor Center. The trail starts at the northwest corner of the parking area and contours to the south side of the hill offering spectacular views of the Olympic Mountains. At the top, there are also views to the north of Griff Peak, Vancouver Island and the Strait of Juan de Fuca.

Initially the trail goes downhill for 400 feet at a gentle grade under 6%. From 400 to 750 feet, the trail proceeds uphill. This stretch is at 7% with a steeper 150-foot stretch in the middle at 8-9%. The trail levels out at the top and is under 2% grade for the next 650 feet. At 1,400 feet, the trail heads downhill around a curve at less than 5% grade for the next 300 feet. The trail is on a steeply-cut bank through this section with exposure to a considerable drop on the outside edge. Those affected by heights may wish to remain on the inside edge of the trail.

The trail continues through gradual ups and downs under 5% until 2,450 feet. From 2,450 to 2,700 feet the trail again goes downhill at about 6%. This is a good location to consider turning back. It is a strenuous hike past this point. From 2,700 to 3,700 feet, the trail is extremely steep with grades ranging from 10 to 18%. The trail continues uphill to its terminus at the top of Hurricane Hill, alternating between moderately steep and extremely steep grades as follows:
From 3,700 to 3,900 feet, grades range from 4-6%
From 3,900 to 4,300 feet, grades range from 8-11%
From 4,300 to 5,700 feet, grades range less than 8%
From 5,700 to 8,200 feet, grades range from 10-18%
audioDescription: Hurricane Hill Trailhead. 2 minutes Parking at the trailhead is along the right side of the road. The trail is across the road on the left. At the trailhead on the right is a wooden bulletin board where park information is posted. An interpretive panel is attached to the board on the left. Filling the top of the panel is a map of the trail with the text, You Are Here, noted toward the bottom. Text below the map reads, Hurricane Hill Trail. The 1.6-mile trail to Hurricane Hill ascends gradually at first, then climbs more steeply through subalpine meadows. From the top there are views of the Olympic Mountains to the south and Vancouver Island, British Columbia to the north. Average hiking time to top is one and one-half hours. Elevation gain is 650 feet. Text continues: Window on the Wilderness. On this hike you can get a taste of Wilderness without packing deep into backcountry. No roads slice the interior. Except for the trail, there are few signs of human impact. To the left of the text is a black and white illustration of a robust black bear in profile facing right. Trees grow in the background. On the right side of the bulletin board are posted park notices and regulations. About 20 feet up trail, a two-foot-tall log post stands in the center of the trail. To its right is a sign on a taller post that reads: No pets, weapons, or vehicles.

title: Hurricane Ridge Road
listingDescription: Hurricane Ridge Road This is the easiest way to reach beautiful panoramic views of the Olympic Mountains and explore the subalpine ecosystem, just a 45-minute drive from Port Angeles. Drive carefully and keep an eye out for rocks and wildlife on the road! In winter, the road may be closed certain days (it is generally plowed on weekends as weather allows), and all vehicles are required to carry tire chains in case of icy road conditions. The road to Hurricane Ridge leads up 1

images.altText: A road winds up a mountain at sunrise.
images.caption: Photo by G. Longenbaugh/NPS.

bodyText:
Hurricane Ridge Road This is the easiest way to reach beautiful panoramic views of the Olympic Mountains and explore the subalpine ecosystem, just a 45-minute drive from Port Angeles. Drive carefully and keep an eye out for rocks and wildlife on the road! In winter, the road may be closed certain days (it is generally plowed on weekends as weather allows), and all vehicles are required to carry tire chains in case of icy road conditions.

The road to Hurricane Ridge leads up 17 miles (27.3 km) into the subalpine ecosystem of Olympic National Park, reaching an elevation of 5,242 feet (1,600 meters) at the Hurricane Ridge Visitor Center. Along the way, the Heart O' the Hills entrance station, campground and trailheads are five miles (8 km) up the road, and there are several scenic pullouts with spectacular views of the mountains, forests and the Strait of Juan de Fuca.

The road may close with short notice due to rapidly changing weather conditions. Fog, falling rocks and wildlife along the road are potential hazards year round, and snow, avalanches and the plowing schedule affect winter opening. Drive safely and always check at the Visitor Center for the latest road and weather updates, or call 360-565-3131. It is very dangerous to stop your vehicle in the road to look at wildlife, so if you must stop, please use a pullout.

title: Irely Lake Trailhead
listingDescription:
This 2.8 mile/4.5 km round trip, creek-side hike leads through the forest to Irely Lake. There may be stream crossings, and there is a ladder at the end that you will need both hands to climb. Always carry your Ten Essentials, and contact the Wilderness Information Center for trail conditions or to plan an overnight trip in the backcountry.
https://www.nps.gov/olym/planyourvisit/wic.htm
https://www.nps.gov/articles/10essentials.htm

images.altText: A black and white symbol for trailhead with a figure of a person with a walking stick and backpack.

bodyText: This 2.8 mile/4.5 km round trip, creek-side hike leads through the forest to Irely Lake. There may be stream crossings, and there is a ladder at the end that you will need both hands to climb. Always carry your Ten Essentials, and contact the Wilderness Information Center for trail conditions or to plan an overnight trip in the backcountry.
audioDescription: Irely Lake Trailhead. 30 seconds The trailhead is directly off the gravel parking lot. A brown wooden sign with white text provides mileage to locations along the trail. These read, Irely Lake 1.1. Three Lakes 7. Skyline Trail 7. Low Divide 30.7. Up trail on the right is a roof covered bulletin board with posted park regulations regarding fishing, pets, wilderness, firearm and weapon, and stock use. Other notices include information about Wildlife, Food, and Your Safety, River Crossings, You Are in Cougar Country, Fish Advisory, and in an emergency contact a ranger or dial 911. The trail enters a forest of tall, pine trees mixed with deciduous trees. Low growing plants edge the trail.

title: James Pond Trailhead
listingDescription: This flat, 0.4 mile (0.6 km) loop trail winds through the forest to James Pond. Look for yellow pond lilies in summer!

images.altText: A sign next to forest trail reads "James Pond."
images.caption: Pond. James Pond.

bodyText: This flat, 0.4 mile (0.6 km) loop trail winds through the forest to James Pond. Look for yellow pond lilies in summer!
audioDescription: James Pond Trailhead. 1 minute A brown and white wooden sign with the text, James Pond, marks the tailhead. In the vicinity is a tall, thin grey wooden bulletin board with park information. Dogs are not allowed on the trail. Where the flat trail enters the woods, the surface is gravel before transitioning to dirt. Along the edge of the trail are green mosses and other low growing and mid-story green plants. The forest is dense with tall pine trees. Green moss hangs from tree branches like tattered draperies.

title: July Creek Loop Trail Trailhead

images.altText: A trail leads toward a wooden bridge in the forest. A lake is slightly visible through the trees.
images.title: Bridge on July Creek Loop trail
images.caption: July Creek Loop near Lake Quinault.

bodyText: A loop branching from the July Creek Picnic Area trail.
audioDescription: July Creek Loop Trail Trailhead. 1 minute In the parking lot to the right of the restroom is the main trailhead. A sign on the left of trail reads, July Creek Picnic Area. A sign below indicates no camping. On the right, another sign with an upward pointing arrow reads, Loop Trail. The trail surface is gravel and mostly flat. The trail passes through a forest of tall trees, some large in diameter. At one point the trail crosses over a wooden bridge with handrails. There are two additional access points for the trail. One is located at the far-left corner of the parking lot. There are two signs, here. One reads, Day Use Only, no camping. The other has arrows pointing to the left and right and reads, Loop Trail. The second access point is up the road. A sign at the trailhead reads, Loop Trail, with an arrow pointing to the right.

title: July Creek Picnic Area Trailhead
listingDescription: July Creek Picnic Area has a short trail to tables for a picnic with a view on the North shore of Lake Quinault.

images.altText: A picnic site with table and fire ring among large conifer trees.
images.title: July Creek Picnic Area
images.caption: A picnic spot at July Creek

bodyText:
July Creek Picnic Area has a short trail to tables for a picnic with a view on the North shore of Lake Quinault.

 

Full Accessibility Description

Length: 1,020 feet, .19 miles
Surface Type: Compacted gravel
Typical Trail Width: 3-5 feet
Typical Running Slope: Steep entry and exit from picnic area with grades up to 13%; grades below 7% in picnic area; level return to parking area on reaching road
Typical Cross Slope: Less than 1% (some sections of trail heavily crowned)
Accessible Parking: Van-accessible parking in parking area
Description: Formerly a campground, the July Creek Picnic Area contains outstanding examples of large Douglas-fir trees, 6 feet in diameter and larger. There is a handicap parking space directly in front of the trail. The loop trail leaves from the center of the parking area, with a 2-inch lip at the curb ramp. There is a 25-foot uphill slope at 10% grade before the trail starts downhill to the picnic area. The first 40 feet of the descent are steep, with 10-13% grade. The descent becomes gradually gentler for the next 120 feet before reaching the picnic area. There are two picnic sites to the right at the bottom of the hill. The trail continues to the left at a very gentle grade, and at 225 feet a bridge crosses over July Creek.

The trail is fairly level for the next 200 feet, then begins to climb back towards North Shore Road. At 420 feet, there is a brief section at 10-12%, then the grade drops under 7% until the last 50 feet up to the road which is again at 10-13%. At 650 feet, the trail meets the road and then runs along the road for 220 feet to return to the parking lot. Once back at the parking lot, follow the sidewalk back to the starting point.
audioDescription: July Creek Picnic Area Trailhead. 30 seconds On the edge of and facing the parking lot is an accessible, all gender, single stall restroom building with a vault toilet. Enter on the left. To the right of the restroom, a trail enters the woods. A sign on the left of trail reads, July Creek Picnic Area and a sign on the right with an upward pointing arrow, reads, Loop Trail. Along the trail are individual picnic sites with a table, and in some, a metal fire grate. The surface in the picnic areas is dirt and may be uneven.

title: Kalaloch Amphitheater

images.altText: Black and white symbol for amphitheater with the figure of a person at the front and bench seating facing them.

bodyText: Amphitheater at Kalaloch Campground.
audioDescription: Kalaloch Amphitheater. 1 minute On a downward sloping surface, are nine rows of wooden bench seats, separated into three sections by aisles. In front of these benches are four more rows of benches with no aisles. At the bottom of the slope is a white, wooden building with a flat blue roof atop a two-foot-high concrete stage with a short stairway on each side. The center of the building is recessed toward the back with two doors that open to reveal a projection screen. Painted on the doors is a red, black, and white American Indian Thunderbird symbol, its head and thick curved beak are raised and faced right, its wings outstretched to the left and right. The projection booth is in the back of the amphitheater at the top of the slope. The amphitheater is surrounded by a forest of tall trees.

title: Kalaloch Amphitheater Trailhead

images.altText: A black and white symbol for trailhead with a figure of a person with a walking stick and backpack.

bodyText: Trailhead to Kalaloch Campground amphitheater.
audioDescription: Amphitheater Trailhead. 30 seconds A brown wooden sign with white text and a left pointing arrow is posted at the trailhead. It reads, Evening Program. The flat, gravel trail winds through ferns, low growing bushes, and tall pine trees, then crosses a wooden bridge with handrails an open amphitheater area. Bench seating is on the left.

title: Kalaloch Beach Trailhead

images.altText: A trailhead with a glimpse of beach beyond.

bodyText: The trail and stairs that reach the beach have been damaged by storm activity, but there is still a fire pit and viewpoint at this location.
audioDescription: Kalaloch Beach Trailhead. 1 minutes At the end of the parking lot across from the trailhead is a flat gravel path leading to a diamond shaped gravel area outlined with wooden timbers. A sign reads: Kalaloch Lodge. Olympic National Park. Fire Circle. Please don’t leave fire unattended at any time. Thank you. Please see front desk if you would like help starting a fire. Near the center of the area is a round, two-foot-tall stone fire pit. Split log benches without backs or armrests are place around the pit. Within the gravel footprint is a picnic table. Outside gravel area is a grass lawn where chairs with backs and armrests are located. A fence along the edge of the grass on the ocean has a sign that reads: Restricted Area.

title: Kalaloch Big Cedar Tree - Parking Area
listingDescription: An easy one-mile loop trail leads to this forest giant. Even half-fallen, its height and mass are incredible.

images.altText: The exposed roots of a massive tree
images.title: Kalaloch Big Cedar
images.caption: The Kalaloch Big Cedar tree's exposed root system.

bodyText:
An easy one-mile loop trail leads to this forest giant. Even half-fallen, its height and mass are incredible.

 

 

Full Accessibility Description

Length: 1,665 feet, .32 miles, from parking out to “lollipop,” or loop, ending and back
Surface Type: Compacted gravel
Typical Trail Width: 5-6 feet narrowing to 3 feet at “lollipop” ending
Typical Running Slope: Under 5% with brief 6.5% stretch in the middle and 100 feet at 6% on the northern section of the loop ending
Typical Cross Slope: Mostly under 1%, though sections have a significant crown (higher in the middle than on the edges)
Description: A storm in 2014 felled half of the Big Cedar tree, but what remains is still an impressive sight, as is the fallen half on the ground. The trailhead is at the end of a .2-mile gravel road. The parking area is gravel with no defined parking spaces. The Big Cedar itself is just 110 feet from the trailhead. The trail circles the tree to the left and continues east into the lush coastal forest. Please resist the urge to climb on this ancient giant. The trail is wide and stable, but the edges slope off steeply where the trail goes around the tree.

After the tree split in 2014, a trail was constructed that continues 690 feet into the forest and has a loop, or lollipop, ending that runs adjacent to another impressive cedar. The “lollipop” ending narrows to 3-foot width, is crowned, and has steep slopes on both sides where substantial gravel fill was added to even the grade. The trail is typically under 5% grade, with one brief section at 6.5% grade in the center. The lollipop portion of the trail narrows to 3 feet and the gravel slopes off steeply on either side. Wheelchair users should exercise caution if navigating the loop. The loop is 285 feet in circumference. The north side has a 6% grade for 105 feet. Upon completing the loop, return on the same trail to the parking area.
audioDescription: Big Cedar Parking Area. 15 seconds This parking lot has a dirt and gravel surface. The trailhead to Big Cedar is off the parking lot.

title: Kalaloch Campground Beach Trailhead

images.altText: A black and white symbol for trailhead with a figure of a person with a walking stick and backpack.

bodyText: Trailhead to the beach from the Kalaloch Campground.
audioDescription: Beach Trailhead. 1 minute A sign at the trailhead along the campground loop road reads: Pets must be on leash at all times. The dirt trail passes through a forest of sparse trees and a thick understory of ferns and shrubs that tightly edge each side of the trail. Be advised. In places along the trail, tree roots and rocks create an uneven surface, and near the entrance to the beach, logs have been placed across the trail to form three wide steps. At the end of the trail, the beach begins with a surface of roundish rocks, then transitions to sand closer to the ocean.

title: Kalaloch Campground Fish Cleaning Station and Restroom

images.altText: Black and white symbol for restroom with male and female figures separated by a wall.

bodyText: Fish cleaning station and restroom for Kalaloch Campground.
audioDescription: Fish Cleaning Station and Restroom. 2 minutes Along the loop road on the right is a white, rectangular restroom building with a blue metal roof. The women’s room is on the left short side of the building, and the men’s room is on the right short side of the building. The surface around the building is paved and flat. In front of the restroom is a roof covered bulletin board with two vertical posts at each front corner. Notices are posted on both sides of the board. Information includes campground, pet, fishing, tidepool, and beach regulations; a notice to contact a park ranger or dial 911 in an emergency; a warning about bears frequenting the area; a sign stating no fireworks; nearest services, and a map of the Kalaloch area. A row of dumpsters is located to the left of the restroom building. To the right of the building is a square, 3-foot-tall stone water station. It’s two spigots face the road. Behind the water station, a dirt path leads to a fish cleaning station behind the restroom. It is a roof covered, wooden structure with a table about 3 feet high and about 20 feet long on a concrete pad. In the center of the table is a metal trough with drains that runs the length of the table. Above the trough is a water pipe with spigots evenly spaced along the pipe.

title: Kalaloch Campground Loop A Beach Access Trail

images.altText: A black and white symbol for trailhead with a figure of a person with a walking stick and backpack.

bodyText: Trail to beach from Kalaloch Campground Loop A.
audioDescription: Kalaloch Campground Loop A Beach Access. 4 minutes On the right side of the campground loop road overlooking the ocean is a pull off with parking. An eight-inch-high concrete edge separates the parking lot and a small grass and gravel area where a picnic table is located. To the right of the table, a brown sign with white text reads, Day Use Only, and below, another sign reads, Pets must be on leash at all times. About 4 feet to the right on a slight downward sloping hill is a three-foot-tall, angled wayside panel with blue and white illustrations of whales. Text on the right reads: Whale Watching. Twice a year California gray whales swim past, sometimes between Destruction Island and this beach. In the fall they are migrating south to calve and nurse in the warm lagoons of Baja California. The gray whales return in early spring on their way to arctic feeding grounds where they comb clouds of shrimp-like creatures from the water. Somehow, across 4000 miles of ocean, the huge mammals navigate precisely, on a predictable timetable. Watch for signs. Fifteen-foot spouts of warm condensing breath punctuate the rhythm of diving and breathing. Occasionally gray whales breach, burst from the water, turn and fall back with a tremendous splash, just playing, or maybe checking their bearings. Filling the left side of the panel is a long, blimp shaped whale with dark skin and patches of white, its opened mouth revealing a curtain of hair-like baleen. A map to the right of the whale has a line of arrows marking the round-trip migration route of Grey whales from their northern summer feeding grounds in the Bering Sea off the west coast of Alaska, then along the west coast of the United States, to their southern mating and calving area in lagoons off the west coast of Mexico. In the center of the panel, three small illustrations show different whale behaviors. From left to right, a submerged whale points downward, only its V-shaped tail above water. Next, a whale underwater with only its head above water and the caption, Spyhopping. Sometimes whales stand nose-up to have a look around. Finally, a whale tail above water with the caption, Diving. As a whale begins a sustained dive, the flukes rise dramatically before disappearing beneath the surface. Spanning the bottom of the panel is a horizontal diagram showing nine positions of a swimming whale, underwater at times, then rising to the surface to breathe. A caption reads, Spouting. Gray whales swim in a pattern that makes them easy to spot. It usually consists of 3 to 5 spouts, followed by a dive that lasts 2 to 5 minutes as they swim along at about 5 miles per hour. After this dive they surface and repeat their breathing pattern. To the right of this wayside, a paved trail leads down a hill to the beach below. In places the pavement is uneven. About 10-feet down the path on the left is a second wayside panel titled, Drift Logs and Riptides. Filling the left side of the panel is a blue and white aerial view drawing showing the churning water of a rip current rolling perpendicular to the shoreline through a narrow gap between the shore and a sandbar. Text in the top right reads: Beach logs are the bones of a rain forest picked clean by the sea. They begin in river valleys—giant conifers like Sitka spruce. When a day’s downpour adds to glacial melt the stream may rise six feet, undermining the bank and toppling trees into the flood, washing them down to river mouth and beach. Some fall from eroding headlands. Numbered trunks are strays from tug-pulled log rafts. Drift logs are dangerous. At high tide they may suddenly roll. Unwary people have been crushed and killed by drift logs. Riptides make swimming and wading dangerous. There are no lifeguards. Swimmers beware. Below the text is a smaller drawing at beach level of a jumbled pile of drift logs. Where the paved path ends, a staircase with eight steps descends to the beach. Unfinished wooden handrails are on each side of the steps. At the bottom, rocks jut out of the sandy surface and log walls create a tunnel-like entrance onto the beach. Be advised: spanning this entryway on the ground is a drift log.

title: Kalaloch Campground Loop D Beach Trail

images.altText: A black and white symbol for trailhead with a figure of a person with a walking stick and backpack.

bodyText: Trail to the beach from Loop D of Kalaloch Campground.
audioDescription: Beach Access Trailhead. 1 minute At the edge of the parking lot is a brown and white wooden sign on a post with a right pointing arrow and the text, Beach Trail. Below this sign is a blue and white metal sign that reads, Pets must be on leash at all times. A black graphic of a dog on a leash is below the text. A third sign has a graphic indicating no bikes allowed, and a final sign states firework are prohibited. The slightly steep and narrow gravel trail joins a stairway with handrail leading down to the beach. The trail is flanked on both sides by low growing foliage.

title: Kalaloch Campground RV Dump Station

images.altText: A black and white symbol of an RV dumping waste.

bodyText: RV dump station for Kalaloch Campground.
audioDescription: RV Dump Station. 90 seconds On the left side of the one-way campground loop road is the dump station. On a post is a brown sign with white text that reads, RV Septic Dump Station. $10 per use. $5 with Interagency Senior or Access Pass. Not included in camping fee. Below the sign is an open fronted box with a metal box inside holding payment slips. To the right of the post is a three-foot-tall metal cannister with a slot at the top for depositing payment. To the left of the payment center is the ground level drain area on the pavement. Behind it on the grass is a vertical board with a hose spigot and a sign with dumping station instructions. Text reads: 1. Connect your hose to trailer holding tank. 2. Insert hose end securely into drain, holding cover open with a foot. Open trailer drain valve. 3. Wash any spillage into the drain using water provided. Danger. Not to be used for drinking or domestic purposes. To the right of the payment station is a blue, square wooden crate-like box. A blue pole with a hose attached to the end rises out of the center of box. A sign next to the box reads: Clean water. Use this hose for filling domestic tank only.

title: Kalaloch Campground Registration

images.altText: A black and white icon of a person in a backpack reading a sign of some kind.

bodyText: Information and campsite registration for Kalaloch Campground.
audioDescription: Kalaloch Campground Registration. 1 minute On an island in the parking lot is a small, one room Campground Registration Office. One side of the building has a window for speaking with park staff during office hours. Next to the office is a roof-covered two-sided bulletin board with campground registration information for Loops D, E, and F. On one side of the bulletin board in the lower right corner is the campground registration board, a framed box divided into rows of individual square sections. Each square is numbered and corresponds to a campsite. Each row is covered by a hard, clear plastic strip with a slot for dropping one of two registration payment receipts into an individual square. On the far left is a brown box with a lid holding campground registration envelopes. Standing in front of the bulletin board is a two-foot-tall cannister for depositing the envelope with payment. On the face of the cannister, at the top, is a slot for slipping in the envelope.

title: Kalaloch Creek Nature Trail
listingDescription: Kalaloch Creek Nature Trail is a short (0.8 mile/1.3 km) loop through coastal rain forest, starting in Loop A of the Kalaloch campground.

images.altText: A path through the forest.

bodyText: Kalaloch Creek Nature Trail is a short (0.8 mile/1.3 km) loop through coastal rain forest, starting in Loop A of the Kalaloch campground.
audioDescription: Nature Trailhead. 1 minute Along the campground loop road a sign indicates the trailhead location for the Nature Trail. On the right before the trail begins is a brown metal food locker and a bulletin board on a paved surface. A posted notice reads, The Kalaloch Nature Trail is an eight-tenths of a mile long and consists of a straight trail with a loop at the end. It has some stairs and crosses several wooden bridges. Welcome to the lush world of the coastal rainforest. Text continues, No Bicycles, No Pets, Report wildlife sightings, and where to find more information. Other posts state the pet regulations, how to help preserve the park, and a warning about bears in the area. Be advised. Where the pavement ends and the trail begins is a rough transition and spanning from the left side of the trail to the middle of the trail, is a thin concrete slab in the ground. The trail passes through a dense forest of towering trees hanging with moss and an understory of ferns and other plants. At one point the trail crosses the road. On the other side a sign reads, Kalaloch Creek Nature Trail.

title: Kalaloch Lodge
listingDescription:
This striking historic lodge is open year-round and was built in 1953 from wood milled from the giant drift logs that still wash up today. It sits right above the beach, looking out at the water, and has rooms and cabins available upon reservation. There is a dining room with ocean views, a gift shop, and a general store.
www.thekalalochlodge.com

images.altText: A lodge building with wooden shingles on a bluff.
images.title: Kalaloch Lodge
images.caption: Kalaloch Lodge

bodyText: This striking historic lodge is open year-round and was built in 1953 from wood milled from the giant drift logs that still wash up today. It sits right above the beach, looking out at the water, and has rooms and cabins available upon reservation. There is a dining room with ocean views, a gift shop, and a general store.
audioDescription: Kalaloch Lodge. 2 minutes The lodge is a long rectangular two-story building that sits parallel to the road on the front side and to the ocean on the back side. It has a wooden singled roof and weathered brown shingles as siding. A brown square sign attached to the front of the building with white text reads, Kalaloch Lodge. In the center of the sign is an arch shaped carved image with white sand and blue water at the bottom, topped with black mountains and green trees under a blue sky with white clouds. Another brown sign to the right has a large fork, knife, and spoon in white. The left side of the building facing the road is slightly angled backward and has a covered porch. The entrance is located here. A stairway with three steps up is located on the right side of the porch and a ramp is located on the left side of the porch. Two signs in the shape of arrows pointing to the right are attached to the porch railing. One reads, Registration and the other, Restaurant. The porch and windows are trimmed in blue. A brick chimney on the left side of the building has a brick and concrete archway attached like a wing off its left side. A sidewalk passes under the arch and veers to the left leading to the parking lot and Mercantile store, and to the right behind the lodge and the first-floor ocean side deck. A long staircase with handrails leads to a second-floor deck. Access to the decks is also through the front entrance of the lodge. The Kalaloch Mercantile is across the parking lot to the left of the lodge. It is a one-story shingled building facing the roadway with the entrance door a bit right of center. A restroom is available around the right side of the building. Attached to the wall to the right of the restroom entrance is a bulletin board with changing information about beach, fishing and pet regulations, tides, ranger programs, nearest services, safety around wildlife, and what to do in an emergency. Contact a ranger or Dial 911.

title: Kalaloch Lodge Trailhead
listingDescription: Be careful on this trail from Kalaloch Campground to Kalaloch Lodge, much of the short route is right alongside Highway 101.

images.altText: A trail runs just on the other side of a highway guardrail.

bodyText: Be careful on this trail from Kalaloch Campground to Kalaloch Lodge, much of the short route is right alongside Highway 101.
audioDescription: Kalaloch Lodge Trailhead. 1 minute This flat, dirt trail off the campground loop road leads through a forest of tall pine trees and a thick understory of ferns and other shrubs that edge the trail. About 65-feet up trail, a sign with an arrow pointing to the right reads, Lodge Trail. A split-rail fence on the left begins here for about 60-feet as the trail parallels the highway. About 10-feet from the end of the fence the trail passes over a wooden bridge with a short concrete railing on the left and a wooden plank fence on the right. On the other side of the bridge, a highway barricade extends about 20 feet on the left, then ends at the paved road shoulder.

title: Kalaloch Ranger Station
listingDescription: The ranger station building is currently closed as Covid-19 safety measure, with information set up outside. With a whale skull and wooden canoe outside, the Kalaloch Ranger Station is hard to miss! Inside, you'll find exhibits and information, plus maps and books for sale. Pick up a tide chart while you're there to plan your beach hikes or tidepooling! Open summer only.

images.altText: A sign among greenery reads "Kalaloch Ranger Station."

bodyText: The ranger station building is currently closed as Covid-19 safety measure, with information set up outside. With a whale skull and wooden canoe outside, the Kalaloch Ranger Station is hard to miss! Inside, you'll find exhibits and information, plus maps and books for sale. Pick up a tide chart while you're there to plan your beach hikes or tidepooling! Open summer only.

title: Kestner Homestead
listingDescription: Learn about homestead life on this flat, self-guided 1.3-mile (2.1 km) loop from the Quinault Rain Forest Ranger Station.

images.altText: A large, wood-shingled, historic building
images.title: Kestner Homestead
images.caption: The Kestner Homestead

bodyText: Learn about homestead life on this flat, self-guided 1.3-mile (2.1 km) loop from the Quinault Rain Forest Ranger Station.
audioDescription: Kestner Homestead. Overview. 90 seconds At the entrance to the gravel parking lot on the left, a brown sign reads, Ranger Station, and has an arrow pointing up trail. Pet Regulations are attached to the signpost. The trail to the Homestead begins at the top of the lot. The trail is wide, flat and a combination of gravel and grass. Almost immediately, the trail reaches a swinging metal gate across the entrance to a wooden bridge. Access to the bridge is on the right side of the gate. A sign at the front of the bridge reads, Please walk on metal grate. This flat, 20-inch-wide expanded metal grate extends down the center of the bridge surface. The bridge has side railings and crosses over a gravel bottom creek. The homestead begins once across the bridge. On each side of the trail are split rail fences. On the left, an orchard grows in a meadow. On the right is a wide meadow. Straight ahead on the left are the homestead buildings. A dense forest of pine trees surrounds the homestead property and in the distance are forested mountains. Continue listening to hear a description of the buildings. 3 Minutes A wide grassy area surrounds the buildings. An old rusty piece of farm equipment sits weathering in the grass. A bathtub lays behind a fence. On the left are three side-by-side buildings. The first is a long, rectangular, wooden-shingled, two-story building with an A-frame peaked roof covered with wide cedar shakes. The shingles and shakes are silvery-brown and weathered. On the left short side of the building is a covered porch with a front door centered on the wall flanked on each side by a white framed window. Above the porch roof is a bank of four windows and at the roof peak, a small window. There is no access through the front door. On the side of the building facing the trail are two large and two small windows left and center followed by an open passageway through the building to the other side. A fifth window is to the right of the passageway. Inside the passageway, the floor surface is concrete as it crosses the building and in places uneven, and then gravel along the sides. Large overhead wooden beams are supported by thick vertical posts. The other side of the building has the same window configuration. The second building is a one-story square, brown wooden structure with wide, silver colored cedar shakes on a peaked roof. The bottom half of the left side of the building is fully open and used as storage. Next to this building on the left is a split rail fence, then a grassy area where the third building is located. It is a barn. It’s red, metal roof is tall and peaked in the center, then flares out and down like extended wings supported on each end by short walls. The front and back of the barn have no solid walls leaving the framework of beams exposed. Inside on a gravel surface are picnic tables. Behind these buildings is a tall wooden structure with a roof and no sides and a small brown, wooden plank building with a door. Beside this building is an old, red farm truck and other farming equipment. Further back is a white, metal modern building. Near this building is a sign on a post with arrows pointing to the left with the text, Kestner Homestead Trail. Maple Glade Forest Trail 0.7 miles.

title: Kestner Homestead Loop Trail
listingDescription: Learn about homestead life on this flat, self-guided 1.3-mile (2.1 km) loop from the Quinault Rain Forest Ranger Station.

images.altText: Dilapidated wooden buildings
images.title: Kestner Homestead outbuildings
images.caption: Outbuildings at the Kestner Homestead

bodyText: Learn about homestead life on this flat, self-guided 1.3-mile (2.1 km) loop from the Quinault Rain Forest Ranger Station.
audioDescription: Kestner Homestead Loop Trail. 1 minute On a wooden sign posted at the back of the Homestead property are arrows pointing to the left and the text, Kestner Homestead Trail. Maple Glade Forest Trail 0.7 miles. After passing buildings on the left and right the loop trail enters the forest where the trail transitions to dirt and becomes narrower. Pine tree branches covered in hanging moss reach out across the trail overhead. Tall green ferns and other low growing plants carpet the ground on each side of the trail. In places, flat wooden bridges with log side bumpers cross small streams. Some bridge surfaces may be rough and uneven. At an intersection in the trail is a directional sign with the distance to the Ranger Station. Going left is 0.2 miles. Going right is 0.3 miles.

title: Kestner Homestead Parking

images.altText: An old road leads past mossy trees and blooming fruit trees in fields to a homestead.
images.title: Kestner Homestead approach
images.caption: The Kestner Homestead in spring

bodyText: The closest access to the Kestner Homestead. The homestead can also be reached via trails from the Quinault Rain Forest Ranger Station.
audioDescription: Kestner Homestead Parking. 30 seconds The parking lot surface is dirt and gravel. The path to the Homestead begins at the end of the parking area. On the left side of the parking lot, a brown sign reads, Ranger Station, and has an arrow pointing up trail. Pet Regulations are attached to the signpost.

title: Kestner Homestead Trailhead
listingDescription: Learn about homestead life on this flat, self-guided 1.3-mile (2.1 km) loop from the Quinault Rain Forest Ranger Station.

images.altText: A historic homestead and barn with an apple tree in bloom.
images.title: The Kestner Homestead in spring
images.caption: The Kestner Homestead in spring.

bodyText:
Learn about homestead life on this flat, self-guided 1.3-mile (2.1 km) loop from the Quinault Rain Forest Ranger Station.

 

Full Accessibility Description

Length: 6,940 feet, 1.3 miles
Surface Type: Compacted gravel
Typical Trail Width:3-5 feet
Typical Running Slope: From Maple Glade start to the homestead, less than 7% (Maximum slope 10%). From kiosk start to the homestead, less than 5%
Typical Cross Slope: Less than 1% (the first bridge has a cross slope of 4% for the last 15 feet)
Description: This loop trail may be travelled in either direction: Following the Maple Glade Trail going left at the first junction, and then left again at 1,050 feet when reaching the sign for the Kestner Homestead Trail; or starting at the information kiosk. Starting from the Maple Glade Trail, it is .77 miles to the homestead. After leaving the Maple Glade Trail, the trail rolls up and down through a forest heavy with maple trees, and the tread is generally clear of obstacles. There is a 40-foot bridge at 1,125 feet, followed by 2 slightly steep sections (10 feet at 7% at 1,560 feet and 30 feet at 6-8% at 1,710 feet) before reaching a mossy bench at 1,710 feet. From the bench, there is a gradual hill for 290 feet at up to 7% grade. At 2,080 feet, the trail narrows to 3 feet. There is a 30-foot 8-10% downhill at 3,770 feet followed by a 25-foot bridge at 3,715 feet. The boundary of the Kestner Homestead is at 4,075 feet. From this point back to the kiosk at the parking area the trail is mostly flat.

The first 170 feet of trail through the homestead is clumped with grass followed by a 110-foot section where the trail is all grass. Turning right at the homestead residence, the trail follows the original entrance road past the orchard for 500 feet before crossing a bridge over Kestner Creek. The decking of the bridge is pending replacement and a 2-foot-wide path of expanded metal is in place the length of the bridge to provide secure footing. Continuing around the gate at the end of the bridge, the trail turns right just before reaching the North Shore Road. From here it is 1,840 feet back to the trailhead kiosk at the parking area. There is a short stretch after turning along the road that is 3-feet wide and there is an adjacent ditch. Wheelchair users should exercise caution. There are roots that rise 2” above the trail tread at 5,800 and 6,490 feet.

For those wishing to visit the homestead on a less-strenuous hike, depart from the trailhead kiosk and return the same way. This is a 1.1-mile round trip.
audioDescription: Kestner Homestead Trailhead. 2 minutes On the forest side of the parking lot which is lined with concrete parking bumpers is a concrete pad where a roof covered bulletin board stands.
