Posted on the board is information about pet and park regulations; firearms and weapons; bear and cougar awareness; no fireworks allowed; backcountry safety; nearest services; local trails; and a notice to contact a park ranger or dial 911 in an emergency. Behind and to the right of the bulletin board is a brown wooden sign that reads: Kestner Homestead Trail. A second sign reads: No pets, weapons, or vehicles. To the left of this sign is a brown box on a post with a sign on the hinged lid that reads, Trail Brochures. Welcome. We hope you enjoy exploring Olympic National Park. Donations for these trail brochures are accepted at park visitor centers. Thank you for your support. The sign ends with this quote by John Muir: In every walk with Nature one receives far more than he seeks. Filling the right side of the sign is a green and white illustration showing a high mountain peak with a forest and lake below. The dirt trail begins to the right of the trail sign and winds through a forest of tall trees, some covered with hanging green moss. The understory is a dense carpet of ferns, mosses, and other plants.

title: La Poel Picnic Area
listingDescription: Open in summer, La Poel is a forested picnic area with fire pits, picnic tables, an accessible outhouse, and views of Lake Crescent. Not suitable for RVs, trailers, buses - the road is steep, winding, and narrow.

images.altText: A picnic table among the trees, overlooking a lake.

bodyText: Open in summer, La Poel is a forested picnic area with fire pits, picnic tables, an accessible outhouse, and views of Lake Crescent. Not suitable for RVs, trailers, buses - the road is steep, winding, and narrow.
audioDescription: La Poel Picnic Area. 45 seconds A sign at the entrance reads, La Poel Day Use Area. Closed at dusk. Graphics indicate that picnic tables are available. Camping trailers and tent camping are not permitted. A second sign reads, Keep Right. An all gender, single stall, accessible restroom with a vault toilet is located in this area. Enter on the left front side of the building beneath an open alcove. The door to the restroom is on the right.

title: Lake Angeles and Heather Park Trailheads
listingDescription: To reach this trailhead, make sure to drive to the end of the road (you will pass some buildings with parking areas, but these are private housing - not for public use). From here, climb 4 miles (6.4 km) to the wildflower meadows of Heather Park, or 3.4 miles (5.4 km) to the mirror-like waters of Lake Angeles.

images.altText: A mountain like with snow all around
images.title: Lake Angeles in the snow
images.caption: Lake Angeles in the snow

bodyText: To reach this trailhead, make sure to drive to the end of the road (you will pass some buildings with parking areas, but these are private housing - not for public use). From here, climb 4 miles (6.4 km) to the wildflower meadows of Heather Park, or 3.4 miles (5.4 km) to the mirror-like waters of Lake Angeles.
audioDescription: Lake Angeles - Heather Park Trailheads. 2 minutes On the left side of the Lake Angeles trailhead is a roof-covered bulletin board with changing park information. A garbage can is behind the bulletin board. A brown directional sign with white lettering reads: Lake Angeles Trail. Lake Angeles 3.7 miles Klahhane Ridge 6.2 miles. Hurricane Ridge 9.9 miles. Below, another sign reads, No Pets, Weapon Use or Wheeled Devices. On the right side of the trailhead is a tall green and white informational sign with a map of the trail system marked with white lines and the text, You Are Here. The map shows the Lake Angeles Trail and Heather Park Trail branching off in different directions. Above the map, a trail profile diagram illustrates the elevation gain for the Lake Angeles Trail. Below the map, text reads: Lake Angeles Trail. Two trails leave and rejoin each other 6.2 miles from here, then continue on to Hurricane Ridge. Both pass through lower elevation forest for the first several miles, then break into spectacular vistas. Both trails also steepen after the first 2 to 3 miles. Lake Angeles, surrounded by high cliffs on three sides, is reached by the trail on the left. Lake Angeles, 3.3 miles. Klahhane, 6.1 miles. Hurricane Ridge, 9.8 miles. Heather Park, noted for its July wildflowers, is reached by the trail on the right. The halfway Rock lookout point provides a view across the Strait of Juan de Fuca to Vancouver Island. Halfway Rock, 2.2 miles. Heather Park, 4 miles. Klahhane Ridge, 6.2 miles. Hurricane Ridge, 9.9 miles Fire. Because of the large fire in 1898, most of the forest along these trails is second growth. Lake Angeles has been designated a “No Fire” area. On the higher slopes there is thinner soli, less moisture-giving snow, more wind exposure. Trees and plants grow slowly. A brown sign with white lettering for the Heather Park Trail reads: Halfway Rock, 2.2 miles. Heather Park, 4.1 miles. Klahhane Ridge, 6.3 miles. Hurricane Ridge, 10 miles

title: Lake Crescent - East Beach
listingDescription: East Beach is a scenic picnic area on the lake shore, with tables, fire pits, and an accessible outhouse.

images.altText: A glittering lake with green hills on all sides.

bodyText: East Beach is a scenic picnic area on the lake shore, with tables, fire pits, and an accessible outhouse.
audioDescription: Lake Crescent – East Beach. 2 minutes A brown wooden and white sign supported by log posts reads, Welcome to Lake Crescent, Olympic National Park. The Park Service arrowhead logo is attached to the sign. Another sign reads, East Beach Day Use Area. Alcohol and Glass Prohibited. Symbols on the sign indicate picnicking and dogs on leash are permitted, but camping is not. The gravel parking area is bordered on the right by forest, on the left by the lake and beach, and straight ahead by a picnic area with tables. Large boulders on the ground separate the parking lot from the picnic area. At the end of the parking lot on the forest side is a brown, an all gender, single stall, accessible restroom with a vault toilet. Entry is on the left front side of the building. Garbage bins are located to the left of the restroom. On the beach is a boat rental station with canoes lined up along the shoreline. A sign reads, Floatation Vest Required. A chalkboard notes the cost to rent a boat. A wooden and concrete pier, stretching out into the lake, has a railing on each side up until the last 10 feet. A swimming area in the lake is defined by a string of floating, orange buoys. Forested mountains border the lake on all sides.

title: Lake Crescent Lodge
listingDescription: On the south shore of Lake Crescent, about 25 miles (40 km) west of Port Angeles is historic Lake Crescent Lodge. The lodge was built in 1916 and has cabins, motel rooms and rooms in the historic lodge building available for rent. There is also a dining room, lounge and coffee bar, gift shop and boat rentals. In 1937, President Franklin D. Roosevelt journeyed to the Olympic Peninsula and visited Lake Crescent Lodge! He would go on to sign into law the creation of Olympic N

images.altText: A wooden love seat next to a peaceful lake.
images.title: Lake Crescent Lodge beach
images.caption: A peaceful place to rest outside Lake Crescent Lodge.

bodyText:
On the south shore of Lake Crescent, about 25 miles (40 km) west of Port Angeles is historic Lake Crescent Lodge. The lodge was built in 1916 and has cabins, motel rooms and rooms in the historic lodge building available for rent. There is also a dining room, lounge and coffee bar, gift shop and boat rentals. In 1937, President Franklin D. Roosevelt journeyed to the Olympic Peninsula and visited Lake Crescent Lodge! He would go on to sign into law the creation of Olympic National Park in 1938.

For reservations and additional information, visit the Lake Crescent Lodge website.
audioDescription: Lake Crescent Lodge. 3 minutes Single story, white duplex cottages with front porches and rocking chairs line the left side of the asphalt walkway leading to the lodge. A sign reads, Singer Tavern Cottages, Rooms 5 to 21. On the right of the walkway, a green, white and black sign with a drawing of the lodge reads, Welcome to Lake Crescent Lodge. Straight ahead, at the end of the walkway sits a three-story white shingled building with a brown shingled roof, dormer windows and a covered porch with railing on the front and right sides. Tall bushes grow in front of the porch. Pots with flowers sit on the ground on each side of a one-step staircase leading to the raised front porch, where directly ahead, is the double door entry. Hanging above the staircase, a green and black sign reads, Lake Crescent Lodge. Flags adorn the porch beams and bulletin boards with posted notices and flyers, are attached to the building. One flyer reads: A Historic Tradition. In 1915, Avery and Julia Singer built a small hotel at Barnes Point on the shore of Lake Crescent, opening Singer’s Tavern. At the time of its opening, the Tavern consisted of eight Lodge rooms, which are still in use today, and a series of cottages. Julia Singer planted an ornamental garden, together with a small golf course, a vegetable garden and fruit trees. The Singers sold the property in 1927 to the Seattle Trust Company and from there it passed to Walter and Bessie Bovee. In the latter half of the 1930s, members of Congress proposed the establishment of a large national park encompassing the central mountainous region of the Olympic Peninsula, and as a result, the lodge received its most notable guest, Franklin D. Roosevelt, who visited the peninsula in the fall of 1937. Roosevelt arrived at the lodge in the evening of September 30, where he spent the night and continued on to the lake Quinault Lodge the next day. While he was at Singer’s Tavern, Roosevelt discussed the proposed Olympic National Park with Park Service and Forest Service advisors, and with Washington senators. Following his tour of the Peninsula, the President signed authorization for the creation of Olympic National Park in 1938. The lodge remained an inholding through the 1940s, when several new lodges and an addition to the main lodge were built. In 1951, the National Park Service bought the lodge and its property for $95,000. The Mission 66 initiative proposed the lodge’s demolition and replacement with modern facilities. A number of accessory buildings were removed, but the main lodge was spared, though motel-style units were constructed nearby. Several cabins were replaced with newer units of similar character. The Main Lodge, Singer Cottages, Roosevelt Cottages and the main grounds are on the National Register of Historic Places. The lodge serves travelers seasonally from May until January 1. Facing the Lodge, the walkway turns right and leads to a wooden dock with side railings that juts out into the lake. Inside the lodge are restrooms, a gift shop, a restaurant, and a lounge.

title: Lake Crescent Lodge - Marymere Falls Trailhead

At the trailhead, the gravel path gently slopes uphill and enters a dense forest of tall trees, their limbs hanging with moss. Tall green ferns and other understory plants line the trail.

title: Lake Quinault Lodge
listingDescription: The historic lodge walks the line between rustic and luxurious, with lake views, a fireplace, and panoramic lake views in the dining room, but no phones or TVs in most of the guest rooms. Inn style rooms available by reservation. From the Quinault Nation: "The opening ceremonies occurred on August 18, 1926, with Quinault Medicine woman, Sally (James) Freeman providing the Blessing Ceremony; she was the close friend of Stella McNeil, whose husband was a co-owner of the Lodge.

images.altText: A large wooden lodge building with a sprawling lawn.
images.title: Lake Quinault Lodge
images.caption: Lake Quinault Lodge

bodyText:
The historic lodge walks the line between rustic and luxurious, with lake views, a fireplace, and panoramic lake views in the dining room, but no phones or TVs in most of the guest rooms. Inn style rooms available by reservation.

From the Quinault Nation:
"The opening ceremonies occurred on August 18, 1926, with Quinault Medicine woman, Sally (James) Freeman providing the Blessing Ceremony; she was the close friend of Stella McNeil, whose husband was a co-owner of the Lodge. The interior of the Lodge was decorated with Native motif on the ceiling beams. Later, Sally provided basketweaving demonstrations while her family entertained the visiting tourists with singing, dancing and drumming. Additionally, long intricate canoes carved by Chief Howeattle provided exciting races on the lakefront of the Lodge.

"During the late 1920s, huge barbecues were held in the summer on the beach in front of the lodge. The crowds were entertained by foot races, water sports and square dancing on Fred Halbert's dance pavilion (R.H. Jones, A History of Lake Quinault Lodge, 1997). Many of these same activities persist today. Harvest Moon, Quinault Ambassador and master basketweaver is a frequent guest at the Quinault Lodge. Collaborative Interpretive signs provide tribal heritage and artistic works, with geologic, scientific and historical perspectives of the area on the Lakefront shoreline trail. Rented kayaks rather than tribal canoes ply the waters of Lake Quinault."
audioDescription: Lake Quinault Lodge. 1 minute In the garden area in front of the Lodge, a brown rectangular wooden sign hangs from green posts. White text reads, Lake Quinault Lodge. A design shows a person painted red holding an extended white bow and pointing it at a black bear. The lodge is V-shaped with a taller central section and two lower roofed side wings. A cupola sits in the center of the tall, pitched roof over the central section. The building is clad in dark shingles and its many windows are trimmed in white. The entry door is in the center of the middle section. Inside is a restaurant. A back patio has tables and seating that face the lake.

title: Living Forest Trailhead
listingDescription: This short 0.4 mile (0.64 km) loop trail starts beside the historic Beaumont cabin, behind the Olympic National Park Visitor Center in Port Angeles. May be wheelchair accessible with assistance.

images.altText: An adult and two children walk a forest trail surrounded by cedar trees and tall ferns
images.title: Living Forest Trail
images.caption: The Living Forest Trail

bodyText:
This short 0.4 mile (0.64 km) loop trail starts beside the historic Beaumont cabin, behind the Olympic National Park Visitor Center in Port Angeles.

 

Full Accessibility Description

Length: .32 miles
Surface Type: Compacted gravel
Typical Trail Width: 3-4 feet
Typical Running Slope: 6% or less, with sections less than 20 feet up to 12%
Typical Cross Slope: Less than 1%
Elevation Gain/ Loss: 72 feet
Accessible Parking: Van-accessible parking in parking area.
Description: This trail begins immediately behind the Olympic National Park Visitor Center in Port Angeles. There is a wheelchair available to check out at the visitor center. The first 420 feet of the trail consists of 3 switchbacks that are at a gentle grade but contain a few slightly steeper sections where trees pinch the trail (trail width is at least 3 feet at each location).

Beyond the switchback section, trail branches to the left and right to create the main loop of the trail. Either direction continues uphill. Travelling to the left provides a gradual grade through open forest. To the right, the forest is denser with a few sections that are steep (up to 12%) for 10-20 feet where the trail goes next to or between trees. At 1,260 feet when travelling to the right, or at 220 feet when traveling to the left, a 240-foot spur trail leads to an exposed root wad of a fallen tree before returning to the main loop.
audioDescription: Living Forest Trailhead. 30 seconds A sign at the head of the trail reads: Living Forest Trail. Accessible with assistance. Bicycles Prohibited. Where the flat, gravel trail begins, small rocks line the left edge. Approximately 15 feet from the trailhead, a wooden handrail begins on the right. The trail passes through an area of low growing ferns before entering the forest.

title: Log Cabin Resort - Boat Rental
listingDescription: Explore Lake Crescent by boat, kayak, or paddleboard. Pay for boat rental inside the main lodge building, then head to the rental building.

images.altText: Two kayaks on a serene lake.
images.caption: Kayakers enjoy Lake Crescent near Log Cabin Resort. Photo by Grant Longenbaugh.

bodyText: Explore Lake Crescent by boat, kayak, or paddleboard. Pay for boat rental inside the main lodge building, then head to the rental building.
audioDescription: Boat Rental. 1 minute A brown, shingled building with green trim houses the boat rental office. A white sign with black text attached to the door reads, Restricted Area, Authorized Personnel Only. To the left of the door a green sign attached to the building reads, Boat Rental. Row. Canoe. Peddle. P.F.D.s included. To the right of the door under a window, another green sign reads, Water activities at your own risk. At the water’s edge, a sign reads, Boat Rental. Pay launch fee at lodge. No Swimming. Beyond the sign, a flat, downward slanting metal bridge with handrails extends out to a low floating pier where rental boats are secured on either side. A second bridge and pier are located off to the right of the boat rental area. The lake is surrounded by green forested mountains.

title: Log Cabin Resort - Campground
listingDescription: For RV and tent site camping, visit https://www.olympicnationalparks.com/rv-camping/log-cabin-rv-campground/

images.altText: A sign that reads "Log Cabin Campground"
images.title: Log Cabin Campground Sign
images.caption: The entrance to the campground at Log Cabin Resort

bodyText: For RV and tent site camping, visit the resort website.
audioDescription: Log Cabin Resort Campground. 45 seconds A brown and white wooden sign at the entrance to the campground reads, Log Cabin Campground. On either side of the main road are numbered campsites with picnic tables and fire grates. Some sites include electrical and water hook ups for recreational vehicles, while some are designated for bike and tent camping. Rental cabins are also available at the campground. Each is a brown, single level, square, log cabin, with green and red trim, windows, and a brown metal A-framed roof. Two front steps with hand railings lead up to a porch and the front door. Picnic tables and fire grates are in front of the cabins.

title: Log Cabin Resort - Main Lodge
listingDescription: Open in summer, the Log Cabin Resort offers lodging, camping, boat rentals, a restaurant, and a small general store/snack bar. Boat Rental registration is located inside the main lodge. For accommodations visit https://www.olympicnationalparks.com/lodging/log-cabin-resort/

images.altText: A lakeside lodge viewed from uphill.
images.title: Log Cabin Resort main lodge 01
images.caption: The lodge at Log Cabin Resort.

bodyText: Open in summer, the Log Cabin Resort offers lodging, camping, boat rentals, a restaurant, and a small general store/snack bar. Boat Rental registration is located inside the main lodge. For accommodations visit the resort website.
audioDescription: Log Cabin Lodge. 30 seconds The lodge is a brown wooden building with dark green trim. A concrete walkway extends from the parking lot to the wood and glass double front doors. The entrance area is covered by an upward slanted roof supported on each side by a tall, green, log post. To the right of the entrance is a brown and white wooden sign that reads, Log Cabin Lodge. A sign on the front of the building reads, Established 1895. Inside the Lodge is a General Store where the office and registration are located, a seating area with cushioned chairs and sofas, the front desk, and a restaurant.

title: Log Cabin Resort Entrance

images.altText: A sign with the National Park Service arrowhead logo and the words "Log Cabin Resort"

bodyText: Open seasonally.
audioDescription: Log Cabin Resort Entrance. 30 seconds A brown and white wooden sign supported by log posts of varying heights reads, Log Cabin Resort. The National Park Service Arrowhead logo is attached to the sign. Other signs along the roadway leading into the resort area use arrows to direct visitors to the Lodge and Campground, Parking for Camper Cabins, Day Use Parking, Boat Launch, RV Turn Around, Campground Chalets and Camper Cabins. A text statement reads, Overnight guests please check in at the lodge to the left. The road ends at a parking lot for the Lodge and guest cabins.

title: Lower Queets Park Entrance

images.altText: A brown wooden sign reads "Entering Olympic National Park" and features an arrowhead logo
images.title: Lower Queets Entrance Sign
images.caption: Lower Queets Park Entrance Sign

bodyText: Park Entrance Sign
audioDescription: Lower Queets Park Entrance. 1 minute On the side of the gravel road is a large brown wooden sign with white text that reads, Entering Olympic National Park. National Park Service. United States Department of the Interior. To the left of the text is the National Park Service arrowhead logo atop a large white triangular shaped base. The logo itself is shaped like an arrowhead with a scalloped edge, pointed at the bottom, with sides that widen out toward the top, before curving slightly inward, then flaring out to create a rounded top. The arrowhead is brown with etched words and images. On the right side are the words, National Park Service, in white letters. To the left, in green, a tall tree towers above smaller trees and the ground below and a section of lake in white. Behind the tree, a white outline of snowcapped mountains. Below the trees, text in white reads, Department of the Interior, and below this, an outline of a bison in profile facing left with a large head and shoulders and smaller hind area. Beyond the entrance sign, a white sign with black text reads, Road closed 7 miles ahead. Near this sign is a gate that swivels outward to close off the road. Tall green pine trees line each side of the road.

title: Madison Falls

images.altText: A waterfall cascades into a small pool.
images.caption: Madison Falls. Photo by J. Burger/NPS.

bodyText: Madison Falls
audioDescription: Madison Falls. 1 minute The smooth, wheelchair accessible trail leads to an area that overlooks the falls. Here, there is a four-foot-tall fence on the left side of the trail and a bench for seating. The water of Madison Falls cascades down a steep, rocky wall covered with bright green moss, all framed by the surrounding lush, green forest. At the bottom, the long white ribbon of water ends in a clear, deep pool which is part of the creek that flows in front of the viewing area. The creek is strewn with rocks, gravel and parts of downed tree trunks and branches.

title: Madison Falls Trailhead
listingDescription: As easy as a walk around the corner, this short, wheelchair-accessible trail leads to the falls. The open field nearby is the site of the late 19th century Sweet family homestead, and is now used in summer for the park's horses and mules to pasture. The mules help keep backcountry trails in shape by helping to carry supplies for the trail crew into the wilderness, where motorized vehicles are not permitted. As cute as they are, please do not feed or touch the animals.

images.altText: A river and trees along the bank with bright green new leaves.
images.caption: The Elwha River near Madison Falls trailhead. Photo by E. Goode/NPS.

bodyText: As easy as a walk around the corner, this short, wheelchair-accessible trail leads to the falls. The open field nearby is the site of the late 19th century Sweet family homestead, and is now used in summer for the park's horses and mules to pasture. The mules help keep backcountry trails in shape by helping to carry supplies for the trail crew into the wilderness, where motorized vehicles are not permitted. As cute as they are, please do not feed or touch the animals.
audioDescription: Madison Falls Trailhead. 20 seconds A square brown and white sign at the trailhead has an upward pointing arrow and the text, Madison Falls. The trail is paved and flat. On the left side of the trail beyond the sign is a single stall restroom.

title: Makah Cultural Institute and Research Center
listingDescription: The Makah Museum interprets and houses 300-500 year old artifacts recovered from the Ozette Archaeological Site, a coastal village covered and preserved by a mudslide which has been called the North American Pompeii. There are also other historic and replica pieces and photographs related to the Makah Tribe on display year-round. For more information on Makah culture and history, please contact the staff at 360-645-2711.

images.altText: Two totem poles hold a sign that reads Welcome to the Makah Cultural and Research Center
images.title: Makah Museum
images.caption: Makah Cultural and Research Center, Museum of the Makah Nation

bodyText:
Currently closed to the public.

The Makah Museum interprets and houses 300-500 year old artifacts recovered from the Ozette Archaeological Site, a coastal village covered and preserved by a mudslide which has been called the North American Pompeii. There are also other historic and replica pieces and photographs related to the Makah Tribe on display year-round. For more information on Makah culture and history, please contact the staff at 360-645-2711 or visit the website.
audioDescription: Makah Cultural Institute and Research Center. 2 minutes At the entrance road to the center is a brown wooden sign attached between two log posts with white text that reads, Welcome to the Makah Cultural and Research Center. Museum of the Makah Indian Nation. The posts are decorated with a black, white, red, and green Makah design. On the left side of the road in a grass field stand two tall, carved wooden figures, one female, one male. The female wears a cone shaped white hat with black fishing designs. Her knee length white dress is edged in red, and its short sleeves and hem are fringed. The bottom half of the dress has a red and black animal design. She is barefoot. The male figure wears a similar hat, but with a black knob on top. He wears a knee length skirt with a red and black animal design. On his bare chest is a black four-pointed star and half-moon. He is barefoot. The Center is further up the road on the right side of the parking lot. On the double wooden entrance door is a circular black design of two fish. To the left of the door on a white wall is a black design of a face. Inside is a gift shop and information desk. There is a fee to visit.

title: Maple Glade Rain Forest Trailhead
listingDescription: From the Quinault Rain Forest Ranger Station, enjoy this idyllic half-mile (0.8 km) loop through the big-leaf maples of the Quinault Rain Forest. For a longer walk, continue to the historic Kestner Homestead.

images.altText: A wooden bridge becomes a trail through the forest
images.title: Maple Glade Trail
images.caption: A trail on the Maple Glade trail

bodyText:
From the Quinault Rain Forest Ranger Station, enjoy this idyllic half-mile (0.8 km) loop through the big-leaf maples of the Quinault Rain Forest. For a longer walk, continue to the historic Kestner Homestead.

 

 

Full Accessibility Description

Length: 2,565 feet, .49 miles
Surface Type: Compacted gravel
Typical Trail Width: 3-5 feet
Typical Running Slope: Less than 5% (maximum slope 7%)
Typical Cross Slope: Less than 1% (the first bridge has a cross slope of 4% for the last 15 feet)
Description: The trail starts at the west end of the ranger station parking area immediately beginning with a 60-foot ramp leading to a 50-foot bridge and then down a 30-foot ramp. The second ramp has a 10-foot section with 7% grade that is the steepest part of the trail. The bridge has settled on the west end and has a cross slope of 4% for the last 15 feet. Trail brochures for the Maple Glade Trail and the Kestner Homestead Trail are available at the bottom of the 30-foot ramp. The Maple Glade brochure describes forest elements at 13 marked points along the trail. 200 feet farther down the trail, proceed right at the junction to follow the brochure in numerical order.

The Quinault Rain Forest receives over 12 feet of rain annually. Portions of the trail may be flooded between the months of October and May, but the summer months are typically dry, and so is the trail. The rain contributes to escalated vegetation growth, so each side of the trail typically has low vegetation growth in the gravel surface, but it is still firm. Despite the gentle grade of the trail, the weather conditions make it difficult to maintain in accessible condition, so wheelchair users should proceed with caution.

Continuing from the junction, the trail proceeds for 2,370 feet through a quiet forest of mossy bigleaf maple trees, braided with stream channels, before looping back to the junction. The grade is gentle for the entirety of the loop and crosses numerous short wooden bridges. There are multiple locations along the trail where bridge ends, tree roots, and trail construction features rise 2 inches above the trail tread. At 425 feet, there is a cut through a downed tree with a 4-inch step. At 1,530 feet, continue to the left at the Kestner Homestead Trail junction to complete the loop. There is a trailside bench at 1,685 feet. The roughest stretch of trail is from 2,010 to 2,090 feet where there are two 8-foot sections of numerous crisscrossed exposed tree roots, followed by a 45-foot section where flooded has caused a 10-inch deep, 18-inch wide rut down the middle of the trail. When back at the first junction, go right to return to the parking lot.
audioDescription: Maple Glade Rainforest Trailhead. 90 seconds At the far-left end of the parking lot is the trailhead. A brown sign with white text reads, Maple Glade Rain Forest Trail. The parking lot’s concrete sidewalk ends here and becomes gravel with a railing on both sides. After the first curve to the right there’s a wooden bridge across a creek. Further along is a second wooden bridge. The trail become gravel again for about 20 feet and then the hand railings end. Here on the left is a brown box on a post with a sign on the hinged lid that reads, Trail Brochures. Welcome. We hope you enjoy exploring Olympic National Park. Donations for these trail brochures are accepted at park visitor centers. Thank you for your support. The sign ends with this quote by John Muir: In every walk with Nature one receives far more than he seeks. Filling the right side of the sign is a green and white illustration showing a high mountain peak with a forest and lake below. The trail continues into the forest.

title: Maple Grove off the Hall of Mosses Trail

images.altText: A grove of huge, moss-laden maple trees towers over a forest floor thick with ferns.
images.title: Maple Grove in the Hoh Rain Forest
images.caption: Maple Grove

bodyText: A short path branches from the Hall of Mosses loop to showcase this grove of massive big leaf maple trees.
audioDescription: Maple Grove. 30 seconds The trail widens and ends in a circular flat dirt area surrounded by a split rail fence. Beyond the fence in a carpet of green ferns, rise a grove of large, big leaf maple trees, their trunks covered in thick, lush green moss and their branches draped in fringed curtains of hanging moss.

title: Maritime Washington National Heritage Area
listingDescription: The Maritime Washington National Heritage Area tells a nationally important story of maritime heritage, from Native American canoe cultures to industrial working waterfronts, that shaped western Washington and contributes today to our development as a nation.

images.altText: Purple sunrise over a harbor
images.title: Maritime Washington NHA - Gig Harbor
images.caption: Morning breaks over peaceful Gig Harbor

relatedParks.fullName: Klondike Gold Rush - Seattle Unit National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Klondike Gold Rush - Seattle Unit

relatedParks.fullName: San Juan Island National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: San Juan Island

bodyText:
The Maritime Washington National Heritage Area (designated in 2019) encompasses 3,000 miles of western Washington’s saltwater coastline from Grays Harbor County to the Canadian border, 18 federally recognized tribes, 13 counties, 32 incorporated cities, and 30 port districts, as well as innumerable harbors, inlets, peninsulas, island shores, and parks—all connected by the nation’s largest ferry system. The Washington Trust for Historic Preservation, a state-wide non-profit dedicated to preserving the state’s historic resources, is the NHA’s Coordinating Entity. 

Communities here were connected to the rest of the world by boat long before roads and railroads were built. The first peoples created complex cultures around canoe journeys and salmon cycles. Then came Spanish, English, Russian and American explorers in search of territory and shipping lanes. As the country developed, the region’s ports began to bolster trade of vast natural resources, and naval installations came to guard the continent. 

Washington’s coastline is rich with historic buildings and vessels, museums, and archival collections, and the maritime industry remains a foundation of the region’s economy today. Shipyards, container ports, cruise ships, tugs, and marinas full of small and large pleasure craft are as much a part of this NHA’s inheritance as historic ships or lighthouses.   

To read the Maritime Washington National Heritage Area management plan, click here. 

The vast diversity of this living landscape can be divided by geographic regions:  

Olympic Peninsula 

The Olympic Peninsula is surrounded by the Pacific Ocean, the Strait of Juan de Fuca, and Puget Sound’s Hood Canal. The Olympic Mountains rise prominently in the interior. Historic ports, coastal communities, and traditional tribal lands rim this boxy landmass. Home to Olympic National Park, the peninsula features the longest stretch of publicly-owned and undeveloped shoreline on the Pacific Coast, and closely resembles the shoreline inhabited by the tribes before Europeans arrived. Olympic National Park is also a UNESCO World Heritage Site, designated for its ecosystem diversity, while the Olympic Coast National Marine Sanctuary lies offshore, distinguished for its educational opportunities.  

Puget Sound 

A complex inlet of the Pacific Ocean and the third-largest estuary in the United States, Puget Sound comprises many waterways, basins, and bays, including Seattle’s brackish Lake Union. For millennia, the sound connected the Northwest people to the sea – for travel, trade, sustenance, protection, and recreation. Today, Puget Sound is home to maritime industries, military bases, small coastal communities, the cities of Seattle, Tacoma, Everett, and the state capital Olympia. The Kitsap Peninsula and enchanting islands lie in the interior of Puget Sound, with the Hood Canal between them and the Olympic Peninsula.    

Northern Coast 

Along the western edge of Skagit and Whatcom Counties lies Washington’s northern coastline, a series of protected bays stretching north to the Strait of Georgia, which separates Vancouver Island from mainland Canada. The traditional aquaculture, fishing, and sea trade economies remain important in this region. Continuing a centuries-old tradition, northern coastal cities like Bellingham still provide jumping-off points for journeys to Alaska through the Inside Passage.  

Salish Sea Islands 

Three Northwest water bodies – the Strait of Juan de Fuca, Puget Sound, and Canada’s Strait of Georgia - are together called the Salish Sea. The over 400 islands that lie in these waters are the ancient homelands of native tribes and habitat for some of the region’s most diverse marine wildlife. This varied island environment– including Whidbey Island, one of the largest islands in the contiguous United States, and the San Juan archipelago— contains some of the most remote and rugged places in this region, as well as active ports and popular vacation destinations.
managedByOrg: The Washington Trust for Historic Preservation

title: Marymere Falls

images.altText: A waterfall.
images.caption: Marymere Falls. Photo by C. Bubar/NPS.

bodyText: Viewing platform for Marymere Falls
audioDescription: Marymere Falls. 30 seconds Pouring over the lip of a 90-foot-high cliff, a white veil of water cascades down a steep rock face covered by a carpet of moss in various shades of green from bright to dark. Ferns and other plants grow on the rocky face away from the rush of falling water, and the dense forest frames the scene. At the base of the falls, the water splashes into a deep pool, joining Barnes Creek. In and around the creek are jumbled remnants of fallen trees.

title: Marymere Falls Trailhead
listingDescription: The most popular day hike at Lake Crescent is the 0.9 mile (1.4 km) one way trail to Marymere Falls. This trail goes through old growth forest to a 90-foot (27 meter) waterfall. The trail starts from the Storm King Ranger Station but can also be accessed from Lake Crescent Lodge.

images.altText: A slender waterfall cascades between moss and stone into a small pool.
images.caption: Marymere Falls. Photo by C. Bubar/NPS.

bodyText: The most popular day hike at Lake Crescent is the 0.9 mile (1.4 km) one way trail to Marymere Falls. This trail goes through old growth forest to a 90-foot (27 meter) waterfall. The trail starts from the Storm King Ranger Station but can also be accessed from Lake Crescent Lodge.
audioDescription: Marymere Falls Nature Trailhead. 30 seconds The flat, gravel trail begins in an open area then quickly enters the forest. A three-foot tall brown and white sign on the left side of the trail reads, Marymere Falls Nature Trail. One and a half miles round trip. No pets, weapons, or vehicles.

title: Meadow Loop Trailhead
listingDescription: An easy, paved, 0.25 mile (0.4 km) trail which crosses open meadows with views of the Olympics. While exploring the ridge please keep your distance from wildlife and stay on paved paths or snow to avoid damaging fragile meadows.

images.altText: A paved trail through a mountain meadow
images.title: Meadow at Hurricane Ridge
images.caption: The Meadow Loop Trail

bodyText:
An easy, paved, 0.25 mile (0.4 km) trail which crosses open meadows with views of the Olympics. While exploring the ridge please keep your distance from wildlife and stay on paved paths or snow to avoid damaging fragile meadows.
 

Full Accessibility Description

Big Meadow and Cirque Rim Trails

Length: Center of parking to overlook: 400 feet. Cirque Rim Trail (overlook to east end of Big Meadow Trail): 1,670 feet. Big Meadow Trail: 900 feet
Surface Type: Asphalt pavement
Typical Trail Width: Center access and Big Meadow 8-foot width. Cirque Rim Trail 4-foot width
Typical Running Slope: Center of parking to overlook: 12-13% for 190 feet reducing to 6-7%. Cirque Rim Trail: 12-20%. Big Meadow Trail: Less than 5%, except for 9% for last 100 feet to east intersection
Typical Cross Slope: Less than 1%
Elevation Gain/Loss: Less than 50 feet
Accessible Parking: Van-accessible parking immediately across from the trailhead
Description: There are three trail access points on the north side of the Hurricane Ridge Visitor Center parking area. The trail with the least grade and the widest tread begins from the center of the parking area. The trail is steep for the first 190 feet with the grade tapering off for the remaining 210 feet to an overlook with views of the Strait of Juan de Fuca, Vancouver Island and the San Juan Islands on a clear day.

Starting shortly before the overlook, the Big Meadow Trail runs east for 900 feet across the meadow to an intersection with the Cirque Rim Trail and the High Ridge Trail. The Big Meadow Trail grade remains under 5% for 800 feet and then increases to 9% downhill where it reaches the intersection of the Cirque Rim Trail and the High Ridge Trail. For the least strenuous option, consider turning around at the Growing Gradually interpretive exhibit and returning to the parking lot or overlook via the same route.

The Cirque Rim Trail departs to the east from the overlook. The 4-foot-wide path follows the rolling contour of the northern slope at grades of 12-20% for 1,670 feet before meeting up with the intersection of the east end of the Big Meadow Trail and part of the High Ridge Trail. From here, the trail continues down a hill for 140 feet to reach the east end of the parking lot. To return to the center of the parking area via the Big Meadow Trail, follow the trail as it climbs a gradual 9% grade for 100 feet and then levels out to less than a 5% grade over the remaining 800 feet of trail leading downhill to the parking area.
audioDescription: Meadow Loop Trailhead. 1 minute At this trailhead is a five-foot-tall upright wooden frame with two informational panels. The panel on the left shows an illustration of a person feeding a deer. Text reads: Keep Wildlife Wild. Human food spoils wild animals. They lose their desire for natural foods by becoming beggars – easy prey for car wheels and predators. No matter how appealing, all park animals are potentially dangerous. They may bite or scratch and can spread disease. Please don’t feed the animals. The panel on the right shows an illustration of a hiking boot with deeps treads about to step on grass, wildflowers, a hidden mouse nest, and an adult mouse. Text reads: Meadow Damage. Your feet are a threat to meadows. Without realizing, people crush fragile plants and flatten nests and small creatures hidden in the grass. Help preserve the meadows. Please stay on maintained trails. Shortcuts leave lasting scars.

title: Merriman Falls

images.altText: A rushing waterfall viewed through foliage
images.title: Merriman Falls
images.caption: Merriman Falls

bodyText: Located outside of the national park, this scenic waterfall is just off the road.
audioDescription: Merriman Falls. 1 minute Guardrails line each side of the roadway where it crosses a stream. Parking pull-offs are located on both sides of the road at the ends of each guardrail. The falls are located on the upslope side of the road. Access to the falls is from dirt trails located at each end of the guardrail. Pouring over the lip of a high cliff, a white veil of water cascades down a steep rock face covered by a carpet of moss in various shades of green from bright to dark. Ferns and other plants grow on the rocky face away from the rush of falling water. The falls are framed by the surrounding forest of towering green pine trees with brown trunks covered in green moss, an understory of lush, green ferns, shrubs, and other low growing plants. At the base of the falls, the water splashes into the creek and follows its downward path over and around moss and fern covered rocks.

title: Mink Lake / Lovers Lane Trailhead
listingDescription: This route passes through old growth forest and subalpine meadows, passing Mink Lake and Deer Lake if one chooses to complete the full 11 mile/17.7 km loop. Make sure to carry 10 essentials and for trail conditions or to plan a backpacking trip, contact the Wilderness Information Center https://www.nps.gov/olym/planyourvisit/wic.htm

images.altText: A path through green forest. A small sign beside the trail reads "Wilderness camping permits and bear canisters required for all overnight trips - obtain at ranger station."
images.caption: Photo by D. Sullivan/NPS.

bodyText: This route passes through old growth forest and subalpine meadows, passing Mink Lake and Deer Lake if one chooses to complete the full 11 mile/17.7 km loop. Make sure to carry 10 essentials and for trail conditions or to plan a backpacking trip, contact the Wilderness Information Center
audioDescription: Mink Lake and Lovers Lane Trailhead. 2 minutes At the end of the parking area, are two brown metal bins, one for recycling, the other for garbage. To the left is a tall, wooden, roof covered bulletin board with park information. One posted sign states pets are not allowed on trails while another provides a warning that bears frequent the area, so keep a clean camp 24 hours a day. A gated service road branches off the parking area and continues through the forest. On the left side of the road before the gate is the trailhead. A brown wooden sign with white text and an upward pointing arrow, reads: Mink Lake. Lover’s Lane. No pets, weapons, or vehicles. Ferns, and other plants, line both sides of the trail as it enters a forest of tall moss-covered pine trees. After the first leftward curve in the trail, another brown and white sign on the right, reads: Wilderness camping. Permits and bear cannisters required for all overnight trips. Obtain at ranger station. Further up trail, the trail splits. Text on a wooden sign reads, Mink Lake, two and a half miles. An arrow points to the right. Text below reads, Lover’s Lane, Sol Duc Falls, three miles. An arrow points to the left. Be advised, the trails have uneven, rough surfaces with tripping hazards of rocks and tree roots. In places, large rocks form steps.

title: Moments in Time Trailhead
listingDescription: This self-guided Nature Trail begins at Lake Crescent Lodge and is a flat 0.6 mile (1km) loop through lakeside forest. Numerous trail-side signs tell the story of Lake Crescent's natural and cultural history.

images.altText: A bench in the forest faces a lake.

bodyText: This self-guided Nature Trail begins at Lake Crescent Lodge and is a flat 0.6 mile (1km) loop through lakeside forest. Numerous trail-side signs tell the story of Lake Crescent's natural and cultural history.
audioDescription: Moments in Time Trailhead. 2 minutes A brown and white wooden sign at the trailhead lists points of interest reached from the trail. Right and left pointing arrows note the direction for the Moments in Time Trail, a left pointing arrow gives the direction for Storm King Ranger Station and Marymere Falls, and an arrow for Lake Crescent Lodge points right. The trail has a flat gravel surface and winds its way through low growing ferns and tall trees. Along the trail is a three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel titled, Moments in Time Trail. The color image background on the panel is a lake with still water flanked on the right by a hill with tall dark pine trees and on the left and rear by the slope of a tall mountain. Text reads: Moments in Time Trail. Shaped by time and water, Barnes Point punctuates the south shore of glacially carved Lake Crescent. This quiet delta, with its mantle of old-growth forest, continues to grow and change. For thousands of years, American Indians lived and traded here. Later, settlers homesteaded this area and entrepreneurs developed hotels and lodges. Today, Lake Crescent is protected in Olympic National Park for all to enjoy. As you walk this trail, you follow the footsteps of many who shaped this landscape. This accessible one-half mile loop has several entrances and exits. A trail map is provided below and at four other entry points. Please return it after use. These interpretive exhibits were provided by the Rob Reed and Lena Sharpe Memorial Foundation.

title: Mora Amphitheater

images.altText: Black and white symbol for amphitheater with the figure of a person at the front and bench seating facing them.

bodyText: Amphitheater at Mora Campground
audioDescription: Amphitheater – Mora. 1 minute The trail to the amphitheater is flat and travels through a forest of tall trees and mid to low height understory plants. The trail ends in a wide-open area at the rear right side of the amphitheater. On a downward slope are seven rows of wooden benches with a center aisle, then three rows of curved benches with no aisle. At the bottom of the slope facing the benches, a grey wooden building with a flat blue roof and a vertical row of enclosed speakers on the left and right, sits atop a two-foot-high concrete stage. The center of the building is recessed toward the back with doors that open to reveal a projection screen. The projection booth is in the back of the amphitheater at the top of the slope. To the right of the stage on the ground, is a round, stone edged fire ring and a semicircular bench.

title: Mora Area Park Entrance Sign

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Park with care in the designated parking areas if you want to take photos with this park entrance sign.
audioDescription: Mora Entrance Sign. 2 minutes Suspended from a horizontal log, supported on either end by vertical logs, is a large dark brown sign with white text that reads, Olympic National Park. Attached to the vertical log on the right is the National Park Service arrowhead logo atop a larger white arrowhead shaped base. The logo itself is shaped like an arrowhead with a scalloped edge, pointed at the bottom, with sides that widen out toward the top, before curving slightly inward, then flaring out to create a rounded top. The arrowhead is brown with etched words and images. On the right side are the words, National Park Service, in white letters. To the left, in green, a tall tree towers above smaller trees and the ground below and a section of lake in white. Behind the tree, a white outline of snowcapped mountains. Below the trees, text in white reads, Department of the Interior, and below this, is a green outline of a bison in profile facing left with a large head and shoulders and smaller hind area. The sign’s log support structure sits atop a stone platform, with stones stacked about six layers high on the right then one layer under the sign. The gravel and grass area in front of the platform is flat. To the left and across the road is the trailhead for the Slough Trail.

title: Mora Campground RV Dump Station

images.altText: A black and white symbol of an RV dumping waste.

bodyText: RV Dump Station for the Mora Campground
audioDescription: RV Dump Station. 30 seconds Along the edge of the parking lot is a brown and white metal sign that reads, RV Septic Dump Station. $10 per use. $5 with interagency senior or access pass. Not included in camping fee. To the right of the sign is a tall thin metal cannister on a concrete base for depositing the fee. To the right of the cannister is a covered box on a post with payment envelopes.

title: Mora Ranger Station
listingDescription: Open intermittently in summer as staffing levels permit, with information and bear canisters. Self-register wilderness camping permits available year-round. For more information on Wilderness Information Center locations and hours go to https://www.nps.gov/olym/planyourvisit/wic.htm. Nearest accessible restrooms at Rialto Beach or the nearby Mora campground.

images.altText: A one-story beige building with a sign that says "Mora Ranger Station."
images.caption: The Mora Ranger Station. Photo by D. Archeluta/NPS.

bodyText: Open intermittently in summer as staffing levels permit, with information and bear canisters. Self-register wilderness camping permits available year-round. Click here for more information on Wilderness Information Center locations. Nearest accessible restrooms at Rialto Beach or the nearby Mora campground.
audioDescription: Mora Ranger Station. 1 minutes A wooden brown sign at the entrance to the ranger station parking lot has white text that reads: Mora Ranger Station. Olympic National Park. Elevation 32 feet. The National Park Service arrowhead logo is attached to the left side of the sign. Beyond the sign on the right are parking spaces. A sidewalk in front of the parking spaces leads to the far-left end of the lot where the ranger station is located. Midway along the sidewalk is a roof covered bulletin board with changing park information. The ranger station is a light green one-story building with a metal roof and windows on each side. The entrance is in the front right corner of the building. A water fountain is located near the entrance. Park information is posted on the outside wall of the building on the right near the entrance.

title: Mora Restrooms and Campground Registration - Loop C

images.altText: Black and white symbol for restroom with male and female figures separated by a wall.

bodyText: Campground registration and restrooms for Loop C, Mora Campground
audioDescription: Mora Campground Registration Loop C. 2 minutes Along the loop road is a white, rectangular restroom building with a blue metal roof. The surface around the building is concrete. The women’s room is on the left short side of the building, and the men’s room is on right short side of the building. Be advised. Short wooden posts stick out of the ground in grassy areas in front of the restroom. Outside the men’s room door is a roof covered bulletin board kiosk. In the center is a self-pay camping registration board, a vertical box with 20 square sections in four horizontal rows. Each square is numbered and corresponds to an individual campsite. Each row is covered by a hard, clear plastic strip with slots for dropping registration payment receipts into individual squares. To the left of the registration board is a brown box with a lid holding campground registration envelopes. A 3-foot-tall cannister for depositing payment envelopes stands in front of and to the left of the kiosk. It has a slot at the top for slipping in the envelope. Notices posted on the bulletin board include campground registration instructions, campground regulations, a site map of the campground, pet regulations, rules about campfire wood, nearest services, a notice to contact a park ranger or dial 911 in an emergency, and a map of the Mora area. Across from the kiosk is a 3-foot-tall stone water station. It’s two spigots face the kiosk. A sign on top reads, no dishwashing. To the left of the kiosk an asphalt path leads into the forest of tall pine trees. A recycle bin and garbage dumpster are located along the roadway to the left of the restroom building.

title: Mora Restrooms and Campground Registration - Loop D

images.altText: Black and white symbol for restroom with male and female figures separated by a wall.

bodyText: Campground registration and restrooms for Mora Campground, Loop D
audioDescription: Mora Campground Registration Loop D. 1 minute Here, in the campground is a roof-covered bulletin board with information about the campground and park. Attached in the center is the campground registration board, a framed box divided into rows of individual square sections. Each square is numbered and corresponds to a campsite. Each row is covered by a hard, clear plastic strip with a slot for dropping one of two registration payment receipts into an individual square. To the left of the board is a brown and blue box holding campground registration envelopes. Standing to the left is a 3-foot-tall cannister for depositing the envelope with payment. On the face of the cannister, at the top, is a slot for slipping in the envelope. To the right of the bulletin board is a restroom building with entrance doors on each side. The women’s room is on the left and the men’s room is on the right.

title: Morse Creek Overlook

images.altText: A mountain view from an overlook.
images.caption: Photo by E. Goode/NPS.

bodyText: Pause to enjoy the view, and learn from an interpretive wayside about Ancient Lake Morse.
audioDescription: Ancient Lake Morse Wayside / Overlook. 2 minutes This three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel stands in front of a three-foot-high stone wall overlooking a gorge carved into a mountain landscape. Text at the top of the panel reads: Ancient Lake Morse. Thousands of years ago, a great ice sheet from Canada flowed south through the Puget Sound and west through the Strait of Juan de Fuca. The ice sheet abutted alpine glaciers flowing from the Olympic Mountains. As warming occurred, meltwater from mountain glaciers was dammed by the ice sheet, forming ancient Lake Morse. Continued warming caused the ice sheet to withdraw, draining the lake. Morse Creek now parallels the road. In ancient times it flowed over a ridge of soft sediments connecting Blue and Round Mountains. When glaciers dammed the creek, it was diverted to a new path between Round Mountain and the present road, cutting through hard lava rocks. The resulting gorge is visible as you drive down the road or from the short trail at the Tunnels parking area. Below the text are two side-by-side images that compare the ancient landscape to present time. On the left, a color drawing depicts a past landscape. In the foreground, a green hill with scattered tall, dark pine trees, slopes into the expansive blue waters of Ancient Lake Morse. The lake extends into the distance cutting between the peaks of Round Mountain on the left and Blue Mountain on the right. The image on the right is a black and white photograph of the present-day landscape. Where the lake once existed is now a deep winding gorge filled with dense pine forests. Without the lake, the full height of Round Mountain and Blue Mountain is exposed.

title: Mouth of the Elwha Beach

images.altText: A surfer carries a surfboard toward the beach under dramatic, cloudy skies.
images.caption: Photo by E. Goode/NPS.

bodyText: The restoring Elwha nearshore. This is private property and a very fragile environment. Please be respectful.
audioDescription: Elwha Nearshore Trailhead. 3 minutes A large panel with color photographs and text provides information about this area. A text header reads: Welcome to the restoring Elwha nearshore. This is private property and a very fragile environment. Please be respectful. In the center of the panel text reads: This nearshore ecosystem is federally designated critical habitat utilized by several federal and state listed species. The Elwha nearshore serves as nursery grounds for migrating salmon as well as migrating and spawning grounds for surf smelt, sand lance and other forage fish. Beach features including vegetation and driftwood stabilize the beach and provide shade and habitat for a variety of species. What can you do. Leave Vegetation and Log Line (Large Woody Debris) untouched. No Driftwood Collection, Cutting, or Burning. No Unauthorized Motor Vehicles. This is a walking beach. No Fires or Fireworks. No Camping. No Firearms. No Alcohol. Leave No Trace Color photographs ring the text. Beginning in the top left corner and moving clockwise, a large flock of white birds, some floating on the water, some hovering overhead with extended wings. A caption reads, Gulls and eagles feeding on federally listed forage fish eulachon. Next, a juvenile Surf Smelt in profile facing left. It has a long thin body with a dark round eye, dark scales on top and silver scales on its side, a side fin, a fin on its top, and a V-shaped tail fin. On the far right, a magnified view of many round white objects and grains of sand. The caption reads, Forage fish eggs laid on upper intertidal beaches. Below, a silver-blue fish with a dark round eye atop a ruler that measures the fish at five-inches. The caption reads, Longfin smelt. In the bottom right corner, a high aerial view captioned, Elwha River mouth, shows the path of the main river channel through a forested area and then out across the white sand beach where the main channel and vein like tributaries enter the ocean. To the left, an eight-inch silver fish with grey vertical stripes and a dark round eye laying atop a ruler. The caption reads, Juvenile Chum, Chinook, and Coho salmon. The final photograph is an aerial view of a beach with a jumble of light-colored wood. The caption reads, Driftwood log line along beach.

title: Mouth of the Elwha Beach Trailhead
listingDescription: This sandy beach on the Strait of Juan de Fuca was formed after the dams on the Elwha River were removed in 2011 and 2014, gradually releasing many tons of sediment. It's a great place to appreciate the free flowing Elwha River's journey, not to mention catch a beautiful sunset. Look for geese and beavers in the nearby wetland, eagles and gulls fishing in the river, and seals offshore!Though not part of Olympic National Park, the mouth of the Elwha is a wonderful place to see

images.altText: A shimmering body of water, with a gravel bar visible off shore and mountains past the far shore.
images.title: The Mouth of the Elwha River
images.caption: Raindrops catching the sun as they fall.

bodyText:
This sandy beach on the Strait of Juan de Fuca was formed after the dams on the Elwha River were removed in 2011 and 2014, gradually releasing many tons of sediment. It's a great place to appreciate the free flowing Elwha River's journey, not to mention catch a beautiful sunset. Look for geese and beavers in the nearby wetland, eagles and gulls fishing in the river, and seals offshore!

Though not part of Olympic National Park, the mouth of the Elwha is a wonderful place to see how the Elwha River has transformed in the years since dam removal.

While there are not trash/litter receptacles, there is a designated dog waste disposal bin and porta potty available. These services are sponsored by Clallam Marine Resources Committee.
audioDescription: West Elwha Beach Trailhead. 1 minute A yellow gate with a sign that reads, Fire Lane, Do Not Block, spans most of the entrance to this trailhead. Access to the trail is at the left side of the gate. The trail is flat with a gravel surface. A tall brown and white sign on the right side of the trail reads: West Elwha Beach. Help keep it clean. Public access on the dike and beach is provided by private landowners and the Lower Elwha Klallam Tribe. Continued use depends on your compliance with the following: Disposal bins at the portable toilets. Protect birds and wildlife. Pack it in – pack it out. Symbols on the sign include: Clean up after your dog. Dogs must be on a leash Hiking, swimming, surfing and wildlife watching are permitted. Firearms, fires, camping, fireworks, and drones are not permitted Text at the bottom of the sign reads: This beach is maintained by community members and volunteers led by the Surfrider Foundation and Clallam County Marine Resources Committee and in Partnership with Clallam County.

listingDescription: The NatureBridge outdoor education campus hosts school groups, youth science and backpacking trips, teacher development, family programs, and even weddings. Learn more at https://naturebridge.org/locations/olympic
