title: North Fork Ranger Station
listingDescription: Unstaffed.

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a building with a flag.

bodyText: Unstaffed.
audioDescription: North Fork Ranger Station. 1 minute In front of a wooden rail fence is a brown wooden sign with white text that reads, North Fork Ranger Station. A driveway to the left of the fence leads to a parking area for the Ranger Station on the left. The single-story building has a peaked brown shingle roof and brown wooden shingle siding. Windows are trimmed in white, and the front door is green. A small, covered porch with a step up is on the front of the building which faces the parking area. On the right side of the porch is a white bulletin board with park information and a map of the area. A second building similar in style and look is on the right side of the parking area. The buildings sit in an open area surrounded by a forest of moss-covered pines and deciduous trees with a dense understory of ferns and other plants.

title: North Fork Restroom and Campground Registration

images.altText: Black and white symbol for restroom with male and female figures separated by a wall.

bodyText: Restroom and campground registration for North Fork Campground.
audioDescription: North Fork Campground Registration. 30 seconds On a grassy island in the center of the looping road is a two-sided, roof covered, bulletin board with information about fishing, trails, wilderness, pets, firearms, safety notices and overnight camping. The fee for overnight camping is provided along with instructions for mailing payments to the park. Envelopes are provided in a brown box attached to the bulletin board. Adjacent to the bulletin board is a brown metal 2-foot-high food storage locker.

title: North Fork Skokomish Trailhead
listingDescription: This trailhead is located above the Ranger Station. Walk past the overflow parking and stock corral to reach it. Dayhikers can walk the valley part of this 15.1-mile (24.3 km) trail that leads eventually to the Duckabush River. If you plan to make this the start of an overnight backpacking trip, check in with the Wilderness Information Center https://www.nps.gov/olym/planyourvisit/wic.htm

images.altText: A path with stairs leads through tall trees in a forest.
images.caption: Photo by E. Goode/NPS

bodyText: This trailhead is located above the Ranger Station. Walk past the overflow parking and stock corral to reach it. Dayhikers can walk the valley part of this 15.1-mile (24.3 km) trail that leads eventually to the Duckabush River. If you plan to make this the start of an overnight backpacking trip, check in with the Wilderness Information Center.
audioDescription: North Fork Skokomish. Trailhead. Overview On the edge of the parking area is the trailhead for North Fork Skokomish River. To the left of the trailhead is a large brown wooden sign listing the names and distance in miles to locations along the trail. Text reads, North Fork Skokomish River. Rapids Bridge 1. Flapjack Lake Junction 4. Camp Pleasant 6.9. Nine Stream 10. First Divide 13.1. To the right of the trailhead, and behind large rocks lining the edge of the parking lot, are two tall kiosks with information about planning and preparing for your hike and how to protect the wilderness. To the right of the kiosks stands a bulletin board with additional information about park rules and regulations. Continue listening for a description of the kiosk panels and bulletin board information. 7 minutes. Beginning with the kiosk closest to the trail, a text header across the top in white and green lettering on a black background reads, Your First 3 Steps into Wilderness. The remainder of the panel is an image of a lake surrounded by a forest of tall, thin green pine trees, with brown, jagged mountain peaks in the distance. In the lake’s blue water is a reflection of the forest and mountains. Text across the middle of the image reads, When you enter the Olympic Wilderness, you’re in for a wild time. Six hundred miles of trails link you to sea and sky. Are you hiking the coast, crossing creeks through old-growth forest or ascending mile-high peaks? Whatever your destination, Your First 3 Steps into Wilderness can lead to success or disaster. Attentive trip planning and preparation will help protect you and the future of wilderness. Step 1. Plan, Step 2 Prepare, Step 3 Protect. The header on the second panel reads, Step 1. Plan. Below, are two columns of text. On the left is parkwide planning information. On the right, is planning information pertaining to Staircase. Text in the Parkwide column reads: Before your trip, contact the park’s Wilderness Information Center (WIC) for safety information, permits and regulations. Group size limit is 12. Leave your trip itinerary, including date of return, with someone who expects you back. Observe all regulations, including those that restrict pets, weapons and wheeled vehicles or devices. Safely secure all food, garbage and scented items 24 hours a day to protect yourself and wildlife. Contact the WIC for bear cannister loan locations. Text in the Staircase column reads: Protect vegetation and the value of solitude by observing limits on the number and size of camping parties at Flapjack Lakes. Contact the WIC for reservations and permits. Check local conditions before heading out. Even if it is spring in the Skokomish valley, higher elevations may still be snow covered, making route finding and travel difficult. Observe stock regulations that help protect you, your animals and the wilderness. Above 3,500 feet, stay on trails and only use designated stock camps. Pack non-viable pellets or rolled grain. Below the text, is a Trail Grade Profile illustrating the elevation for locations along the trails. The Wagonwheel Lake trail terminates at 4,000 feet. Flapjack Lakes are at 4,000 feet. The North Fork Skokomish River trail reaches almost 5,000 feet before terminating a bit above 4,000 feet. A map at the bottom shows the trail system in the Staircase area with the text, You Are Here. Three small photographs are inset into the map. The first, a red and black frog; next, purple spiked flowers; and last, a black, white, and orange butterfly with wings opened on a pink flower. Moving to the right, the second kiosk has two tall vertical panels. The header on the first panel reads, Step 2. Prepare. Below the header, text reads, Parkwide. Carry backcountry essentials including extra food, extra warm-when-wet clothing, topographic map, compass, flashlight and extra batteries, sunglasses and sunscreen, pocketknife, matches in waterproof container, candle or firestarter and first aid kit. Prepare for hazards of weather, terrain, water crossing and wildlife. Prevent hypothermia in cool, wet weather by wearing wool and synthetic layers, a warm hat and raingear. Boil, filter or chemically treat all drinking water to avoid infection by Giardia, a microscopic intestinal parasite. Staircase. Always check the weather forecast and prepare for the unexpected. Consult a ranger about snow and trail conditions prior to every outing. Rely on basic gear and skill, not electronics. Cell phones, GPS units and other electronic devices may not work, especially in lower valleys and forested areas. Wear sturdy, waterproof boots and gaiters. The trail can be muddy or rocky and rugged. In the center of the panel are three photographs, the first, a swollen stream of white rushing water, cascading over boulders through the center of a thick pine forest; the second, a heavy-set black bear with long snout, close-spaced eyes, and rounded ears, stands in the forest looking directly at the camera; the third, a plant, with dark veined green leaves and three bunches of red berries. The header on the second panel reads, Step 3. Protect. Below, text reads: Parkwide. Leave no trace of your stay. Think about how your actions impact wildlife, vegetation and visitors. Use established campsites. If hiking cross-country, camp on durable surfaces like rock and snow. Minimize use of campfires. Pack out everything you pack in. Properly dispose of human waste. Use privies where available or dig a 6 to 8-inch hole at least 200 feet from camps and water. Do not urinate in composting or vault toilets. Wash your dishes and yourself away from lakes and streams. To protect water quality, avoid using soap. Leave natural objects and cultural artifacts where you find them to help protect this irreplaceable wilderness. Staircase. Never feed wildlife for their health and your safety. Backpackers and day hikers should always keep food secured from wildlife. Protect vegetation. Observe restoration closures to allow plants to recover. Avoid walking on or disturbing plants, especially near trails, water or campsites. Use a stove to eliminate impacts of fires and wood gathering. Campfires are prohibited about 3,500 feet. If you build a fire at lower elevations, keep it small and use an existing fire ring. Gather, don’t cut, only small pieces of dead and down wood. Be sure your fire is out cold as winds can reignite embers. To the right and below the text are three photographs. A tall image of red, yellow, and pink wildflowers, some growing between grey rocks; next, a brown and white adult marmot, standing in profile with a dark grey young marmot standing behind it; and, a dark blue mountain lake with a flower-strewn meadow in the foreground, and snow peaked gray mountains in the background. To the right of the kiosks is a bulletin board with park regulations pertaining to campfires, trails, wilderness camping permits, wildlife, and marijuana; instructions for obtaining a wilderness camping permit; and how to pay your park entrance fee. Below the regulations are safety notices about backcountry safety; mountain goats and your safety; and your safety in cougar country. The last notice at the bottom explains the fishing regulations for North Fork Skokomish River in Olympic National Park. A final sign along the parking area marks the head of another trail. Text reads, Wagonwheel Lake. 2.9 miles. 3,200 feet vertical elevation gain. Very steep. No Pets allowed on the trail.

title: North Fork Trailhead (Quinault)
listingDescription: From the North Fork Campground area, this trail leads up the North Fork of the Quinault River into the Wilderness. To plan a backpacking trip, contact the Wilderness Information Center at http://www.nps.gov/olym/planyourvisit/wilderness.htm. For more information on Wilderness Information Center locations and hours go to https://www.nps.gov/olym/planyourvisit/wic.htm. Shorter day hikes out and back on this trail meander past streams through low elevation rain forest, reaching

images.altText: A clear river runs peacefully between forested banks, with snowy peaks in the distance
images.title: North Fork of the Quinault River
images.caption: The North Fork of the Quinault River

bodyText: From the North Fork Campground area, this trail leads up the North Fork of the Quinault River into the Wilderness. To plan a backpacking trip, contact the Wilderness Information Center. Shorter day hikes out and back on this trail meander past streams through low elevation rain forest, reaching large cedars and maples heavy with moss.
audioDescription: North Fork Trailhead and Wayside. 3 minutes On the right side of the dirt parking lot and down a wide path is an all gender, single stall, accessible restroom building with a vault toilet. Enter on the right front side beneath an open alcove. The door to the restroom is on the left. A metal garbage receptacle stands in front of the restroom on the left. On the left side of the parking lot are fenced stock corrals. At the top of the parking lot is the trailhead. Be advised: the trail varies in width, is rough and uneven, and in places, covered with rocks. To the left of trail is a roof covered bulletin board, and to the right, a tall interpretive panel. Text at the bottom of the panel reads: North Fork Trailhead. The north fork Quinault River-Low Divide Trail follows the river grade through a rain forest of Sitka spruce and moss-curtained bigleaf maple. The trail parallels several narrow canyons 200 to 300 feet above the stream. After crossing the river at Sixteen Mile (13.2), you begin a 4.6-mile climb to Low Divide (3600 feet). From there you can make side trips to Martins Park, Martins Lakes, or along the Skyline Trail towards Lake Beauty. Text continues: The Press Expedition. In 1890 the first explorers to cross the Olympic interior struggled six months to get here from Elwha River. Now, on a well-marked trail, you can hike their route in less than a week. Pack mules carried 1500 pounds of equipment for the five men: tent, blankets, ammunition for rifles, snowshoes, tools, flour, bacon, coffee and cooking pots. For food they depended mostly on game. To the left of the text is a black and white illustration showing five men, four standing and one kneeling, wearing wide brimmed hats, and long-sleeved shirts and pants. Four have facial hair. They each hold a rifle and look in different directions. In the center of the panel is a map with the text, You Are Here, and the trail marked with white dashes. Park boundaries, campgrounds, and other trails are marked on the map. At the top of the panel is a trail grade profile showing the trailhead elevation at 500-feet and ending at Low Divide where the elevation is 3600 feet. The bulletin board has posted information on both sides regarding trailhead burglaries; contact a park ranger or dial 911 in an emergency; bear and cougar awareness; day hikes at Quinault; backcountry safety; river crossings; wilderness regulations; stock use; pet regulations; firearms and weapons; fish advisory; fishing regulations, and how to help preserve your park. Up trail, a sign with the header, North Fork Quinault, provides mileage distance to nine locations along the trail. Wolf Bar 2.5, Halfway House 5.1, Elip Creek Junction 6.5, Trapper Shelter 8.1, Twelve Mile Shelter 11.5, Sixteen Mile 12.2, Skyline Trail Junction 15.7, Low Divide 16.1, and Whiskey Bend Road 44.3.

title: North Fork Trailhead (Sol Duc)
listingDescription: Come prepared when you make this 9.3 mile hike through montane forests! The route includes a river crossing, and changing weather can create hazardous conditions. This trail is not suitable for those who do not have map and compass skills. Always carry your Ten Essentials, and contact the Wilderness Information Center for trail conditions or to plan an overnight trip in the backcountry https://www.nps.gov/olym/planyourvisit/wic.htmhttps://www.nps.gov/articles/10essentials.h

images.altText: A trail through a green forest.
images.caption: The North Fork Trail in the Sol Duc River valley.

bodyText: Come prepared when you make this 9.3 mile hike through montane forests! The route includes a river crossing, and changing weather can create hazardous conditions. This trail is not suitable for those who do not have map and compass skills. Always carry your Ten Essentials, and contact the Wilderness Information Center for trail conditions or to plan an overnight trip in the backcountry.
audioDescription: North Fork Trailhead. 1 minute This roadside parking area is narrow and backs up to a cliff. A sign reads, Warning. Unstable cliff face. Do not cross fence line. To access the trail from the parking area, cross the two-lane road. A brown and white sign on the left side of the trailhead has the word, Trail, with a right pointing arrow. Be advised, the trail surface here is riddled with tree roots. The trail almost immediately enters a dense forest of towering pine trees. Up trail, on the right, is a brown, wooden information kiosk with posted notices about proper food storage in bear country, Leave No Trace and wilderness protection regulations, wilderness permits for camping, campfires and why they are not permitted, and pets. A tall bulletin board stands next to the kiosk. Still further up the trail, a brown and white sign on the left reads, No pets, weapons, or vehicles.

title: North Kalaloch Beach Access pullout

images.altText: A P symbol denoting a parking area
images.title: Parking Lot
images.caption: Parking

bodyText: A narrow trail from this gravel pullout leads to the beach.
audioDescription: The narrow trail to the beach is located directly off the gravel pullout. A sign with park information sits in the center of the trailhead. Pets must be leashed at all times. The trail cuts through the center of dense growing shrubs.

title: North Peninsula Overlook
listingDescription: On a clear day, look out at across the valley to the Strait of Juan de Fuca.

images.altText: A wayside sign near an overlook view of a valley/
images.caption: Photo by E. Goode/NPS.

bodyText: On a clear day, look out at across the valley to the Strait of Juan de Fuca.
audioDescription: Hurricane Ridge Road Wayside Overlook. 4 minutes Along the front edge of the parking lot is a flat, gravel overlook area completely outlined by a six-inch-high concrete bumper. The landscape beyond the overlook begins with low tree covered hills and open areas with structures, then a wide expanse of water, with mountains in the distance on the opposite shore. On the left side of the gravel area are three wayside panels, each in a three-foot-tall, angled metal frame. The wayside on the extreme left is titled, Siege of Ice. Text reads: Only ice, sky, and a few jagged islands of rock – an ocean of ice filled the horizon. If there is valley fog, imagine it is ice, and you will have a picture of the continental glacier, grinding against the terrain. Glaciers were the prime architects of the scenery before you. But in this green landscape the only way to comprehend the extent of the ice is to examine the aftermath. A thousand feet above this spot the melting glacier dumped tons of rock and gravel debris. Only glaciers could have carved this valley’s steep walls. Filling the left side of the panel, a black and white drawing shows dark finger-like edges of mountains in a white landscape. A smaller image beneath the text shows three large rocks on white ground with a dark hill in the background. The caption reads: House-sized boulders lie scattered around the park, their crystals foreign to Olympic rock. Moving to the right, the next wayside is titled, Oh say can you see? Filling the top of this wide panel is an illustration of the landscape before you with various points of interest labeled and the Strait of Juan de Fuca in the center. From left to right, Victoria, Canada, Mt. Douglas, Haro Strait, Discovery Island, San Juan Islands, American Camp, San Juan Island National Historic Park, Bellingham Washington, Dungeness National Wildlife Refuge, Mt. Baker 10,778 feet, Sequim, Washington, Protection Island, North Cascades National Park, Puget Sound, and Glacier Peak. Text below reads: In clear weather you can see Canada and the volcanic peaks of the Cascade Mountains. Visibility here is becoming increasingly impaired, however, by pollutants from sources including industry, wood stoves, and the automobiles we drive. A quote by Thoreau reads: Simply to see a distant horizon through clean air is wealth enough for one afternoon. The final wayside on the right is titled, Rainshadow. Text reads: Farmland to the northeast must be irrigated. Less than 20 inches of rain falls there annually. Behind you only 40 miles to the west grows a dense rainforest, a dripping jungle of ferns and giant spruce in a Jack-in-the-beanstalk environment nurtured by 140 to 180 inches of rainfall per year. Mountains cast the shadow. Saturated Pacific winds rise steeply up the coastal slopes. As sudden altitude cools and condenses the air, most of the moisture is wrung out over the peaks by the time clouds reach this corner of the peninsula. Filling the left side of the panel is a drawing of a snow-capped mountain with clouds overhead, one cloud dropping lines of blue rain on the left side of the mountain. A white arrow in the rain points up slope. A smaller image to the right captioned, Rain forest, shows tree branches covered with draping moss.

title: North Shore Day Use Area

images.altText: Black and white symbol for restroom with male and female figures separated by a wall.

bodyText: Day use area on the north shore of Lake Crescent
audioDescription: North Shore Day Use Area. 2 minutes A sign at the entrance reads: North Shore Day Use Area. Alcohol and Glass prohibited. Graphics on the sign indicate that picnic tables are available, pets on leash are allowed, and camping is prohibited. The road ends at a parking lot with parking spaces on the right. A paved, accessible parking spot is located at the far end of the lot next to an all gender, single stall, accessible restroom building with a vault toilet. Enter on the left front side beneath an open alcove. The door to the restroom is on the right. The trail to the day use areas and lake shore begins about 30 feet down a slight hill and to the right of the restroom. Be advised. There are large rocks on the left and right sides of the trailhead. The dirt trail passes through a forest of tall pine trees and varies from flat to sloped. In one section, there is a concrete stairway with 10 steps and no hand railings. At the bottom of the steps on the left is a flat picnic area with an in-ground metal fire pit. To the right, the trail continues to the lake on a slight slope. At the shoreline, a wooden dock extends out into the lake about 30 feet. Be advised: there is a step up onto the dock and there is no railing around the perimeter of the dock. Toward the front of the dock on the right, is a single grab bar above a low platform where boats may be tied up, and on the left, a short set of stairs with no grab bar descends into the water. There is an alternate trail without steps back up to the parking area. It passes another picnic area with a metal fire pit.

title: Obstruction Point Trailhead
listingDescription: Another option for longer hikes is to drive the narrow, gravel Obstruction Point road and hike along the high alpine ridges or into Grand Valley. The drive is not for the faint of heart (or unwieldy large vehicles like RVs and trailers), but the breathtaking views are worth it.

images.altText: A trail through a flat area, with mountains in the distance.
images.caption: Fall at Obstruction Point. Photo by C. Bubar/NPS

bodyText: Another option for longer hikes is to drive the narrow, gravel Obstruction Point road and hike along the high alpine ridges or into Grand Valley. The drive is not for the faint of heart (or unwieldy large vehicles like RVs and trailers), but the breathtaking views are worth it.
audioDescription: Obstruction Point Trailhead. Overview. 1 minute Off the parking area is an all gender, accessible, single stall restroom with a vault toilet. At the trailhead, a brown and white sign reads, Obstruction Point. Elevation 6100 feet. Listed below are destinations along the trails that branch off from here with mileage to each. Beside an upward pointing arrow are Badger Valley, .3 miles and Deer Park, 7.5 miles. Beside a right pointing arrow are Grand Lake, 3.7 miles, Moose Lake, 4.2 miles, and Grand Pass, 5.9 miles. Attached to the leg of this sign is a smaller sign that reads, No Pets, Weapons, or Vehicles. To the right of this sign is a tall bulletin board with changing park information. Behind the bulletin board are three, three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panels standing side-by-side providing information about the Olympic Wilderness, Obstruction Point Trail, and Backcountry Tactics. Continue listening for a description of each panel. 5 minutes Beginning with the wayside on the left, text at the top left corner reads, Olympic Wilderness. Local tribal people have visited the Olympic Mountains for centuries. Today wilderness use has increased so much that long-lasting impacts are occurring in this fragile environment. Text at the bottom right corner reads, Subalpine plants have adapted to wind, cold, and thin soil, but not to human use. Help protect Olympic’s wilderness character. Camp in established campsites or on bare ground. Travel on trails or trample-resistant surfaces. Bury human waste away from streams and lakes. Use a backpacking stove. Build small campfires only where allowed. Pack out all trash. Leave what you find for others to enjoy. In wilderness you may find unspoiled scenery, solitude and adventure. Be prepared to accept wilderness on its own terms. Four illustrations are spread across this panel. From left to right, a green and black dome tent sits atop smooth ground near an outcropping of rocks. The caption reads, Place tents on established campsites. Next, a booted, human foot, steps on grass with the caption, Travel on trails wherever possible. Then, a plastic, six-ring drink can holder and a blue, plastic cup laying on its side have the caption, Carry out all trash. The final illustration shows a jumbled, rock, fire ring on the ground surrounded by grass. Inset, is a small broad-based blue container with a thin neck and a single stove burner attached to the top of the neck. The caption reads: Use backpacking stoves to reduce impact. The second wayside panel has the header, Obstruction Point Trailhead. Filling the left side of the panel is a green map with trails marked in black dashed lines and the text, You Are Here, indicating your current location on the map. Filling the right side of the panel under the header text, reads: Deer Park Trail. This trail, one of the highest in the park, follows an open ridgetop all the way to Deer Park, 7.4 miles. From Elk Mountain near Obstruction Point there are good views of Mount Olympus. Badger Valley Trail. The trail traverses northeast .2 miles, then descends steeply through Badger Valley to Grand Valley. Grand Lake is .2 miles below the junction of the Badger Valley, Lillian Ridge, and Grand Pass Trails. Moose Lake is almost a mile from Grand Lake. From Gladys Lake to the pass is a steep climb for over a mile. Lillian Ridge Trail. For a steep but shorter route back to Obstruction Point from Grand Valley, climb 1200 feet in less than 2 miles to Lillian Ridge and follow the ridge 2 miles to Obstruction Point. Isolated Plants. Certain vegetation grows here and nowhere else. With no relatives among their lowland neighbors, some upland plants more closely resemble arctic species. The Ice Age ferried around a variety of seeds, and apparently some tundra plants found these mountaintops a familiar, favorable place to take root. Isolated from civilization, and from the common plant community, the Olympic Mountains were islanded by glaciers. Inset, is a black and white drawing of small plants, two with long stems topped by a bushy, oblong spike of leaves, and others, low lying, with five petals around a dark center. The header on the third wayside panel reads, Backcountry Tactics followed by the text, From this point on, meet the wilderness on its own terms. The weather can change swiftly, dramatically. Hypothermia, a sudden drop in body temperature, is a threat even in summer. Bring layers of clothing: wool shirt and sweater, wind and water-repellent shell or parka. If you plan to cross any high passes, carry an ice axe and know how to use it. Snow remains late and the trail can ice up. Travelers to Grand Valley who are caught by early autumn snow should stay in the valley until the storm passes. During blizzards people have died trying to hike out via Lillian Ridge. Below the text, a black and white drawing shows a person laying on their stomach dressed in winter clothing, holding a T-shaped ice ax. The head of the ax is square on one end and pointed on the other and is perpendicular to the shaft which is approximately 20-inches long. The base of the shaft ends in a spike. The illustration is captioned, Ice Ax, and depicts a person stopping their fall on an icy slope by pressing the head of the ax into the ice. To the left of the text, are four sequential drawings of a man in different stages of dress to illustrate how to layer winter clothing. First, the man wears white long underwear with long sleeves and long pants. Second, a blue hat, red and black checkered shirt, pants, and knee-high boots have been added. Third, a puffy, blue, zipped vest has been put on. Fourth, the man is shown wearing a green parka with a white, fur-rimmed hood and yellow gloves over top all the layers.

title: Olympic Hot Springs Trailhead
listingDescription: The access road to this trailhead is currently open only to foot traffic and bicycles beyond Madison Falls parking area. This adds an additional 8 miles/12.9 km to your hike/ride just to get to the trail head. From there, an additional easy 2.5 mile/4 km hike takes you to the hot spring. Because this is a back country trip, be prepared with your 10 essentials and contact the Wilderness Information Center at https://www.nps.gov/olym/planyourvisit/wic.htm

images.altText: A black and white symbol for trailhead with a figure of a person with a walking stick and backpack.

bodyText: The access road to this trailhead is currently open only to foot traffic and bicycles beyond Madison Falls parking area. This adds an additional 8 miles/12.9 km to your hike/ride just to get to the trail head. From there, an additional easy 2.5 mile/4 km hike takes you to the hot spring. Because this is a back country trip, be prepared with your 10 essentials and contact the Wilderness Information Center.

title: Outdoor Recreation Information Center

images.altText: Person in ranger uniform talking with visitor
images.title: Ranger station at REI
images.caption: Ranger station at REI

relatedParks.fullName: Klondike Gold Rush - Seattle Unit National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Klondike Gold Rush - Seattle Unit

relatedParks.fullName: San Juan Island National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: San Juan Island

bodyText: At the Ranger Desk in the REI Seattle Flagship Store, we have the information you need to discover the best recreation opportunities on public lands in Washington State. We also have a wide selection of educational merchandise and free printed materials to help you make the most of your visit. We're able to bring you this unique service experience through a dynamic partnership with the National Park Service, U.S. Forest Service, Washington State Parks, and REI.

title: Ozette Area Information

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Ozette Area Information. 1 minute Along the side of the road is a gravel pull-off with two informal bulletin boards, one managed by the National Park Service, the other by the Friends of Hoko River State Park. The NPS board has posted notices about wilderness, fishing, boating, and pet regulations; coastal safety; marine debris; food storage on the coast; Leave No Trace Ethics; and how to help preserve your park. One notice reads: Cryptosporidium and giardia are in the coastal water sources. Boil or filter all water. Chemical treatments like chlorine and iodine do not work. The Friends group board has changing notices about environmental work by local groups and tour information. Near the bulletin boards is a brown and white sign that reads: Olympic National Park Ozette Area 21 Miles. A right pointing arrow with text reads: Ozette Campground. The sign will read either open or closed. A second right pointing arrow with text reads: Coastal Camping. At the bottom text reads: Pets prohibited on Ozette Trails.

title: Ozette Boat Launch
listingDescription: Lake Ozette is a wonderful place to canoe and kayak, but it can change from calm and tranquil to very windy quickly, and waves several feet high are common during high winds. The water can also be dangerously cold. Always wear life jackets when you're out on the water, and consider wearing wet suits or other thermal clothing in case of accidental immersion. There have been a number of cold-water drownings in Lake Ozette, so be extra careful and remember safety gear for a good

images.altText: A dirt road slopes gently into a lake in the distance
images.title: Ozette Boat Launch
images.caption: Ozette Boat Launch

bodyText: Lake Ozette is a wonderful place to canoe and kayak, but it can change from calm and tranquil to very windy quickly, and waves several feet high are common during high winds. The water can also be dangerously cold. Always wear life jackets when you're out on the water, and consider wearing wet suits or other thermal clothing in case of accidental immersion. There have been a number of cold-water drownings in Lake Ozette, so be extra careful and remember safety gear for a good experience.
audioDescription: Boat Launch. 30 seconds A gravel road leads to the boat launch. About halfway down the road a sign on the left reads, Load and unload only. Parking lot .1 mile north. A sign on the right has an upward pointing arrow and reads, Boat Launch. At the end of the road on the right is a bulletin board with posted park information. Straight ahead, the gently sloping launch area is an extension of the gravel road. Around the marshy shoreline reeds and grasses grow. Behind them is a dense forest of pine trees.

title: Ozette Ranger Station Parking

images.altText: A P symbol denoting a parking area
images.title: Parking Lot
images.caption: Parking

bodyText: Parking lot
audioDescription: Ozette Ranger Station Parking. 2 minutes The flat gravel parking lot is edged with concrete parking bumpers. Along the left side of the lot is an all gender, single stall, accessible restroom building with a vault toilet. Enter on the right front side beneath an open alcove. The door to the restroom is on the left. Be advised. In the parking lot in front of the restroom entrance is a staff parking space partially boxed in with parking bumpers. To the right of the restroom on the grass is an open fronted, roof covered building with a bench seat along the back wall. Behind this building is a grassy picnic area with tables. The flat, gravel trail to the ranger station is to the left of the restrooms toward the parking lot entrance. Large boulders mark the trailhead on the left and right. Almost immediately on the right is a brown and white sign with an upward pointing arrow that reads, Coastal Trail Information. Restrooms. On the left side of the trail is a roof covered bulletin board with park information about coastal, backcountry and river crossing safety; wilderness regulations, food storage, campfires and permits; fishing regulations; nearest services; and what to do in an emergency. Contact a ranger or dial 911. In the left bottom corner is information about how to pay your entrance fee. In the right bottom corner is a notice that reads: Cryptosporidium and giardia are in the coastal water sources. Boil or filter all water. Chemical treatments like chlorine and iodine do not work. Additional information is posted on the back of the bulletin board. Further down trail, a slightly arched wooden bridge with side railings spans a creek. On the other side of the bridge is the Ranger Station on the left, a building with interpretive panels on the right, and restrooms straight ahead.

title: Ozette Triangle Coastal Trailhead
listingDescription: From here, hike the Ozette Triangle for a 9-mile (14.5 km) round-trip day hike or overnight, or travel through the forest to connect to longer coastal hiking routes for overnight backpacking. To plan a backpacking trip, contact the Wilderness Information Center at http://www.nps.gov/olym/planyourvisit/wilderness.htm. Wilderness permits are NOT available at the Ozette Ranger Station. When hiking the coast, remember to be aware of tides! Certain routes will become impassible at

images.altText: A boardwalk trail leads through a misty forest
images.title: Ozette Triangle boardwalk
images.caption: A boardwalk leads through a misty forest on the Ozette Triangle trail

bodyText: From here, hike the Ozette Triangle for a 9-mile (14.5 km) round-trip day hike or overnight, or travel through the forest to connect to longer coastal hiking routes for overnight backpacking. To plan a backpacking trip, contact the Wilderness Information Center. Wilderness permits are NOT available at the Ozette Ranger Station. When hiking the coast, remember to be aware of tides! Certain routes will become impassible at high tide. Know your route and consult your tide table.
audioDescription: Coastal Trailhead. 1 minute A paved walkway leads across a bridge with siderails at this trailhead. A brown wooden sign with white text to the left of the bridge approach reads, Coastal Trails. Backcountry permits required for overnight use. Boardwalk trails slippery when wet. Graphic icons indicate that pets and bicycles are not permitted on the trail. A second brown and white sign attached to the bridge railing on the left reads, Lake Ozette Sockeye Salmon Research. The Makah Tribe operate a smolt trap and automated counting weir each year to determine timing and abundance of the Lake Ozette sockeye salmon run. This equipment is designed to minimize interference with the migration of the fish. Fisheries personnel work on the trap and weir mostly at night. This is a cooperative project between the National Park Service and the Makah Tribe, working to restore the Lake Ozette Sockeye salmon run. In the water below is a silver metal ladder with research apparatus attached to one side. On the opposite side of the bridge the trail enters a dense forest of pine and deciduous trees.

title: Park Headquarters Offices
listingDescription: No services. Not open to the public. Administrative offices.

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a building with a flag.

bodyText: No services. Not open to the public. Administrative offices.
audioDescription: Park Headquarters. 1 minute The first floor of this two-story, long rectangular building is constructed of grey stonework, and the second floor is covered with grey shingles. Brown wooden shingles cover the pitched roof. A stone chimney sits atop the roof at left of center. The long side of the building faces front with five windows extending across the second floor. A glass entry door and four windows span across the first floor. The entry door is left of center, set between two stone walls parallel to the front of the building and covered by a shingled roof. A flat sidewalk leads to five stone steps and a landing in front of the entry door. Above the landing, a brown sign with black letters reads, Olympic National Park. Small trees, ferns, and shrubs grow around the base of the building.

title: Parking Area for Dickey Boat Ramp

images.altText: The letter â€œPâ€, in a square icon.

bodyText: Parking area. Boat ramp located across the road.
audioDescription: Parking Area Boat Ramp. 15 seconds A sign along the paved roadway has a left pointing arrow for Dickey Boat Ramp and a right pointing arrow for Parking. The dirt side road for parking leads to a wide, round gravel parking area. Birch trees with white bark grow in the forest here along with green pine trees.

title: Peabody Creek Trailhead
listingDescription: A half-mile (0.8 km), creekside loop from the visitor center parking area.

images.altText: A trail through the forest and a bridge over a creek, seen from a high angle.
images.caption: Peabody Creek Trail. Photo by D. Sullivan/NPS.

bodyText: A half-mile (0.8 km), creekside loop from the visitor center parking area.
audioDescription: Peabody Creek Trailhead. 1 minute A sign at the head of the trail reads, Peabody Creek Trail. One-half mile loop. Bicycles prohibited. The flat gravel trail leads into a dense forest of tall trees and thick undergrowth. Green moss clings to standing and fallen trees. Pine trees with full branches, some hanging low, create dark spaces within the forest. Tall, slender, trees with mottled white and gray bark, lean left and right. Other trees stand straight and tall with brown bark deeply ridged and etched. Along each side of the path, tall ferns and other ground cover create a lush blanket of greens and browns.

title: Peabody Creek secondary trailhead (unmarked)

title: Pillow Basalt view at Morse Creek Overlook
listingDescription: Across the road from the Morse Creek overlook, you may notice interesting rock formations, called "pillow basalt." From the U.S. Geological Survey: Basalt "pillows" form when lava cools quickly under water. The lack of bubbles in the lava suggests that the rock crystallized on the ocean floor under the pressure of deep water (preventing bubbles from forming in the lava).

images.altText: A road cut into a steep rocky mountainside.
images.caption: The pillow basalt alongside Hurricane Ridge Road. Photo by E. Goode/NPS.

bodyText: Across the road from the Morse Creek overlook, you may notice interesting rock formations, called "pillow basalt." From the U.S. Geological Survey: Basalt "pillows" form when lava cools quickly under water. The lack of bubbles in the lava suggests that the rock crystallized on the ocean floor under the pressure of deep water (preventing bubbles from forming in the lava).
audioDescription: Pillow Basalt Pullout/ Morse Creek Overlook. 25 seconds A three-foot-high stone wall rings the outer edge of the sidewalk located at this overlook. Beyond, overlapping mountains covered with green pine trees extend into the distance. Across the road from the overlook are rock formations on a brown, dirt hillside. The grey and brown rocks are ragged, cracked, and somewhat round in shape. Trees grow up hill from the rock formations.

title: Pyramid Peak Trailhead from Spruce Railroad Trail
listingDescription: The Pyramid Peak trail is accessed from Camp David Junior Road on the North shore of Lake Crescent. The trail and climbs 2,600 feet in 3.5 miles (792 meters in 5.6 km); one section of the trail crosses a steep, exposed landslide. Like Mount Storm King, the summit has a fantastic panoramic view of the lake and Strait of Juan de Fuca from above, but the hike is longer and much more gradual.

images.altText: The mirror-like surface of a lake reflects clouds and mountains.
images.caption: The mirror-like surface of Lake Crescent on a calm day. Photo by B. Baccus/NPS.

bodyText: The Pyramid Peak trail is accessed from Camp David Junior Road on the North shore of Lake Crescent. The trail and climbs 2,600 feet in 3.5 miles (792 meters in 5.6 km); one section of the trail crosses a steep, exposed landslide. Like Mount Storm King, the summit has a fantastic panoramic view of the lake and Strait of Juan de Fuca from above, but the hike is longer and much more gradual.
audioDescription: Spruce Railroad Trailhead / Pyramid Peak Trailhead. 1 minute Parking for this trail includes an accessible parking spot. Across the road from the parking area a brown sign with white text and a left pointing arrow reads, Spruce RR Trail. Pyramid Peak Trail. The paved trail begins here on a gentle uphill slope. A three-foot-tall stone wall runs alongside the trail on the right until the trail makes a 180-degree bend to the right. Up trail is another 180-degree bend curving to the left. The trail continues to gently climb until it reaches a T-intersection with the flat, paved Spruce Railroad Trail. A directional sign at the intersection has arrows pointing left and right for the Spruce RR Trail and a right pointing arrow for the Pyramid Peak Trail. A sign at the Pyramid Peak trailhead reads, Pyramid Peak 3.5 miles. This trail is narrow and has a dirt surface. All trails pass through a dense forest of pine trees with an understory of moss and ferns.

A dirt road leads to a parking area loop and a single-story, rectangular building. It has a peaked, brown shingle roof and brown wooden siding and sits in an open grassy area surrounded by trees. A split rail fence with an opening for access partially edges the parking area. On the left front side of the building is a screened-in porch with two uneven steps in front of the door. Inside, the door to the station is straight ahead. Attached to the wall on the left is a bulletin board with park notices and other information about cougar and bear awareness, river crossings, wilderness and fishing regulations, area day hikes, how to help preserve the park, and a notice to contact a park ranger or dial 911 in an emergency. A tall, metal antenna stands near the back right corner of the building.

Sam's River Loop is a level day hike through different ages and stages of temperate rain forest, but winter storms often damage this trail, so you may have to scramble over fallen trees and other obstacles! Queets River Trail has somewhat more elevation gain, fluctuating between 240 and 800 feet. It will also require fording t

images.altText: A bee on a purple lupine flower
images.title: Bee and Lupine on Queets River bank
images.caption: Lupine growing on the banks of the Queets River

bodyText:
Queets River Trailhead is the beginning of two trails, the Sam's River Loop (2.8 miles/4.5 km), and the longer (16.2 miles/26.1 km) Queets River Trail. Sam's River Loop is a level day hike through different ages and stages of temperate rain forest, but winter storms often damage this trail, so you may have to scramble over fallen trees and other obstacles!

Queets River Trail has somewhat more elevation gain, fluctuating between 240 and 800 feet. It will also require fording the large river, so it may only be suitable for later season hikes when the flow is lower. 2.4 miles (3.9 km) up Queets River Trail, just before Coal Creek, there is a small side trail to the left that leads 0.2 miles (0.3 km) to one of the biggest Douglas-fir trees in the park, a humbling giant at 212 feet (65 meters) tall and 14 feet (4.2 meters) in diameter!
audioDescription: Queets River Trailhead. 90 seconds Parking for the trail is on the left side of the dirt road. The trailhead is further up the road just beyond a very large, moss covered tree trunk laying across most of the road. Move to the right of the trunk to access the trail. Past the tree on the left side of the trail is a roof covered bulletin board with park notices about cougar and bear awareness; river crossings; wildlife, food, and your safety; wilderness, park, and fishing regulations; area day hikes; pack it in, pack it out; and a notice to contact a park ranger or dial 911 in an emergency. In the center of the board is a wooden box with wilderness camping permits. Instructions are attached to the box lid. To the right of the bulletin board is an upright interpretive panel about travelling safely on the Queets River Trail. Select menu item, Queets River Trail Wayside, for a description of the panel. Beyond the panel the trail continues to the river.

bodyText: U.S. Forest Service Ranger Station. The rangers are also able to provide information and permits for Olympic National Park.
audioDescription: Hood Canal Quilcene Ranger Station and Visitor Information Center. 2 minutes The facility is a one-story, green building with a brown shingled roof. The entry area and front door are in the center of the building under a small roof set perpendicular to the main roof. Attached to the wall next to the front door is a brown sign with white letters that reads, Quilcene Ranger District, Olympic National Forest. The Forest Service logo is on the sign. Posted on the exterior wall of the building is information about recreational activities. Inside the facility is an information desk, sales area, and a large topographic map attached to the wall. Near the road in front of the building is a sign atop a 3-foot-high stone pedestal. The sign is square, though slightly broader at the top, with rounded corners. The top third of the sign is tan with words in brown that read, Hood Canal Ranger District, Quilene Station. The bottom portion is brown with words in tan that read, Olympic National Forest. Below, a thin sign reads, Visitor Information Center, and below this, a sign that reads, U.S. Department of Agriculture. Attached to the stone pedestal is the U.S. Forest service logo. The logo is in the shape of a shield, slightly wavy across the top with curved vertical sides that end in a beveled point at the bottom. It is brown with a gold edge and gold words at the top that read, Forest Service, and at the bottom, Department of Agriculture. In the center, the letters U and S are separated by a gold A-shaped pine tree.

On the left side of the map are small color photographs showing points of interest along the corridor, and on the right is text titled, A Highway Through the Past, providing information about the history of the area. Across the parking lot from the restrooms is the trailhead, a garbage can, and a three-section bulletin board. The section on the left includes self-service pay station information for the day use area. Standing in front of this board is a brown metal canister for depositing payment. The trail begins to the left of the bulletin board. Be advised. There are concrete parking curbs in front of each parking space.

title: Rialto Beach
listingDescription: Rialto Beach is one of the most popular beaches in Olympic, and one of the most accessible. A short path leads to a pebble beach and ocean view. In summer, there is a wheelchair accessible ramp on the path. Rialto is a wonderful place to look for wildlife, from otters and seals to pelicans and bald eagles! You may even see gray whales migrating in summer! Hikers can trek north along the undeveloped coast 1.5 miles (2.4 km) to the formation known as Hole in the Wall, and beyon

images.altText: A sunset over a rocky beach with a rushing tide.
images.caption: Sunset at Rialto Beach. Photo by B. Baccus/NPS.

bodyText:
Rialto Beach is one of the most popular beaches in Olympic, and one of the most accessible. A short path leads to a pebble beach and ocean view. In summer, there is a wheelchair accessible ramp on the path. Rialto is a wonderful place to look for wildlife, from otters and seals to pelicans and bald eagles! You may even see gray whales migrating in summer! Hikers can trek north along the undeveloped coast 1.5 miles (2.4 km) to the formation known as Hole in the Wall, and beyond. This coast has seen drama, tragedy and heroism. Memorials north of Rialto Beach commemorate 36 people who died in wrecks of Chilean and Norwegian vessels in 1920 and 1903.

Leashed pets are allowed from the parking lot to Ellen Creek, about half a mile north on the beach.
audioDescription: Rialto Beach. 90 seconds At the end of the parking area on the right is a sidewalk and two accessible restroom buildings that face the sidewalk. For each building, the men’s room entrance is on the far right, and the women’s room entrance is on the left. Just past the restrooms is a 3-foot-tall square stone water station with water spigots on the front face. Further up the sidewalk on the left is a roof covered kiosk with posted information. Topics include, Coastal safety regarding beach logs, slick footing, tides and headlands, sneaker waves, and rip currents; camping; pets; Ranger Programs at Mora; how to connect to Olympic National Park’s audio tour; Dial 911 or contact a ranger in an emergency; where to find the nearest services; Tide charts; Food storage in bear country; Leave No Trace ethics; wilderness permit process; no fires permitted; and a notice that reads: Cryptosporidium and giardia are in the coastal water sources. Boil or filter all water. Chemical treatments like chlorine and iodine do not work. Continuing straight ahead leads to the ocean. Be advised: large drift logs are scattered on the beach, some in piles, and rocks jut out of the sand along the water line.

title: Ruby Beach
listingDescription: A short hike through coastal forest reveals spectacular Ruby Beach. Its dramatic sea stacks and tide pools make Ruby Beach a favorite among the many beautiful beaches of the Olympic Coast.

images.altText: Sunset at a beach with rocky sea stacks and lavender water
images.title: Ruby Beach Sunset
images.caption: Sunset at Ruby Beach

bodyText:
A short hike through coastal forest reveals spectacular Ruby Beach. Its dramatic sea stacks and tide pools make Ruby Beach a favorite among the many beautiful beaches of the Olympic Coast.

 

Full Accessibility Description

Length: Viewing area adjacent to parking area; beach access 735 feet
Surface Type: Compacted gravel
Typical Trail Width: 4-5 feet
Typical Running Slope: Numerous drain dips that create steep cross slopes
Typical Cross Slope: Mostly under 1%, though sections have a significant crown (higher in the middle than on the edges)
Description: Ruby Beach is the northernmost beach access point in the Kalaloch Area. All of the beach access trails at Kalaloch descend from the top of the bluff to the beach. They are generally steep and constructed to weather the 8.5 feet of annual rainfall. Winter ocean swells typically rearrange the beach logs at each location, so conditions at the point where the trail reaches the beach are constantly subject to change.

The Ruby Beach parking area is a sloped gravel lot with two vault toilets in the center. There is an accessible viewing area overlooking the ocean on the north end of the parking area, with a lower section of rail for wheelchair users on the left-hand side. Vegetation may obscure the view at sitting height.

The Ruby Beach trail is the only beach access wide enough for a wheelchair to reach the beach. Be advised that the trail is steep, has multiple drain dips and there is a drain across the trail at the halfway point that is 3-6 inches deep. The trail starts on the west side of the overlook and runs approximately 300 feet downhill at 10-20% to the first switchback, which is wide and has a trailside bench. There are 3 drain dips in the top of this section placed 50 feet apart. Continuing downhill at grades of 8-16%, there is an angled drain dip 50 feet below the switchback that forms steep cross slopes, and a wood cross drain at 365 feet that creates a 12-inch wide, 3-6-inch drop. The grade remains steep at 7-16% until 510 feet, where it drops below 5% for the remainder of the trail. There is a spur access to the beach at 575 feet. At 675 feet, the trail narrows to 3 feet before ending at the beach at 735 feet.
audioDescription: Ruby Beach Trailhead. 1 minute Situated on a grass and gravel island on the right side of the circular parking lot is a brown, all gender accessible restroom building with vault toilets. The building front faces the parking lot. There are two restrooms, one door on the right and one on the left. The trailhead is located on the opposite side of the parking lot. On the right, before the trail enters the woods is a roof covered bulletin board with park information and regulations. Topics include: Marine debris; Beach Regulations regarding pets; resource preservation; Coastal safety regarding beach logs, slick footing, tides and headlands, sneaker waves, and rip currents; Beach fires; Tide charts; Ranger programs at Kalaloch; contact a ranger or dial 911 in an emergency; where to find the nearest services; traveling in cougar country; fishing; and that it is illegal to remove animals or plants found in the surf, on the beach, or in tidepools. To the left of the bulletin board is a brown lidded box on a post with trail brochures.

title: Ruby Beach Overlook

images.altText: A beach with large stone sea stacks.
images.caption: Ruby Beach just before sunset. PHoto by S. Sheltren/NPS.

bodyText: Pause to take in the view on your way down to Ruby Beach.
audioDescription: Ruby Beach Overlook. 1 minute In the center of the round overlook area is a log bench seat. The outer curved edge of the overlook has a wooden rail fence. The scene in front of the overlook is where the thin forest with low lying ground cover meets the white sand beach and the blue ocean. Sea stacks of steep vertical rock topped with trees and shrubs stand just offshore while smaller, more eroded stacks are closer to shore and on the beach itself. At high tide water surrounds all the stacks. Silvery white driftwood logs are scattered on the beach, some in jumbled piles. In the far distance, a headland of steep rocks topped with trees juts out into the ocean.

title: Salmon Cascades
listingDescription: 5 miles (8 km) up the Sol Duc road, stop by this viewing platform to witness the iconic leap of determined fish up a waterfall on their way to spawn. The view of the cascades is lovely year-round, but if you hope to see fish, look for Coho salmon in September and October, or steelhead trout from late March through May. These anadromous fish (meaning they live in both fresh and salt water) are born in the Sol Duc River, but spend most of their lives in the Pacific Ocean before

images.altText: Two salmon leaping in cascading water
images.title: Salmon leaping at Salmon Cascades
images.caption: Salmon leaping at Salmon Cascades

bodyText:
5 miles (8 km) up the Sol Duc road, stop by this viewing platform to witness the iconic leap of determined fish up a waterfall on their way to spawn. The view of the cascades is lovely year-round, but if you hope to see fish, look for Coho salmon in September and October, or steelhead trout from late March through May. These anadromous fish (meaning they live in both fresh and salt water) are born in the Sol Duc River, but spend most of their lives in the Pacific Ocean before returning home to spawn. Fishing is not allowed near Salmon Cascades. If you plan to fish, be sure to check the park fishing regulations for appropriate areas, limits, and equipment limitations. Please also be aware that to protect the fish resources, much of the park is only open to catch and release fishing.

 

 

Full Accessibility Description

Length: 190 feet to viewing platform
Surface Type: Compacted gravel
Typical Trail Width: 6 feet
Typical Running Slope: Less than 5% with one 12-foot uphill to the viewing platform 7-11%
Typical Cross Slope: Less than 2%
Elevation Gain/Loss: Less than 25 feet
Accessible Parking: Van-accessible parking along parking area.
Description: The primary purpose for this trail is to provide access to a viewing platform that is perched above Salmon Cascades on the Sol Duc River. In late summer/early fall, coho salmon can be seen leaping out of the water as they make their way upriver to spawn. The trailhead is at approximately milepost 7 on the Sol Duc Road. There is a van-accessible parking space immediately in front of the trail, and a picnic table and accessible toilet available to the right down a gravel walkway.

The trail proceeds into the woods at grades under 5%. At 100 feet there is a root in the center of the trail that creates a slight hump, but runs in-line with the trail, and can be easily navigated around. At 140 feet, the trail arrives at an intersection. The viewing platform is 50 feet further to the right from the intersection, including a brief steep climb for 12 feet at 7-11%. Continuing straight from the intersection, the trail narrows to a 2-foot width. The first 35 feet climbs at steep grades up to 15% then levels out, ending at a 2-3 foot drop off near the river.
audioDescription: Salmon Cascade Parking. 2 minutes A flat parking lot for eight vehicles is lined with horizontal, log, parking bumpers that designate individual parking spaces. On the opposite side of the bumpers, a thin, flat gravel area runs the length of the parking lot. There is a picnic table. At the far end of the gravel area is a brown, metal trash bin and an all gender, single stall, accessible restroom building with a vault toilet. Enter on the left front side of the building beneath an open alcove. The door to the restroom is on the right. Behind the gravel area is a forest of tall pine trees and an understory of low growing plants where a flat trail enters the woods. A brown wooden sign at the trailheads reads, No fishing in this area. A posted flyer attached to the sign reads: Fishing Regulations for Sol Duc River (main stem, North Fork, tributaries). Season: Open June 1 to October 31. Note: Area closed to fishing 100 yards upstream and 250 yards downstream at the Salmon Cascades. License: Not required. A Washington State catch record care is REQUIRED (bolded) to fish for salmon or steelhead, which must be accounted for as if caught in State waters. Catch and release: Except, anglers may retain 2 adipose clipped hatchery steelhead. Legal gear: Freshwater fishing is restricted to artificial lure with a single point, barbless hook. No bait is allowed. Fishing may only be conducted with a single rod, reel and line that is under immediate control. Only knotless nets may be used to land fish. Please report any violators to 360-565-3115 or contact a Park Ranger. A complete list of Olympic National Park Fishing Regulations may be obtained at Ranger Stations and Visitor Centers or can be found online at http://www.nps.gov/olym/planyourvisit/fishing.htm.”

title: Salmon Cascades Overlook

images.altText: A fish leaping up cascading water.
images.caption: Salmon Cascades. Photo by G. Longenbaugh.

bodyText: Viewing platform at Salmon Cascades
audioDescription: Salmon Cascade Overlook. 3 minutes Be advised, tree roots and rocks protrude onto the trail surface in places. At the end of the trail is a wooden platform overlooking the cascades. The left side railing and one-half of the front railing on the left are about four feet high. The remainder of the front railing and the right side are lower, about three feet high. Upstream is to the left, where flat, dark green water flowing from left to right, soon meets rocks of many sizes becoming frothy white as it cascades over dark brown boulders and rocks of various sizes. Changes in creek bed elevation from high to low create a series of water falls until finally downstream, the water flattens out again. The light brown rocks lining the river are rough in texture and covered in places with green moss. On the far riverbank, small deciduous trees with white bark stand in front of a dense forest of green pine trees. Just before the platform on the left side of the trail, is a three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel titled, Leaps of a Lifetime. Filling the panel’s background is a color cutaway illustration of a creek, two-thirds underwater and one third above. Underwater in the foreground, three salmon swim in shallow water above a gravelly creek bottom. One has bright red sides with a green and black spotted back, a hook nose that overhangs its mouth, a fin on its back and three fins on its belly. The other two salmon are greener with black spots and have pointed noses. In the near background, red and green salmon swim above a deep pool, and in the far background, two salmon leap out of the water at the base of a waterfall on their journey upstream. Text at the top left reads: Strength, endurance, instinct - how do tools of survival guide you through life’s challenges? Watch these powerful forces at work as coho salmon leap 11 feet up Salmon Cascades. Born in gravelly river beds above the cascades, thousands of juvenile coho salmon memorize river scents on their 70 mile swim to sea. For up to two years coho range hundreds of miles from Oregon to British Columbia. Ocean temperatures and salinity, angle of the sun and magnetic fields help guide them back to the Sol Duc River. These unique summer Coho enter the river in July when water levels are low and they can navigate the cascades. By recalling river scents, about 1,000 coho return to their birthplace from late summer to early fall. When they spawn and die, coho salmon bring new life. Their marine nutrients benefit forests and over 130 wildlife species. A caption in the bottom right corner reads: Do coho salmon share all their secrets of survival? Sometimes, when nature envelops us with wonder, and we are left with more curiosities than conclusions.

Sam's River Loop is a level day hike through different ages and stages of temperate rain forest, but winter storms often damage this trail, so you may have to scramble over fallen trees and other obstacles!

bodyText: Queets River Trailhead is the beginning of two trails, the Sam's River Loop (2.8 miles/4.5 km), and the longer (16.2 miles/26.1 km) Queets River Trail. Sam's River Loop is a level day hike through different ages and stages of temperate rain forest, but winter storms often damage this trail, so you may have to scramble over fallen trees and other obstacles!
audioDescription: Sams River Loop Trailhead. 30 seconds Just before the Queets River Trail crosses the river, a brown and white wooden sign on the right side of the trail reads, Sams River Loop Trail. Follow this narrow trail as it parallels the river, winding through a forest of towering pine trees, some covered with green moss, and an understory of ferns and mosses.

title: Sam's River Loop Trailhead at Ranger Station
listingDescription: A flat 2.8 mile trail through different ages of temperate rain forest. Watch for obstacles on your way - trees may fall across the trail after a windy storm!

images.altText: Sunlight filters through green maple leaves and mossy branches.
images.title: Maples over Sam's Loop Trail
images.caption: Maples above the Sam's River Loop Trail

bodyText: A flat 2.8 mile trail through different ages of temperate rain forest. Watch for obstacles on your way - trees may fall across the trail after a windy storm!
audioDescription: Sams Loop Trailhead. 30 seconds The trailhead is located off the parking loop for the Queets Ranger Station. A brown and white wooden sign at the trailhead reads, Sams Loop Trail. Pets, weapons, vehicles and bicycles prohibited. The narrow trail begins on grass then passes between birch trees with white bark to enter the forest. Ferns and other low growing plants line each side of the trail while pines with hanging moss tower above. In places, fallen trees lay across the trail.

images.altText: A beach and cliffs at sunset.
images.caption: Sunset at Second Beach. Photo by S. Sheltren/NPS.

title: Second Beach Trailhead
listingDescription: The trailhead is located 14 miles (22.4 km) west of US 101 on La Push Road on the Quileute Indian Reservation. The trail is 0.7 miles (1.1 km), winding through forest before descending 200 feet (61 meters) to a sandy beach with seastacks and tidepools. A statement from the Quileute Tribe for visitors: "The Quileute Tribe is a Sovereign Nation which means they have their own government inside of the United States that consists of a Tribal Council. The Quileute Tribe makes dec

images.altText: A coastline with large rocky sea stacks at sunset.
images.caption: Second Beach at sunset. Photo by S. Sheltren/NPS.

bodyText:
The trailhead is located 14 miles (22.4 km) west of US 101 on La Push Road on the Quileute Indian Reservation. The trail is 0.7 miles (1.1 km), winding through forest before descending 200 feet (61 meters) to a sandy beach with seastacks and tidepools.

A statement from the Quileute Tribe for visitors:
"The Quileute Tribe is a Sovereign Nation which means they have their own government inside of the United States that consists of a Tribal Council. The Quileute Tribe makes decisions on how best to balance community and tradition, while providing visitors with enjoyable experiences. However, in an effort to avoid misunderstandings or violations of our customs, we ask that visitors follow basic procedures for conduct. Thank you for your assistance in helping us protect our sacred and ceremonial areas including the preservation of historical artifacts. Please be attentive to signage, and obey our individual tribal rules and regulations. Please respect the privacy of residential communities. Ask before photographing or recording an individual, an event, or activity. Do not pick up or remove artifacts or objects, such as sand, rocks, shells, minerals, marine growth, driftwood from beach, eagle feathers, broken pottery, etc. (This is a violation of ORDINANCE NO. 74-A-8) Burial grounds and religious ceremonies are sacred and are not to be entered. Traditionally, our people are hospitable and generous in nature. However, spiritual teachings, sacred ceremonies and burial grounds are not openly shared with the public.We are proud of our teachings, and our heritage. They have been passed to us by our ancestors, and represent thousands of years of our individual histories. Your patience and understanding of our traditions and cultures is appreciated. Thank You."

You can learn more about the community and current events from the Quileute Tribe's monthly newspaper.

First Beach is accessible by vehicles and is popular for surfing. There are nearby options for dining and accommodations managed by the Quileute Tribe. Check current conditions at this webcam.

title: Second Beach Vault Toilet

images.altText: Black and white symbol for restroom with male and female figures separated by a wall.

bodyText: Vault toilet
audioDescription: Second Beach Vault Toilet. 30 seconds At the end of a dirt path is a single user primitive vault toilet. It is a tall, unfinished plywood structure with a peaked roof and no attached door on the front facing door opening. A tarp, attached to the left side of the entrance, may be pulled across the door. A six-inch tall threshold runs across the bottom of the doorway. This toilet is not accessible to persons using wheelchairs.

title: Seven Lakes Basin Trail Junction

images.altText: A black and white symbol for trailhead with a figure of a person with a walking stick and backpack.

bodyText: Connection to backcountry routes. Consult the Wilderness Information Center for backcountry trips.
audioDescription: Seven Lakes Basin Trail Junction. 1 minute Be advised. The trail is uneven in spots with many tripping hazards due to protruding rocks and tree roots. In places, logs have been laid across the trail to create steps. At this trail junction, a wooden sign indicates the Seven Lakes Basin Loop Trail continues straight ahead. Deer Lake and Lover’s Lane are also reached by heading in this up trail direction. Sol Duc Falls Campground is down trail. Here, the trail branches off to the right where it crosses a bridge above Sol Duc Falls ending at the Falls overlook. Continuing straight ahead, the trail passes through a forest of tall pine trees and dense understory of young trees, shrubs, ferns and mosses. The river is on the right. Further along, the trail splits again. Lovers Lane Trail continues to the right toward Sol Duc Resort 3 miles up trail, and to the left, the trail leads to Deer Lake 3 miles ahead.

title: Shadow Mountain General Store

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a fuel pump.

bodyText: Gas station, general store, and RV park.
audioDescription: Shadow Mountain General Store. 1 minute The face of this long rectangular wooden building has a tall vertical, square top, false front that rises above the roof line, taller in the center with a shorter wing to each side. Attached in the center, a sign reads, Shadow Mountain General Store. A raised wooden porch runs the entire front length of the building and is covered by a roof. To the right of center is a stairway with railings and one wide step up to the porch. Directly ahead is the double glass entry door. Be advised, a boot brush is attached to the tread of the step at the base of each side railing. Windows to the right and left of the door display a variety of signs. On the far right, a large red rectangular container about three feet tall has a painting of a campfire on the front and the words, Fire Wood. Wooden plant containers line the parking lot in front of the porch and concrete parking bumpers edge the front of each parking space located directly in front of the porch. Clear access from the parking lot is directly in line with the front door. In the parking lot to the right of the store is a two-pump gas station.
managedByOrg: Shadow Mountain RV Park and General Store

title: Shi Shi Beach Trailhead
listingDescription: Shi Shi Beach and Point of Arches are among the most picturesque coastal destinations in Olympic - and the most popular! The 8-mile (12.9 km) round-trip trail begins on the Makah Reservation, and continues into Olympic National Park, so you will need two different permits. You can buy a Makah Recreation permit in the town of Neah Bay at Makah Marina, The Museum at the Makah Culture and Research Center, Washburn's General Store, Makah Mini Mart, Makah Tribal Cetner, or Hobuck

images.altText: A black and white symbol for trailhead with a figure of a person with a walking stick and backpack.

bodyText:
Currently closed to the public.

Shi Shi Beach and Point of Arches are among the most picturesque coastal destinations in Olympic - and the most popular! The 8-mile (12.9 km) round-trip trail begins on the Makah Reservation, and continues into Olympic National Park, so you will need two different permits. You can buy a Makah Recreation permit in the town of Neah Bay at Makah Marina, The Museum at the Makah Culture and Research Center, Washburn's General Store, Makah Mini Mart, Makah Tribal Cetner, or Hobuck Beach Resort.

To plan your backpacking trip to Shi Shi, contact the Olympic National Park Wilderness Information Center.. When hiking the coast, remember to be aware of tides! Certain routes will become impassible at high tide. Know your route and consult your tide table.
audioDescription: Shi Shi Beach Trailhead. Overview. 2 minutes At the entrance to the gravel parking lot, a brown and white sign reads, Shi Shi Trail Day Use Parking. Overnighters use secure venues Back .6 miles. Beyond the sign on the left is a square, gray cinderblock restroom with two brown doors that face the parking lot. The women’s room is on the left. The men’s room is on the right. In front of the doors is a three-foot-wide concrete pad with a five-inch step up. At the far end of the lot the trail enters a dense forest of tall trees. At the trailhead, a brown and white sign on the left reads, Notice. Pets, Weapons, Vehicles, and Bicycles prohibited beyond boundary of Olympic National Park 1.7 miles ahead. On the right is a sign with information about oil spill funds protecting old growth forest. About ten feet further on the right stands a covered bulletin board, its frame constructed of thick logs. Posted material includes in-depth information about the trail and the National Marine Sanctuary. Continue listening for full text of the posted information. 7 minutes. A white sign with black text reads, Oil Spill Funds Protect Old Growth Forest. In the forest behind this sign lies the Anderson Point Property, approximately 277 acres of coastal forest protected in 2006 for the benefit of a threatened seabird, the marbled murrelet. The area was set aside to ensure 200 years of protection for marbled murrelet nesting habitat as a restoration action funded by the Natural Resource Damage Assessment and Restoration Settlement. This protection was made possible through an agreement between the Makah Indian Tribe and the Tenyo Maru Natural Resource Trustees who worked to restore natural resources injured in the 1991 Tenyo Maru oil spill. Marbled murrelets are robin-sized seabirds that are protected by the State of Washington and the Federal Endangered Species Act. Marbled murrelets feed on small fish and fly inland to nest on large branches of mature conifers. One of the primary documented reasons for the decline of this seabird is the loss of nesting habitat: old growth and mature forests. Scientists estimate that 7 to 11 percent of the marbled murrelet population along Washington’s outer coast may have been killed in the 1991 Tenyo Maru oil spill. The agreement ensures that this area will be managed by the Makah Indian Tribe and excluded from their commercial land base, protecting it from commercial timber harvest and other land use activities. On the bulletin board are three posters. From left to right they read, Welcome to the Makah Tribe’s Shi Shi Beach Trail. This trail is 2 miles long and requires moderate exertion. Beach access in Olympic National Park is by steep trail. For your safety and enjoyment, please respect our few rules. This area is Makah Wilderness, don’t remove any flowers or foliage and don’t harass wildlife or take any shells or shellfish. Stay on designated trails and walkways. The sea cliffs and unmarked trails are dangerous. Supervise children closely. Don’t build fires or camp overnight anywhere on the trail. Overnight campers must obtain a backcountry permit through Olympic National Park. Pack out what you pack in. Consult tide charts for the area to guard against high tide accidents. Areas beyond Shi Shi Beach are impassable at high tide. Report vandalism to Makah Tribal law enforcement. Generations of Makah people have used this area. If you are patient and respectful, its enduring beauty will enrich and teach you too. A graphic in the right bottom corner shows a red and black bird with outstretched wings standing on the back of a black whale. The next poster reads, Welcome to Olympic Coast National Marine Sanctuary. In July 1991, the Japanese fishing vessel, Tenyo Maru and the Chinese freighter, Tuo Hai collided in heavy fog northwest of Cape Flattery, Washington. The Tenyo Maru sank immediately, releasing 475,000 gallons of oil and fuel that killed thousands of seabirds. This education panel was funded by the Tenyo Maru Natural Resource Trustees as one of a number of restoration projects designed to educate the public and to restore natural resources injured by the oil spill. The Trustees include the US Department of the Interior, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, the Makah Indian Tribe, and the State of Washington. An underwater photograph shows sunlight penetrating through green-hued water with long ribbons of kelp. Text reads, The Kelp Forests. Swaying fronds of kelp for a critical new sure habitat. Each plant may reach 70 feet in length their leaf light blades fan out across the water, providing shade in hiding places for fish and invertebrates. Look closely for sea otters eating or resting among the dense canopy of kelp just offshore in Olympic coast national Marine sanctuary. A photograph shows many birds with black heads and backs and white chests standing on the top of a rock ledge. Text reads, Murres at Risk. Common murres, the black and white seabirds seen along the coast, are signs of a healthy marine ecosystem. Murres use their wings to fly underwater in pursuit of small fish. They breed on remote islands or inaccessible cliffs, where they are protected from most predators. The young leave the nest before they can actually fly, leaping recklessly into the ocean to be raised at sea by their fathers. Because they spend so much time at sea, common murres are especially vulnerable to oil spills. Changing ocean conditions, entanglement in fishing nets, and low flying aircraft have also harmed the Washington breeding population, which has declined significantly over the last few decades. A final photograph is an aerial view of a large ship on the ocean. Text reads, Safer Maritime Shipping. The Makah Tribe and Olympic Coast National Marine Sanctuary sit at the entrance to one of the busiest shipping lanes in the world. Over 13,000 vessels pass here each year, carrying large amounts of fuel oil. Collisions or groundings threaten wildlife, fish and shellfish, their habitats, historic and cultural sites and the scenic beauty of this area. Federal, tribal and state agencies and the shipping industry work together to prevent oil spills. Larger vessels observe and Area-To-Be-Avoided, a buffer zone designed to keep ships away from especially sensitive and dangerous areas near Cape Flattery.
