The final poster has a topographic map of the west coast of Washington State along the right edge. At the top is the Strait of Juan de Fuca and labels along the coast from north to south mark specific management areas. Text reads, nearby coastal waters are part of Olympic National Marine Sanctuary, a 3300 square mile protected area administered by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. This area was designated in 1994 in recognition of its rugged character, rich marine life and vulnerable nature. Together with this landowner and other state, federal and tribal organizations, Olympic Coast National Marine Sanctuary protects marine resource supports, important scientific research and promotes compatible use and enjoyment of these resources. To enjoy your visit fully, remember the following. Don’t get trapped by the tide. Coastal headlands, stream crossings and sandy beaches can be treacherous. The water is cold and currents are strong. Hypothermia can kill within minutes. Beach logs are unstable. Don’t build fires among driftlogs. Avoid beached marine mammals. Dead or sick animals can past disease to humans. Injured animals can bight. Solitary seal pups are not orphans. Report beached marine mammals to the nearest ranger station or call 360-457-6622. Do not harass wildlife. Feeding or disturbing wild animals is illegal. Leave historical and cultural objects alone. Historic shipwreck remains and Indian artifacts and petroglyphs are protected by state and federal laws. Fish and gather shellfish only in accordance with regulations. Enjoy your visit to Olympic Coast National Marine Sanctuary.

title: Ski Patrol Ice Station
listingDescription: Seasonal - winter

images.altText: A small hut in the snow on stilts, with stairs leading to the front door.
images.caption: Photo by D. Sullivan/NPS.

bodyText: Seasonal - winter
audioDescription: This small, brown wooden building with an A-shaped peaked roof sits off the ground atop log pylons. Ten steps with handrails on both sides lead up to a covered porch landing and a red front door. A white, cross shaped sign attached to the door reads, Ski Patrol. First Aid Station. Authorized Personnel Only. To the right of the door is a window. On the front of the building above the porch a sign reading, Olympic Ski Patrol, has a light-colored cross symbol with the words, National Ski Patrol, in the center. Attached to the front of the porch to the right of the stairs is a rack for holding three rescue sleds.

title: Slough Trailhead
listingDescription: A fairly level, 0.9 mile (1.4 km) forested trail to the Quillayute River.

images.altText: A black and white symbol for trailhead with a figure of a person with a walking stick and backpack.

bodyText: A fairly level, 0.9 mile (1.4 km) forested trail to the Quillayute River.
audioDescription: Slough Trailhead. 30 seconds To the right of the trailhead is a two-legged, vertical bulletin board framed in gray with a brown and white sign attached to the top that reads, Slough Trail. Park information is tacked to the bulletin board. The trail, here, is narrow and almost immediately enters the forest.

title: Slough Trailhead at Mora Ranger Station
listingDescription: A fairly level, 0.9 mile (1.4 km) forested trail to the Quillayute River.

images.altText: A black and white symbol for trailhead with a figure of a person with a walking stick and backpack.

bodyText: A fairly level, 0.9 mile (1.4 km) forested trail to the Quillayute River.
audioDescription: Slough Trailhead. 30 seconds To the right of the trailhead is a small brown and white wooden sign attached horizontally to a post that reads, Slough Trail. Attached to the post is a no dogs permitted sign. The trail, here, is narrow and almost immediately enters the forest.

title: Smoky Bottom Trailhead
listingDescription: Starting just past the Glines Canyon Spillway Overlook (currently accessible on foot only, about 3 miles/4.8 km beyond the Madison Falls parking lot), this 1.9 mile/3 km one way trail drops into the valley above the former dam site. As you walk across riverbanks which were under water for nearly a century, you can see how the ecosystem has begun to return to a wilder, more natural state.

images.altText: A meadow full of lupine flowers, with an old dam site in the distance.
images.caption: Riverbank lupine bloom in spring along the Smoky Bottom Trail, with a view of the former Glines Canyon Dam.

bodyText: Starting just past the Glines Canyon Spillway Overlook (currently accessible on foot only, about 3 miles/4.8 km beyond the Madison Falls parking lot), this 1.9 mile/3 km one way trail drops into the valley above the former dam site. As you walk across riverbanks which were under water for nearly a century, you can see how the ecosystem has begun to return to a wilder, more natural state.
audioDescription: Smoky Bottom Trailhead. 25 seconds This trail begins as a gravel pathway with a wooden fence on the left and a hill on the right bordered by rocks. The fence and rock border end about 40 feet from the trailhead.

title: Sol Duc Amphitheater

images.altText: Black and white symbol for amphitheater with the figure of a person at the front and bench seating facing them.

bodyText: Amphitheater at Sol Duc Campground
audioDescription: Sol Duc Amphitheater. 1 minute A flat, dirt path from the parking area to the amphitheater passes through a mixed forest of pine and deciduous trees. Green moss hangs from tree branches and low growing plants carpet the forest floor. The approach to the amphitheater is from the rear where on a downward sloping surface, are nine rows of wooden bench seats, separated into three sections by aisles. In front of these benches are three more rows of benches with no aisles. At the bottom of the slope facing the benches, a grey wooden building with a flat roof and a vertical row of enclosed speakers on the right, sits atop a two-foot-high concrete stage. The center of the building is recessed toward the back with doors that open to reveal a projection screen. The projection booth is in the back of the amphitheater at the top of the slope. To the right of the stage on the ground, is a round, stone edged fire ring and a semicircular bench.

title: Sol Duc Campground
listingDescription: Operated by the Sol Duc Hot Springs ResortLocation: The Sol Duc River valley area, twelve miles (19 km) up Sol Duc Hot Springs Road off of Highway 101. Description: The Sol Duc Campground is located along the Sol Duc River, near the Sol Duc Hot Springs resort and Eagle Ranger Station. Some sites are right along the river! 82 campsites, one group site and one that is wheelchair accessible. Fire rings with grates, accessible restrooms, water, animal-proof food storage, RV dum

images.altText: A campsite with picnic table in a mossy forest setting.
images.title: Sol Duc Campground 01
images.caption: A site at Sol Duc Campground.

bodyText:
Operated by the Sol Duc Hot Springs Resort
Location: The Sol Duc River valley area, twelve miles (19 km) up Sol Duc Hot Springs Road off of Highway 101.
Description: The Sol Duc Campground is located along the Sol Duc River, near the Sol Duc Hot Springs resort and Eagle Ranger Station. Some sites are right along the river! 82 tent campsites, 17 RV campsites, one group site and one that is wheelchair accessible. Fire rings with grates, accessible restrooms, water, animal-proof food storage, RV dump station (fee).
Open: Seasonally. After the resort has closed for the season, the campground is primitive with no running water, and then closes fully for the winter after the first winter storm (when the Sol Duc Road closes until spring).
Accessibility: One wheelchair accessible campsite, accessible restrooms.
RVs: Resort-run RV park open in summer only. Sites can accommodate 21-foot RVs, and a few can accommodate 35-foot RVs.
Reservations and prices: Sites can be reserved online at recreation.gov during summer (mid-April through October). The rest of the year all sites are first come, first served.
Filling time: Online reservations for summer often fill up well in advance, so make your reservations early at recreation.gov.
audioDescription: Sol Duc Campground. 30-seconds On the right side of the road, a brown wooden sign has white text that reads, Sol Duc Campground, Loop A. An arrow points to the right. A smaller sign attached to the signpost reads, Loop B, Sol Duc Falls with an arrow pointing straight ahead.

title: Sol Duc Campground Loop B Entrance

images.altText: A campsite in the forest.

bodyText: Entrance to Loop B in Sol Duc Campground
audioDescription: Sol Duc Campground Entrance Loop B. 20 seconds On the right side of the road, a brown wooden sign has white text that reads, Sol Duc Campground, Loop B. An arrow points to the right.

title: Sol Duc Entrance

images.altText: A frosty road with sun shining through trees, illuminating mist.
images.caption: Sol Duc Road in Winter. Photo by M. Juran/NPS.

bodyText: Entrance to the Sol Duc River valley
audioDescription: Sol Duc Entrance. 2 minutes On a small grass and fern covered hill on the left side of the road is a brown rectangular wooden sign attached to two thick log posts with white text that reads, Welcome to Soleduck Valley. A smaller sign in the top right corner reads, U.S. Fee Area. To the left of the sign are three upright log posts. Attached to one is the National Park Service arrowhead logo atop a larger white arrowhead shaped base. The logo itself is shaped like an arrowhead with a scalloped edge, pointed at the bottom, with sides that widen out toward the top, before curving slightly inward, then flaring out to create a rounded top. The arrowhead is brown with etched words and images. On the right side are the words, National Park Service, in white letters. To the left, in green, a tall tree towers above smaller trees and the ground below and a section of lake in white. Behind the tree, a white outline of snowcapped mountains. Below the trees, text in white reads, Department of the Interior, and below this, is a green outline of a bison in profile facing left with a large head and shoulders and smaller hind area.

title: Sol Duc Entrance Interpretive Exhibit

images.altText: A large, open air kiosk with tall signs and a mossy roof.
images.caption: Photo by D. Sullivan/NPS.

bodyText:
A sheltered series of interpretive panels at the entrance to the Sol Duc Valley.

If you have audio description turned on (a technology sometimes used by people with low vision or blindness), the description for this site is abbreviated for time. For a full description of this site (22 minutes), follow this link.
audioDescription: NOTE: The script offers choices: it provides a very basic overview of the building and the interp panels, then provides a detailed description of each panel. The detailed option is laid out to access the panels in a clockwise direction. Sol Duc Interpretive Exhibit. Overview 1 minute At the far-right edge of the parking lot, a path leads to a roof covered, open-sided wooden structure supported along each side by log posts. Large interpretive panels are attached between these log posts. Additional panels are attached to log posts inside the building. There are a total of nine panels titled, 1. Welcome to Sol Duc; 2. Gateway to the Wilderness; 3. Plant Identification; 4. A Visit to the Original Sol Duc Resort; 5. Tears of the Dragon: geology of the Sol Duc Springs; 6. Sol Duc River: the architect; 7. Soleduck Valley: a blending of two forest communities; 8. Spotting Sol Duc Wildlife; and 9. Explore Spectacular Sol Duc Valley. Continue listening to hear a detailed description of each Interpretive panel. 30-minutes at the link.

title: Sol Duc Entrance Station
listingDescription: Open seasonally only.

images.altText: Black and white symbol for entrance station with a narrow booth and a sign.

bodyText: Open seasonally only.
audioDescription: Sol Duc Entrance Station. 2 minutes The entrance station is a small light grey wooden building with a high-pitched roof, a window on each side, and an American flag. The building sits in the center of the road on a rectangular island placing both the building and island parallel to the roadway. Vehicles approach the long side of the building with a sliding glass window where park staff assists with entrance fees and park passes. A sign on the station has the National Park Service arrowhead logo and the text, U.S. Fee Area. Another sign reads, Credit or debit cards preferred. A large upright sign in front of the building reads: Olympic National Park Entrance Fees-Valid 7-days with receipt Private Vehicle, 30 dollars Bicycles and Walk-ins per person, 15 dollars Motorcycles, 25 dollars Annual Passes - Photo ID required Interagency including all National Parks, 80 dollars Olympic National Park, 55 dollars Senior Annual, 62 years and older, 20 dollars Active U.S. Military, free Lifetime Passes - U.S. Citizens and Permanent Residents Senior Lifetime, 62 years and older, 80 dollars Access, permanently disabled, free Near the sliding glass window, a sign reads, Attention. Overnight camping in an automobile or recreational vehicle is allowed only in the Sol Duc Hot Springs resort RV Court by reservation or may be available in the Sol Duc Campground Loops on a first come first served basis. Thank you for your compliance.

title: Sol Duc Falls

images.altText: A large waterfall.

bodyText: One of the most popular waterfalls in the park. Always stay on designated trails and viewing areas - fences are there for your safety!
audioDescription: Sol Duc Falls. 2 minutes Be advised. The trail to the falls is uneven in spots from protruding rocks and tree roots, and in some areas, there are log, stone, and concrete steps. A wooden bridge with side rails crosses the falls. Upriver is on the left. In the distance, frothy white-water flows over rocks toward the bridge through a forest of green pine trees and yellow-green foliage growing along the riverbanks. Near the bridge, two boulders at the top of a rocky ledge, separate the river into three fingers of water that cascade over the edge of a steep gorge to the river below. Downriver, on the right, the narrow, deep gorge with its sides covered in lush green moss, ferns and other leafy plants, opens up a bit wider as the clear water flattens out briefly before another section of cascades begins. Along the steep banks are tall rock faces and above, a dense forest of green pines. Continuing across the bridge, the trail turns left. Railings span the river side of the trail. A bench is on the right. Then, as the trail slightly ascends, a series of uneven concrete steps and an uneven, rocky step section leads to an area that overlooks a section of the river. A bench is located on the right. This is the end of the trail. Traveling back over the bridge to the main trail, a brown wooden directional sign at the end of the bridge indicates that Seven Lakes Basin Loop Trail, Deer Lake, and Lover’s Lane are to the right and Sol Duc Falls Campground is to the left.

title: Sol Duc Falls Trail
listingDescription: Perhaps the most picturesque waterfall in Olympic, Sol Duc Falls is a treat - a big reward for a fairly easy hike. From the parking lot at the end of the road, the walk through old-growth forest to cascading Sol Duc Falls is just .8 of a mile (1.3 km) and relatively level. Please enjoy the falls from the designated viewing areas, so you don't take an unexpected swim!

images.altText: A steep waterfall between canyon walls covered in greenery.
images.caption: Sol Duc Falls.

bodyText: Perhaps the most picturesque waterfall in Olympic, Sol Duc Falls is a treat - a big reward for a fairly easy hike. From the parking lot at the end of the road, the walk through old-growth forest to cascading Sol Duc Falls is just .8 of a mile (1.3 km) and relatively level. Please enjoy the falls from the designated viewing areas, so you don't take an unexpected swim!
audioDescription: Sol Duc Falls Trailhead. Overview. 2 minutes Be advised, the trail surface may be uneven with tripping hazards of rocks and tree roots. In places, log steps span the width of the trail. Parking for the trailhead is along the entrance road that loops around a grassy picnic area with tables. An accessible restroom with vault toilets is located on the edge of the roadway before the road begins to loop. The women’s single stall restroom is on the left, and the men’s single stall restroom is on the right. The trailhead is at the top of the loop. Trash and recycling bins are located here on the right. On the right and left sides of the trailhead are roof covered kiosks with information about planning and preparing for your hike and how to protect the wilderness. Continue listening for a description of the kiosk panels. 7 minutes. Beginning with the kiosk on the left and the panel on the left, a text header across the top has white and green lettering on a black background that reads, Your first 3 steps into Wilderness. The remainder of the panel is an image of a meadow with pink flowers in the foreground and layers of snowcapped mountains in the background. In the bottom left corner, text in a tan graphic overlay, reads: When you enter the Olympic Wilderness, you’re in for a wild time. Six hundred miles of trails link you to sea and sky. Are you hiking the coast, crossing creeks through old-growth forest or ascending mile-high peaks? Whatever your destination, Your First 3 Steps into Wilderness can lead to success or disaster. Attentive trip planning and preparation will help protect you and the future of wilderness. Step 1. Plan. Step 2 Prepare. Step 3 Protect The header on the second panel reads, Step 1. Plan. Below, are two columns of text. On the left is parkwide planning information. On the right, is planning information pertaining to Sol Duc. Text in the Parkwide column reads: Before your trip, contact the park’s Wilderness Information Center or area ranger station for safety information, permits and regulations. Limit your group size to twelve. Leave your trip itinerary, including date of return, with someone who expects you back. Observe all regulations that restrict pets, weapons, and wheeled vehicles and devices. Store edibles, garbage and scented items in hard-sided food containers 24 hours a day to protect yourself and wildlife. To their detriment, wild animals can become accustomed to human food. Text in the Sol Duc column reads: To protect fragile vegetation and the value of solitude, quotas restrict number and size of camping parties in this area. Contact the Wilderness Information Center for reservations and permits. Carry a topographic map and compass and know how to use them. Snow is common at higher elevations through midsummer. Use good route-finding and personal safety skills. Stock regulations help protect you, your animals and the wilderness. Above 3500 feet, stay on trails and only use designated stock camps. Pack non-viable pellets or rolled grain. Observe all other regulations. Below the text, is a Trail Grade Profile illustrating the elevation for locations along the Sol Duc trail. Sol Duc Falls is at 2,000 feet, Heart Lake is a bit below 5,000 feet, and High Divide is a bit above 5,000 feet. A map at the bottom shows the trail system in the Sol Duc area with the text, You Are Here. Three small photographs are inset into the map. The first, an orange lily with black spots, then a brown fawn with white spots lays on rocky ground surrounded by green plants, and a high mountain view with tall green pine trees and mountain peaks in the distance. Moving to the second kiosk on the right side of the trail, the header on the first panel reads, Step 2. Prepare. In the center of the panel is an image of white water flowing down a rocky streambed. Above the image, text reads: Parkwide. Carry backcountry essentials including extra food, extra warm-when-wet clothing, topographic map, compass, flashlight and extra batteries, sunglasses and sunscreen, pocketknife, matches in waterproof container, candle or Firestarter and first aid kit. Prepare for hazards of weather, terrain, water crossing and wildlife. Prevent hypothermia in cool, wet weather by wearing wool and synthetic layers, a warm hat and rain gear. Boil, filter or chemically treat all drinking water to avoid infection by Giardia, a microscopic intestinal parasite. Below the image, text reads: Sol Duc. Always check the weather forecast to help you prepare for the unexpected. Check with a ranger for snow and trail conditions prior to every outing. Electronics should not replace basic gear and skill. Cell phones, GPS units and other electronic devices might not work, especially in lower valleys and forested areas. Repackage food prior to your trip to reduce pack weight and litter, and to lessen the risk of problems with animals. The header on the second panel reads, Step 3. Protect. Below, an image of a meadow with red flowers, a blue mountain lake, and mountains in the distance fills one third of the panel on the right. On the left, black text on a tan background, reads: Parkwide. Leave no trace of your stay. Think about how your actions impact wildlife, vegetation and visitors. Use established campsites along the trail system. If hiking cross-country, camp on durable surfaces. Observe revegetation closures to protect plants. Minimize use of fire. Pack out everything you pack in. Properly dispose of human waste. Use privies where available or dig catholes at least 200 feet from campsites and water. Do not urinate in composting or vault toilets. Wash your dishes and yourself away from water sources. Use small amounts of biodegradable soap or none at all. Leave natural objects and cultural artifacts where are you find them to help protect this irreplaceable wilderness. Below the text are two photographs, one, a photograph of a black bear eating berries in a meadow, and a close up of a blue berry hanging from red leaves. Text continues: Sol Duc. Never feed wildlife for their health and your safety. Day hikers should keep their food within reach and secure from wildlife. Protect vegetation. Avoid walking on or disturbing plants, especially near trails, water or campsites. Minimize your space by sharing tents. Use a few big tents, not many small ones. Use a stove to eliminate impacts of fire and wood gathering. Campfires are not permitted above 3500 feet in elevation. If you build a fire at lower elevations, keep it small and use an existing fire ring. Gather, don’t cut, only small pieces of wood. Be sure your fire is out cold as winds can reignite fires. Up trail from the kiosks on the right is a bulletin board with park information pertaining to Wilderness regulations, Stock use in the Sol Duc Area, ways to tread lightly, backcountry safety, Day Hikes at Sol Duc, Pet Regulations, fishing regulations, and hypothermia. Other notices include alerts about cougars, mountain goats, and bears in the area; what to do in an emergency, contact a ranger or dial 911; an alert that thefts have occurred in the area; and the nearest services. In the center of the bulletin board is a map of the area. Beyond the bulletin board along the trail are three brown wooden signs with text in white. The first sign, on the left reads: Soleduck Trail. Soleduck Falls one-eighth mile. Deer Lake 4 miles. Lunch Lake via Deer Lake 8 miles, Soleduck Park via Soleduck River Trail 8 miles. The second sign on the right reads: No pets, weapons, or vehicles. The third sign on the right reads: Wilderness camping permits and bear cannisters required for all overnight trips.

title: Sol Duc Hot Springs Entrance

images.altText: Cars and cabins, with a forested mountain in the background.
images.title: Cabins at Sol Duc Resort
images.caption: Cabins at Sol Duc Hot Springs Resort.

bodyText: Entrance to Sol Duc Hot Springs Resort.
audioDescription: Sol Duc Hot Springs Entrance. 15 seconds Attached to four log posts is a brown rectangular sign with white text that reads, Sol Duc Hot Springs. In between the words, Sol and Duc, is a blue and white graphic representation of swirling water.

title: Sol Duc Hot Springs Resort
listingDescription:
The concession-operated Sol Duc Hot Springs Resort has lodging and an RV campground; you can make reservations by calling 888-896-3818. The resort features three hot mineral pools, a swimming pool, dining room, snack bar, massage services, and a gift shop. The resort is open from late March through mid-October.
www.olympicnationalparks.com/lodging/sol-duc-hot-springs-resort

images.altText: A wooden lodge building
images.title: Sol Duc Hot Springs Resort
images.caption: Sol Duc Hot Springs Resort

bodyText: The concession-operated Sol Duc Hot Springs Resort has lodging and an RV campground; you can make reservations by calling 888-896-3818. The resort features three hot mineral pools, a swimming pool, dining room, snack bar, massage services, and a gift shop. The resort is open from late March through mid-October.
audioDescription: Sol Duc Hot Springs. 1 minute In the center section of this long brown rectangular wooden building is an A-shaped peaked roof with a second, lower, A-shaped peaked roof extending outward from the building covering the entrance area. A white sign attached to a beam at the front of the entry roof reads, Welcome to Sol Duc Hot Springs. In between the words, Sol and Duc, is a blue and white graphic representation of swirling water. From road level, the entrance area has a flat concrete walkway with benches and planter boxes along the left and right sides. Be advised, there may be a two-foot-tall A-frame sign standing in the middle of the walkway. The walkway ends at seven steps leading up to the double front doors. A gift shop is just inside the door, and straight through to the back of the building is a restaurant. Behind the building are circular hot spring pools and a large rectangular pool.

title: Sol Duc RV Dump Station

images.altText: A black and white symbol of an RV dumping waste.

bodyText: Dump station for Sol Duc Hot Springs Resort RV Park
audioDescription: Sol Duc RV Dump Station. 30 seconds A brown and white sign attached to a post reads, RV Septic Dump Station. $10 per use. $5 with Interagency Senior or Access Pass. Not included in camping fee. Attached below this sign is a white paper sign with black typed text that reads, Please pay dump fee at Eagle Ranger Station. To the left of the signs is a water hose and a concrete pad with a drain where RV sewage is dumped.

title: Sol Duc RV Park

images.altText: Cars and cabins, with a forested mountain in the background.
images.title: Cabins at Sol Duc Resort
images.caption: Cabins at Sol Duc Hot Springs Resort.

bodyText: Managed by Sol Duc Hot Springs Resort.
audioDescription: Sol Duc RV Park. 30 seconds A tan sign with black text at the entrance to the RV Park reads, Sol Duc Hot Springs Resort R.V. Park. All use is by reservation only. Please register at the lodge. No tent camping. RV camp spots are located along the edges of a wide gravel lot. Water, garbage receptacles, a restroom, and a dump station are in the vicinity.

title: Sol Duc Restrooms and Campground Registration - Loop A

images.altText: Black and white symbol for restroom with male and female figures separated by a wall.

bodyText: Campground registration and restroom for Loop A of Sol Duc Campground
audioDescription: Sol Duc Campground Registration Loop A. 1 minute Here, along the loop road is a roof-covered bulletin board with information about the campground and park. On the left is the campground registration board, a vertical framed box divided into rows of individual square sections. Each square is numbered and corresponds to a campsite. Each row is covered by a hard, clear plastic strip with a slot for dropping one of two registration payment receipts into an individual square. To the left of the board is a brown box with a lid holding campground registration envelopes. Standing in front of the board in the center is a 3-foot-tall cannister for depositing the envelope with payment. On the face of the cannister, at the top, is a slot for slipping in the envelope.

title: Sol Duc Restrooms and Campground Registration - Loop B

images.altText: Black and white symbol for restroom with male and female figures separated by a wall.

bodyText: Campground registration and restroom for Sol Duc Campground Loop B
audioDescription: Sol Duc Campground Registration Loop B. 2 minutes At the edge of the roadway in front of the restroom is a roof-covered 2-sided bulletin board with information about the campground and park. On the front, attached on the left side, is the campground registration board, a vertical framed box divided into rows of individual square sections. Each square is numbered and corresponds to a campsite. Each row is covered by a hard, clear plastic strip with a slot for dropping one of two registration payment receipts into an individual square. A brown lidded box holding campground registration envelopes is to the left of the board. Standing alone to the left is a 3-foot-tall cannister for depositing the envelope with payment. On the face of the cannister, at the top, is the slot for slipping in the envelope. A green and white sign attached to the left leg of the bulletin board frame reads, All pets must be on a leash. Clean up after your pet. Posted notices provide information about campground regulations, pet regulations, firewood, bear warnings, and wildlife, food, and your safety. A map of the Sol Duc area is also posted here. On the back side of the bulletin board is information about wilderness regulations, backcountry safety, bear awareness, cougars, and park preservation. Emergency information is provided. Contact a ranger or dial 911 in an emergency. Other notices include no fireworks, day hikes at Sol Duc, fee checklist, and fishing regulations. Behind the bulletin board and up a slight rise is a rectangular restroom building with entrance doors on each side. A dirt path leads to the women’s room on the left and a dirt path leads to the men’s room on the right.

title: Sol Duc River View Picnic Area
listingDescription: Pause for a picnic, or just to look down over the rushing waters of the Sol Duc River.

images.altText: An upright wayside sign and a view of a river.
images.caption: River views at the picnic area. Photo by D. Sullivan/NPS.

bodyText: Pause for a picnic, or just to look down over the rushing waters of the Sol Duc River.
audioDescription: Picnic Area. 20 seconds Parallel to the parking lot is a long narrow grassy area where picnic tables sit atop square, ground level gravel pads outlined by in-ground flat wooden timbers. Be advised, the back edge of the grassy area slopes downward, and the edge of the parking lot, adjacent to the grassy area, is lined with above ground timbers.

title: South Beach Access Trailhead

images.altText: A black and white symbol for trailhead with a figure of a person with a walking stick and backpack.

bodyText: Trail to beach from South Beach Campground.
audioDescription: Beach Access Trailhead. 1 minute At the edge of the parking area is a brown and white wooden sign on a post with an upward pointing arrow and the text, Beach Trail. Below this sign is a blue and white metal sign that reads, Pets must be on leash at all times. A black graphic of a dog on a leash is below the text. A final sign indicates fireworks are prohibited. The gravel trail down to the beach has wooden timber steps along its route and may be rocky.

title: South Beach Restroom and Campground Registration

images.altText: Black and white symbol for restroom with male and female figures separated by a wall.

bodyText: Restroom and campground registration for South Beach Campground.
audioDescription: Campground Registration. 30 seconds Attached on the stone wall of the restroom building to the right of the men’s room entrance is the campground registration board, a horizontal framed box divided into rows of individual square sections. Each square is numbered and corresponds to a campsite. Each row is covered by a hard, clear plastic strip with a slot for dropping one of two registration payment receipts into an individual square. To the right of the board, is a brown box with a lid holding campground registration envelopes. Standing below the brown box is a thin, 3-foot-tall concrete box where payment envelopes are deposited.

title: South Shore Quinault Ranger Station - USFS - NPS
listingDescription: Because Lake Quinault is surrounded by both National Park and National Forest land, this facility is operated jointly by the National Park Service and U.S. Forest Service. Open daily in summer, weekdays only the rest of the year. Information, wilderness permits and bear canisters (summer only).

images.altText: A multi-story building and parking lot
images.title: Quinault South Shore Ranger Station
images.caption: The Quinault South Shore USFS-NPS Ranger Station

bodyText: Because Lake Quinault is surrounded by both National Park and National Forest land, this facility is operated jointly by the National Park Service and U.S. Forest Service. Open daily in summer, weekdays only the rest of the year. Information, wilderness permits and bear canisters (summer only).
audioDescription: Quinault Ranger Station - USFS- NPS. 30 seconds This two-story rectangular wooden yellow building with windows on each level faces the parking lot. The glass entrance door is in the center under a low roof that wraps around the right side of the building. A brown and white wooden sign to the left of the door reads, Quinault Ranger District, Olympic National Forest. Inside are staffed visitor service desks for the Forest Service and the National Park Service. Free brochures, flyers, and other park and area information are available. There is a small sales area with postcards, books, and other items.

title: Spruce Burl Trailhead

images.altText: A trail through a forest. The trees have large round protrusions, or burls, in their bark.
images.title: Spruce Burl Trail
images.caption: Spruce Burl Trail

bodyText:
A branch of the Beach 1 trail.
 

Full Accessibility Description


Length: 960 feet
Surface Type: Compacted gravel
Typical Trail Width: 2 feet
Typical Running Slope: Under 5%
Typical Cross Slope: Under 3%
Description: As the name suggests, the Spruce Burl Trail navigates through a forest of spruce trees with large burls. It is a loop trail that starts and ends on the Beach 1 Trail. There are parking pullouts on both the east and west side of the highway for Beach 1. If parking on the east side of the highway, exercise extreme caution when crossing the highway, as the speed limit is 55 mph and there is no crosswalk.

The trail starts at the edge of the west-side pullout and proceeds into the forest. All grades on this hike are under 5%. Proceed up the Beach 1 Trail for 115 feet. There is a sign for the Spruce Burl Trail at the intersection. Turn right to follow the trail. At 445 feet, there is a short, narrow bridge. On the ocean (west) side of the loop, grasses and berry vines often grow densely along the trail. There are also numerous roots crossing the trail, some on the west side 8-10 inches. At 565 feet, the trail meets the Beach 1 Trail. Turn left to return to the parking area. It is 165 feet back to the first intersection, and another 115 feet from there to the parking area.
audioDescription: Spruce Burl Trailhead. 30 seconds Branching off the Beach 1 trail to the right is the Spruce Burl Trail. It begins as a narrow trail with low growing plants along each edge, then opens wide as it reaches an area of spruce trees with burls growing on their trunks. The burls are spherical woody growths, some small and growing alone, and some larger and growing in masses. Tree bark covers the burls. On the left, a 10-foot-long spur off the trail leads to the intertwined roots of two spruce trees where you can feel the roundness and rough bark of several burls growing on the roots.

title: Spruce Nature Trail
listingDescription: Another short rain forest loop, the Spruce Nature Trail packs incredible variety into just 1.2 miles (1.9 km). This is a great place to look for the fascinating phenomenon known as "nurse logs" - fallen trees which provide a place for new seedlings to grow. You can see them at every stage, from the new-fallen log with brand new baby trees sprouting on it to the rows of centuries-old trees whose "nurse log" has long since rotted away, leaving them standing in a perfectly strai

images.altText: A trail through a green forest, a small wayside sign off to one side.
images.title: Spruce Nature Trail
images.caption: Spruce Nature Trail

bodyText:
A short rain forest loop, the Spruce Nature Trail packs incredible variety into just 1.2 miles (1.9 km). This is a great place to look for the fascinating phenomenon known as "nurse logs" - fallen trees which provide a place for new seedlings to grow. You can see them at every stage, from the new-fallen log with brand new baby trees sprouting on it to the rows of centuries-old trees whose "nurse log" has long since rotted away, leaving them standing in a perfectly straight line, called a colonnade. The trail also winds past the Hoh River, with its unique pale blue glacial waters flowing down from Mount Olympus to the Pacific.
 

Full Accessibility Description


Length: 6,645 feet, 1.25 miles; Loop: 6,040 feet, 1.14 miles
Surface Type: Compacted gravel
Typical Trail Width: First 350 feet: 6 feet; 350-720: 3 feet; 720-6,040 feet: 2-3 feet
Typical Running Slope: First 400 feet: under 5%; remainder fluctuating uphill and downhill with numerous steep grades typically less than 50 feet in length ranging from 7-25%, interspersed with gentle stretches
Typical Cross Slope: Less than 2%
Elevation Gain/Loss: Less than 65 feet
Accessible Parking: Van-accessible parking immediately across from park information boards
Description: The Hoh parking area has five van-accessible parking spaces. From the parking area, cross the crosswalk and turn right to reach the trailhead where several boards display information about the area. From the information boards, proceed forward for 310 feet to an intersection. There is a bench on the left at 200 feet. At the intersection, go to the right. At 350 feet cross the 30-foot bridge. The trail narrows from 6 feet to 3 feet after the bridge. From 400 to 455 feet, the trail climbs at 14-17% grade to another intersection. The Hoh River Trail is to the left. Proceed to the right for the Spruce Nature Trail. Continue downhill for 50 feet at 8-11% grade, followed by 30 feet of uphill at 6-8% to reach the start of the loop trail. Turn left and continue uphill at 14-17% grade incline. At 640 feet, there is a staircase with nine stairs. The steps are 4-6 inches high with long treads between, sloping upward at 8-11%. At the top of the staircase, continue uphill at a maximum grade of 10% for 750 feet, completing the longest continuous climb of the trail. After this point, the trail is a series of ups and downs with more level sections in between, before meeting back at the beginning intersection to complete the loop.
audioDescription: Spruce Trailhead. 45 seconds At a fork in the Hoh River Trail, a brown and white sign on the right side of the trail has a right pointing arrow and reads: Spruce Trail and Hoh River Trail. Another sign points left for the Hall of Mosses trail. Moving to the right, the trail crosses a wooden plank bridge with railings. In places the trail becomes narrow and rocky and with an uphill section leading to another fork in the trail. The Spruce Trail continues to the right and the Hoh River Trail is to the left. The trail passes through a lush rain forest with trees of varying ages, some covered in hanging moss. Ferns line the trail creating walls of green in places, and fallen, decaying trees are covered with ferns and mosses.

title: Spruce Railroad Trailhead - Camp David Jr Road
listingDescription: Accessed from either the East Beach Road or Camp David Junior Road, the Spruce Railroad Trail hugs the shore of Lake Crescent for 4 miles (6.4 km) along an old railroad route. As a continuation of the Olympic Discovery Trail, bicycles and pets are permitted on this trail.

images.altText: A hiker with a dog on a leash crosses a bridge beside a lake.
images.caption: Leashed pets are allowed on a few trails in Olympic, including Spruce Railroad Trail! Photo by C. Bubar/NPS.

bodyText:
1/3/2024: Trail closed three miles from trailhead due to rockslide.

Accessed from either the East Beach Road or Camp David Junior Road, the Spruce Railroad Trail hugs the shore of Lake Crescent for 4 miles (6.4 km) along an old railroad route. As a continuation of the Olympic Discovery Trail, bicycles and pets are permitted on this trail.
audioDescription: Spruce Railroad Trailhead. 90 seconds The trail may be accessed from an upper parking area and a parallel, lower parking area. From the upper area, proceed straight ahead on the paved path. At the trailhead on the left, a brown and white sign reads: Spruce Railroad Trail. A green and black sign below reads, Olympic Discovery Trail. Pathway to the Pacific. A sign on the right side of the trail reads: Next restroom 4 miles. No restroom at Devil’s Punch Bowl. Dogs on leash only. Pick up after pets. Unlit tunnel ahead. A sign below has a diagram that explains trail courtesy. Bikes yield to hikers and horses. Hikers yield to horses. From the lower parking area, the trail begins at the far end where a tall, wooden framed bulletin board stands. A brown sign attached at the top has white text that reads, Spruce R.R. Trail. Posted notices provide trail and fishing regulations, how to help preserve your park, and steps to take in an emergency. Contact a ranger or dial 911. Beyond the bulletin board, the trail climbs a steep slope where it joins the main paved trail. The trail passes through a forest of tall pine trees.

title: Spruce Railroad Trailhead - East
listingDescription: Accessed from either the East Beach Road or Camp David Junior Road, the Spruce Railroad Trail hugs the shore of Lake Crescent for 4 miles (6.4 km) along an old railroad route. As a continuation of the Olympic Discovery Trail, bicycles and pets are permitted on this trail.

images.altText: A lake shoreline, seen from the water.
images.caption: The "Devil's Punchbowl" bridge. Photo by M. Juran/NPS.

bodyText:
1/3/2024: Trail closed one mile from trailhead due to rockslide.

Accessed from either the East Beach Road or Camp David Junior Road, the Spruce Railroad Trail hugs the shore of Lake Crescent for 4 miles (6.4 km) along an old railroad route. As a continuation of the Olympic Discovery Trail, bicycles and pets are permitted on this trail.
audioDescription: Spruce Railroad Trailhead. 2 minutes A brown and white sign on the right side of the road leading to the trailhead reads, Spruce Railroad Trail Parking. In the parking area is an all gender, single stall, accessible restroom with a vault toilet. Entry is on the left front side of the building. Garbage bins are in front of the restroom on the right. Across the gravel pathway at the trailhead stand three, vertical, yellow poles spaced about five feet apart. A brown and white sign on the left side of the trail reads, Warning. Low level light in tunnel. Stay to the right. Use reflective devices. Walk bicycles through tunnel. About five feet beyond the warning sign, also on the left, is a covered bulletin board with posted park information. One notice reads: The Spruce Railroad Trail connects the North Shore and Lyre River trailheads. The trail runs on or next to the World War 1 Spruce Railroad bed and offers excellent views of Lake Crescent. From the west end, a six-and-a-half-mile paved extension leads farther west to Highway 101. This section is wheelchair accessible. Bicycles, horses and dogs are allowed on this trail. Dogs must be on leash at all times. Motorcycles and other motor vehicles are not allowed. Bicyclists must ride in control and at a safe speed. Watch out for ticks and poison ivy. This is a day use area only. Other notices include information about backcountry safety, a warning about poison oak, and fishing regulations.

title: Staircase Amphitheater

images.altText: Black and white symbol for amphitheater with the figure of a person at the front and bench seating facing them.

bodyText: Amphitheater
audioDescription: Amphitheatre. 30 seconds The trail from the parking area is uphill with switchbacks and is uneven in places. Lights are located along the trail. The amphitheater has six rows of wooden benches on each side of a center aisle facing a tall, roof covered, white projection screen located approximately 15 feet in front of the first row of benches. The ground surface in the amphitheater slopes downward and is rocky in places. The projection booth is located uphill behind the benches.

title: Staircase Big Cedar Tree

images.altText: A massive fallen tree
images.title: Staircase Big Cedar Tree
images.caption: Staircase Big Cedar Tree

bodyText:
A small spur off of the main Staircase Rapids Loop trail leads to the impressive mass of the fallen Big Cedar Tree.
 
 

Full Accessibility Description


Length: 1,100 feet, .2 miles
Surface Type: Compacted gravel
Typical Trail Width: 6-8 feet
Typical Running Slope: Under 5%
Typical Cross Slope: Less than 2%, trail is crowned (higher in the middle than on the edges)
Accessible Parking: Van-accessible parking in parking area
Description: From the Staircase parking area, the trailhead is located directly across the bridge over the Skokomish River. From the trailhead sign, the 8-foot-wide compacted gravel trail dips down and back up in the first 140 feet in which 2 sections under 20 feet reach 8% grade. From here, the trail continues at grades under 5%. At 690 feet, there is an intersection with the Big Cedar Trail, turning left to reach the big cedar.

The trail narrows to six feet at the intersection, continuing for 410 feet to reach a fallen western red cedar tree 14 feet in diameter. There is also a smaller, but still impressively large living cedar at the end of the trail.
audioDescription: Big Cedar Tree. 1 minute Along the mostly flat gravel Big Cedar Nature Trail in a forest of dense trees and lush ferns is a fallen Western Red Cedar tree. The root end of the tree is adjacent to the pathway while the trunk of the tree extends deep into the forest. A brown, wooden sign with inscribed black letters reads, Western Red Cedar. Thuja Plicata. Diameter, 14-feet What remains of the root ball is wider than the tree trunk by about 10 feet. The ball itself is a tangle of weathered silver grey, woody roots, some slender, some thick. Some with pointed ends, some with blunt ends. Here and there, ferns and moss grow upon the roots. The weathered tree trunk is also silver grey with patches of moss and fern growing on its ridged surface. Behind the root ball is a wooden fence, indicating the edge of the pathway surface.

title: Staircase Campground Restroom A

images.altText: Black and white symbol for restroom with male and female figures separated by a wall.

bodyText: Restroom.
audioDescription: Restroom. 30 seconds In the campground along the loop road is a gray rectangular restroom building with a brown metal roof and yellow framed windows. Large boulders sit in front of the building and near each side. The restroom entrance doors are located on each short side of the building behind privacy walls. The women’s room is on the left and the men’s room is on the right. A water station is located on the right near the men’s room. Behind the restroom is an accessible family restroom, a roof covered bulletin board with campground and park information, and a brown metal food storage locker. In front of the restroom near the road is another food storage locker.

title: Staircase Campground Restroom B

images.altText: Black and white symbol for restroom with male and female figures separated by a wall.

bodyText: Restroom.
audioDescription: Restroom. 30 seconds In the campground along the loop road is a brown rectangular restroom building with a wood-shingled roof and yellow framed windows. The restroom entrance doors are located on each short side of the building behind privacy walls. The women’s room is on the right and the men’s room is on the left. A water station is located near the men’s room and a brown metal food storage locker is located near the women’s room.

title: Staircase Entrance Sign

images.altText: A sign reads "Olympic National Park," features the arrowhead logo of the National Park Service.
images.title: Staircase Entrance Sign
images.caption: Staircase Entrance Sign

bodyText: Entrance sign
audioDescription: Staircase Entrance Sign. 90 seconds Suspended from a horizontal log, supported on either end by vertical logs, is a large dark brown sign with white text that reads, Olympic National Park. In the lower right corner is the National Park Service arrowhead logo atop a larger white arrowhead shaped base. The logo itself is shaped like an arrowhead with a scalloped edge, pointed at the bottom, with sides that widen out toward the top, before curving slightly inward, then flaring out to create a rounded top. The arrowhead is brown with etched words and images. On the right side are the words, National Park Service, in white letters. To the left, in green, a tall tree towers above smaller trees and the ground below and a section of lake in white. Behind the tree, a white outline of snowcapped mountains. Below the trees, text in white reads, Department of the Interior, and below this, an outline of a bison in profile facing left with a large head and shoulders and smaller hind area. The sign’s log support structure sits atop a stone platform. The area in front of the platform is flat.

title: Staircase Entrance Station
listingDescription: Ranger present during the summer season.

images.altText: Black and white symbol for entrance station with a narrow booth and a sign.

bodyText: Ranger present during the summer season.
audioDescription: Staircase Entrance Station. 2 minutes The entrance station is a small light gray building with a high-pitched roof, windows on all sides, and an American flag. The building sits in the center of a rectangular island placing both the building and island parallel to the roadway. Vehicles approach the long side of the building with a sliding glass window where a Park Ranger assists with entrance fees and park passes. A sign on the station reads, Debit or Credit only and if using a Pass, ID is required. A sign at the front edge of the island reads: Olympic National Park Entrance Fees-Valid 7-days with receipt Private Vehicle, 30 dollars Bicycles and Walk-ins per person, 15 dollars Motorcycles, 25 dollars Annual Passes - Photo ID required Interagency including all National Parks, 80 dollars Olympic National Park, 55 dollars Senior Annual, 62 years and older, 20 dollars Active U.S. Military, free Lifetime Passes - U.S. Citizens and Permanent Residents Senior Lifetime, 62 years and older, 80 dollars Access, permanently disabled, free Other signs read: Pets not permitted on trails. Permitted in designated areas only on leash at all times. Please keep your receipt Marijuana prohibited

title: Staircase Information Panel

images.altText: A roofed bulletin board with informational signs attached.
images.caption: Photo by E. Goode/NPS

bodyText: Informational bulletin board
audioDescription: Staircase Information. 2 minutes At the entrance to the Staircase Campground is a roof covered bulletin board on the right, just off the road. On the left front is the campground registration board, a vertical box with 64 square sections in eight rows of eight. Each square is numbered and corresponds to an individual campsite. Each row is covered by a hard, clear plastic strip with a slot for dropping one of two registration payment receipts into an individual square. Low and to the right of the registration board are two brown boxes with lids holding campground registration envelopes. The 3-foot-tall metal cannister for depositing an envelope with payment stands on the right. On the face of the cannister, at the top, is a slot for slipping in the envelope. Above the boxes of envelopes is posted information regarding where to camp, quiet hours, food storage, campfires and wood, pet regulations, what fees are required, a ban on fireworks, and firearms and weapons. Fishing regulations are also posted stating the fishing season dates and license information. On the opposite side of the bulletin board are additional posts about river safety, campfire wood, phone locations, nearest services, a map of the area, and information about hiking trails. To the left of the bulletin board is a brown and white welcome sign with a list of registration instructions. Next to this sign, a directional sign with text and an upward pointing arrow that reads, Restrooms and Campground. To the right of the bulletin board is an all gender, single stall, accessible restroom building with a vault toilet on a concrete pad. Enter on the right front side beneath an open alcove. The door to the restroom is on the left.

title: Staircase Overflow Parking

images.altText: A black square with a white letter "P" inside it, a symbol to indicate parking.

bodyText: Staircase Overflow Parking
audioDescription: Overflow Parking. 20 seconds This flat paved parking lot with white lines designating individual parking spaces is surrounded by a forest of tall pine trees.

title: Staircase Picnic Area - North of Skokomish Bridge

images.altText: A picnic table in the forest with a view of a river and bridge.
images.caption: Photo by E. Goode/NPS

bodyText: Enjoy a picnic overlooking the North Fork of the Skokomish River.
audioDescription: Staircase Picnic Area. 30 seconds Across the bridge on the right is a sign with a right pointing arrow that reads: Picnic Area. Large rocks mark the start of the path to the picnic area. The path along the river is rocky and uneven and in places comes close to the riverbank on the right. The picnic area has a table and metal pedestal grill and is surrounded by green ferns and tall pine trees with hanging moss. There is a steep drop off to the river at the edge of the picnic area.

title: Staircase Picnic Area - South of Skokomish Bridge

images.altText: A picnic table in the forest beside a river
images.caption: Photo by C. Bubar/NPS

bodyText: Enjoy a lovely riverside picnic beside the North Fork of the Skokomish River.
audioDescription: Staircase Picnic Area. 30 seconds At the far-left side of the parking lot in front of the accessible parking space is the trail to the picnic area. A sign at the trailhead has a picnic table icon and the text: Picnic only. No vehicles. There are rocks across the trail with room to pass through. The rocky and uneven trail leads downhill to the picnic area with a picnic table and metal pedestal grill. In places in the picnic area tree roots and rocks protrude through the surface.

title: Staircase Ranger Station
listingDescription: Open in summer when staffing allows, with information, exhibits, and wheelchair available for checkout. Stock corral, trails and accessible restroom and picnic area nearby. Wilderness permits and bear canisters are available summer weekends only at the nearby Hoodsport Visitor Information Center. For more information on Wilderness Information Center locations and hours go to https://www.nps.gov/olym/planyourvisit/wic.htm.

images.altText: A small house with a sign outside that says "Staircase Ranger Station"
images.caption: The Staircase Ranger Station. Photo by C. Bubar/NPS

bodyText: Open in summer when staffing allows, with information, exhibits, and wheelchair available for checkout. Stock corral, trails and accessible restroom and picnic area nearby. Wilderness permits and bear canisters are available summer weekends only at the nearby Hoodsport Visitor Information Center.
audioDescription: Staircase Ranger Station. 2 minutes A brown sign with white text and the National Park Service arrowhead logo reads, Staircase Ranger Station. Behind the sign and sitting atop a slight hill is a square grey-green building with a brown A-shaped peaked roof. On the front of the building, an enclosed lower section with its own brown roof angled down and forward, is the location of the yellow entry door with nine windowpanes across the top half of the door. The door handle is on the left. On either side of the door is a single, yellow-framed window, each with twelve panes of glass. Similar windows are located on the sides of the building. From the parking area along the road, a slightly uphill, paved walkway leads to five concrete steps, then two uneven wooden steps, up to the front door landing. There are no railings along the walkway, the stairs, or on the landing. On the left, between the front door and the window, is a wooden box labeled, Information, that holds park brochures. Under the box, a sign indicates no dogs are allowed in the building, and on the door, a sign reads no firearms are allowed in the building. To the right of the front door landing on ground level is a post supporting a wooden box with a lid and a sign that reads, Backcountry Permits. In front of the Ranger Station to the right, are log benches.

title: Staircase Trailhead
listingDescription: The Staircase Rapids Loop is an easy 2 mile/ 3.2 km trail. It winds through old growth forest to a bridge over the North Fork Skokomish River with only a 200-foot elevation gain. A spur trail leads to a huge fallen cedar.

images.altText: Stream through a misty forest
images.title: Staircase Streams
images.caption: Staircase stream

bodyText:
The Staircase Rapids Loop is an easy 2 mile/ 3.2 km trail. It winds through old growth forest to a bridge over the North Fork Skokomish River with only a 200-foot elevation gain. A spur trail leads to a huge fallen cedar.

This trailhead also accesses the Four Stream and Shady Lane Trails, described below.

 

 

Full Accessibility Description

Four Stream Trail

Length: 1,645 feet, .31 miles
Surface Type: Compacted gravel
Typical Trail Width: 6-8 feet
Typical Running Slope: Under 5%, except the last 200 feet which has some brief steep sections up to 16%
Typical Cross Slope: Less than 2%, trail is crowned (higher in the middle than on the edges)
Elevation Gain/Loss: Less than 25 feet
Accessible Parking: Van-accessible parking along parking area.
Description: The accessible portion of the Four Stream Trail runs along the southern bank of the Skokomish River, and ends at a river overlook at 1,645 feet. The trail narrows and continues beyond that point. The Staircase parking area by the ranger station has one accessible parking spot at the west end of the parking lot. Cross the bridge over the Skokomish River. The trailhead sign will be visible from the west end of the bridge. From the trailhead sign, the 8-foot-wide compacted gravel trail dips down and back up in the first 140 feet, in which 2 sections under 20 feet reach 8% grade. From here, the trail continues at grades under 5%. At 690 feet, there is an intersection with the Big Cedar Trail.

Continuing forward to the right, passing a pullout with a view of the river at 910 feet. At this point, the trail narrows to 6 feet. At 930 feet there is a 50-foot stretch at 6 to 8% grade. The trail continues at under 5% grade with another pullout at 1,150 feet before rising to another river overlook. From 1,360 to 1,390 feet the grade varies from 8-10%, increasing to a max of 16% for 25 feet. Beyond this is a gentler section with grades of 7-15% from 1,450 to 1,490 feet. After twenty feet under 6%, there is a final steep section from 7-11% from 1,510 feet to 1,525 feet. The grade is under 5% for the final approach to the overlook which is at 1,645 feet.

 

Shady Lane

Length: 4,410 feet, .84 miles (trailhead at end of bridge to Four Stream Road trailhead)
Surface Type: Compacted gravel
Typical Trail Width: 2 feet
Typical Running Slope: First quarter of trail is rugged with numerous very steep sections 20-40% grade. From 1,050 to 3,940 feet mainly under 6% grade with occasional steep section 12-17%. Final 500 feet starts with an 85-foot section at 30-35% grade and is then mostly under 6% grade with a few 10-foot sections at 15% grade
Typical Cross Slope: Less than 2%, trail is crowned (higher in the middle than on the edges)
Accessible Parking: Van-accessible parking along parking area
Description: From the Staircase parking area, across the bridge over the Skokomish River, the trailhead is identified by a sign on the left-hand side at the far end of the bridge. The next 310 feet of the trail is compacted gravel 3 feet wide. The first 20 feet of this stretch of trail descends from the bridge at a steep 16% grade, decreasing to 8% to 50 feet, and then leveling out to less than 5% grade to 310 feet. The tread then becomes quite rocky to 430 feet, with cross slopes up to 4%.

At 425 feet, there is a steep informal trail down to the river’s edge. At 430 feet, 2 steps lead up to a 2-foot wide, 40-foot-long bridge. The trail width remains at 2 feet for the remainder of the trail. From the end of the bridge to 1,050 feet, the trail follows the contours of the river along a steep slope that has been impacted by several slides. There is a short spur trail to an old mine shaft on the far side of the bridge.

The trail continues to the left, proceeding downhill at grades up to 10% to 500 feet. A water bar runs across the trail at 515 feet before the trail begins uphill to cross the slide area. From 555 feet to 570 feet, there is a rugged stone staircase with 6 steps. The trail continues downhill again at grades up to 18% to a 25-foot level section that is held in place by a large log. Beyond the log, the trail climbs uphill at 10% and then steepens to 20% grades with 2 stone steps in the middle from 675 feet to 695 feet before again going downhill at 14-20% to 765 feet. Going uphill again at 10% from 765 to 790 feet, the trail reaches a second bridge, 25-feet long. Beyond the bridge, the trail runs downhill with sections of exposure to a 15-foot drop on the river side, before dropping steeply through a section of bedrock from 830 to 855 feet.

The next section continues downhill at 20% grade with many roots in the trail from 875 feet to 900 feet. From 900 to 935 feet, the climb increases to 40% grade before becoming more gradual to 985 feet and switching again to downhill at 20% grade to 1,050 feet. From this point on, the trail enters the forest. There continue to be steep sections and periodic roots and rocks in the trail, but they are interspersed with long gentle sections under 6% grade that weave between impressive old-growth cedar trees.

From 1,050 to 1,830 feet, the trail meanders through the woods at grades under 6%. At 1,830 feet, there is a 15-foot downhill at 17% followed by a brief uphill around a large fallen tree. At this point, the trail fluctuates downhill at up to 17% grade to 1,975 feet, followed by gentler downhill under 7% grade to 2,220 feet. From 2,220 to 2,535 feet, alternating gentle ups and downs in the trail under 6% lead to a root-heavy downhill at 14% for 25 feet. Beginning uphill again, gentle grades run to 2,695 feet at 9% before beginning downhill again. The next stretch of trail covers grades under 6% to 3,710 feet, and one 12% from 2,775 to 2,815 feet.

There is an intersection with an unofficial trail to the river at 3,710 feet. This is a good point to turn around, if returning to the Staircase parking area, as the remainder of the trail is a climb up to the Four Stream Road trailhead. If continuing, proceed to the right from the intersection. From 3,940 to 4,025 feet there is a very steep 30-35% climb. The remainder of the hike is uphill at gentle grades, interspersed with a few 10-foot sections at 15%. Arrive at Four Stream Road at 4,410 feet.
audioDescription: Staircase Trailhead. 2 minutes The trailhead is located across a concrete bridge with side rails near the parking lot. Be advised. There is a two-inch high metal lip across the front surface of the bridge. A sign at the end of the bridge on the left reads: Staircase Rapids with an upward pointing arrow, and Shady Lane with a left pointing arrow. Underneath, a second sign reads, No Pets. Along the flat gravel trail on the right is a brown covered box holding trail brochures. A sign on the lid reads: Welcome. We hope you enjoy exploring Olympic National Park. Donations for these trail brochures are accepted at park visitor centers. Thank you for your support. The sign ends with this quote by John Muir: In every walk with Nature one receives far more than he seeks. Further up trail on the right is a tall informational sign with a map of the trail system marked in white lines. Above the map is a trail profile illustrating the elevation gain for three trails. Below these images, text reads: Staircase Trailhead. The main up-valley trail follows the North Fork Skokomish River Valley, climbing through lowland, montane and subalpine forests. Side trails lead to mountain ridges, lakes and scenic vistas. The first mile of this trail shares one leg of the 1.9 mile Staircase Rapids Loop Trail. Text continues: Evolving Wilderness. On the way to Staircase you have passed logged-over land and man-made lake Cushman, dammed to harness hydroelectric power. The Olympic interior was unexplored until 1889. Lieutenant Joseph O’Neil, leader of an 1890 expedition, brought infantrymen and pack mules up this valley on his way to map and survey a swath across the peninsula. A few settlers and miners later tried to extract a living from the steep canyons and rugged peaks. Since 1938 the National Park Service has been charged with preserving the Olympic backcountry. To the left of the text is a drawing of Lieutenant O’Neil with mustache and beard, standing on a slope wearing a blue, short-brimmed square hat and a blue uniform jacket with several medals pinned on his chest. He holds a pair of binoculars. To the left of the Lieutenant in the distance, are the three human figures traversing the snowy slope. In the far distance are pine trees and a snowy mountain ridge under a blue sky.

title: Stock Corral at Graves Creek Quinault

images.altText: Black and white symbol for stock corral with a horse in a partially covered structure.

bodyText: Stock corral located near Graves Creek Ranger Station
audioDescription: Stock Corral. 45 seconds At the Mile 5 signpost, a brown wooden sign with a right pointing arrow reads: Stock Camp. Park Trailers Here. The short road to the corral loops around a center island with trees and plants. Standing at the front edge of the island is a bulletin board. Posted notice include wilderness regulations, backcountry safety, wildlife, food, and your safety, and stock use in the Quinault area. At the top left corner of the loop is the corral, its perimeter lined with a split rail fence. A double gate in the fence faces the loop. A hitching post stands in front of the fence. To the left of the corral near the fence is a picnic table and an in-ground fire pit.

title: Stock Corral at North Fork Quinault

images.altText: Black and white symbol for stock corral with a horse in a partially covered structure.

bodyText: Stock corral located adjacent to the North Fork Trailhead parking lot.
audioDescription: Stock Corral. 30 seconds On the left side of the North Fork Trailhead parking lot is a wide stock corral. Wooden rail fencing lines the perimeter. On the parking lot side is a double gate. Inside the corral is a white, one-story barn with a wooden shingled roof. It has two windows on the left side and two steps up to green double doors on the front. On the right side is an open area under roof. In front of the barn to the right are two hitching posts.

title: Stock Corral, Staircase Area

images.altText: Black and white symbol for stock corral with a horse in a partially covered structure.

bodyText: Stock corral
audioDescription: Stock Corral. 3 minutes The gated stock corral is a large area of dirt surrounded by a split rail fence. Outside the corral is a six-foot-high bulletin board with informational about wilderness regulations, backcountry safety, stock use in the Quinault area, and wildlife, food, and your safety. On the far right is a hitching post. Text on each notice, reads: Wilderness Regulations. Wilderness Camping Permit is required for overnight stays in the backcountry. Food, garbage and scented items must be stored away from wildlife at all times. Campfires are prohibited above 3500 feet elevation. Pets are not allowed on trails, beaches, and in the wilderness. Weapons, bicycles and vehicles are prohibited in the backcountry Backcountry Safety. Plan your trip and know you limits. Tell someone where you are going and when you will return. Be aware of the weather. Carry the 10 essentials which are food, water, extra clothes including rain gear, knife, flashlight, and batteries, first aid kit, map, compass, fire starter and matches, sunscreen and sunglasses. Stock Use in the Quinault Area. Ride only on trails designated for stock use. Wilderness Camping Permit is required for overnight stays in the backcountry. Food, garbage, and scented items must be stored away from wildlife at all times. Tying stock to a single tree for more than one hour is prohibited. For long stays, hitch racks and lines must be at least 200 feet from water. Feed must not contain viable seeds. Grazing is permitted with one-quarter mile of stock camps. Wildlife, Food and Your Safety. Many animals, including bears, rodents, birds, deer, elk and racoons can become habituated to humans. Often that are attracted by food. This leads to unnatural tameness, unpredictable aggression, and other safety and health concerns. These changes in behavior may result in area closures or the death of the animal. Keep your distance. Stay at least 50 yards away from animals. Do not touch or disturb. All foot (human and pet), drinks, cooking tools and supplies, and anything else with a strong odor must be secured from wildlife. Put garbage in dumpsters or pack it out. Do not put garbage in fire pits. Backcountry food storage includes using bear cannisters which are available for loan from ranger stations or hanging food at least 12 feet high and 10 feet out from the nearest tree trunk.

title: Storm King Boat Launch

images.altText: A boat ramp and a dock extending into a bright blue lake.

bodyText: Dock and boat launch on Lake Crescent.
audioDescription: Storm King Boat Launch. 1 minute At the edge of the parking lot, a wooden dock extends out into the lake. Connected to the end of this dock is a downward sloping metal bridge that connects to a second wooden dock, extending the structure even further into the lake. Side rails on the wooden docks are about 18-inches high. The railings on the metal ramp are about 4 feet high. The second dock sits lower in the water than the first dock and has a low railing at the end. Overlapping green, forested mountains surround the lake. To the right of the dock, a ridged, asphalt boat ramp slopes into the water. A sign next to the ramp reads, Olympic National Park. Notice to Boaters. The introduction of non-native plants and water-borne species into Lake Crescent is prohibited. If your boat was last in waters other than this lake, removing contaminants from the hull, bilge and engine is required prior to launch. 36 CFR 2.14

title: Storm King Ranger Station
listingDescription: Open in summer as staffing allows, with information, activities, and ranger programs.

images.altText: A cabin with a stone chimney among trees and mist. Sign in front reads "Storm King Ranger Station."
images.caption: The Storm King Ranger Station.

bodyText: Open in summer as staffing allows, with information, activities, and ranger programs.
audioDescription: Storm King Ranger Station. 4 minutes From the parking lot, a flat path leads to the log cabin Ranger Station. The building is two-stories with two second floor A-shaped dormers sitting midway up the wooden shingled roof. A red brick chimney extends above the roof in the center of the building and a grey, stone chimney on the cabin’s right wall rises above the roof line. A raised front porch with four steps and handrails provides access to the centrally located front door. Windows trimmed in white are on either side of the door. Attached to the cabin and directly adjacent to the door on the right and left, are wooden boxes holding park brochures and other information. Inside, the wooden walls of the cabin are reddish gold in color with prominent dark scattered knots. The wood floor is similar in color. In the center of the room, interpretive material such as tactile casts of animal footprints and touchable animal pelts are laid out on a table with chairs. Hanging on the wall is a black and white historic photograph of nine women and five men aboard a long white wooden boat sitting low in the water. A canopy covers two-thirds of the boat. The boat engine’s chimney rises above the canopy. The women wear ankle length, high collared, long sleeve patterned dresses and wide brimmed hats. The men wear white long-sleeved shirts, dark vests, and pants. One woman holds a guitar. A sign below the photograph reads: Lady of the Lake. Ferries were the only means of transportation at Lake Crescent during the turn of the century. Lady of the Lake, one of the ferries, transported passengers and goods from the East Beach area to Fairholme. It could reach a speed of eight miles per hour and frequently stopped at resorts around the lake. Ferries remained in service until shortly after 1922, when the road around the south shore was completed. A taxidermied trout also hangs on the wall, its pointed mouth opened, exposing sharp teeth. The skin of the trout is gray on top, pink and lightly spotted on the side, and light tan on the belly. Along the spine are two fins and along the belly, four fins. The V-shaped tail fin is spotted. A sign below the fish reads: Beardslee Trout. The Beardslee trout brough considerable acclaim to lake Crescent as early as the 1890s. A subspecies of rainbow trout, it is unique to the lake. The tout is named after Admiral Lesley A. Beardslee who initiated scientific interest in this species. The trout on display weighed 16 ¾ pounds. The largest Beardslee ever caught tipped the scales at 23 pounds. Next to the text is a small black and white photographic portrait of a man from the shoulders up facing slightly left with the caption, Admiral Beardslee. He is light complexioned with a dark, bushy moustache, thick dark eyebrows, close cut gray hair, and dark eyes. His dark jacket has a tall collar adorned with two white stars and an anchor. His black hat has a round side band with military insignia on the front, flat crown, and short front brim. Next to the sign is a taxidermied owl with brown and white feathers, big, round, dark eyes, and a short yellow beak.

title: Storm King Trailhead
listingDescription: The Mount Storm King trail branches off from the Marymere Falls trail and switchbacks up 2,000 feet in 2.2 miles (610 meters in 3.5 km) - an intense, steep ascent! If you venture to the top, please: Don't feed that Canada jay! In national parks, keeping wildlife wild is part of our mission. Unfortunately, some visitors forget this and have fed birds on Mount Storm King. When birds become habituated they forget how to be wild and can even become aggressive. This is not the pla

images.altText: A lake with mountains rising beyond the shore.
images.caption: Mount Storm King, seen across Lake Crescent. Photo by M. Juran/NPS.

bodyText: The Mount Storm King trail branches off from the Marymere Falls trail and switchbacks up 2,000 feet in 2.2 miles (610 meters in 3.5 km) - an intense, steep ascent! If you venture to the top, please: Don't feed that Canada jay! In national parks, keeping wildlife wild is part of our mission. Unfortunately, some visitors forget this and have fed birds on Mount Storm King. When birds become habituated they forget how to be wild and can even become aggressive. This is not the place for a fairy tale princess moment...especially if you don't want to be fined for breaking park laws!
audioDescription: Storm King Trailhead. 30 seconds Caution. The trail surface here is very uneven due to protruding tree roots and rocks. A brown and white sign at the trailhead reads, Storm King Trail. Ferns and other low growing plants line the trail and carpet the forest floor below tall trees.

title: Swan Bay Boat Launch on Lake Ozette

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a boat on a ramp.

bodyText: Boat launch
audioDescription: Swan Bay Boat Launch. 25 seconds The road to the boat launch ends at a gravel parking lot. On the shoreline, the sloping dirt launch cuts through an opening in the trees. Dense forests of green pine trees line the lakeshore in the distance.

title: Switchback Trailhead
listingDescription: A steep series of switchbacks reveals panoramic views and connects to other trails on Klahhane Ridge.

images.altText: A steep trail up a mountainside
images.title: The Switchback Trail
images.caption: The Switchback Trail

bodyText: A steep series of switchbacks reveals panoramic views and connects to other trails on Klahhane Ridge.
audioDescription: Switchback Trailhead. 2 minutes There are three signs at this trailhead. On the right side of the trail is a brown and white sign with the heading, Switchback Trail, followed by mileage to points along the trail. These read: Heather Park Trail, 1.6. Lake Angeles, 4.3. Hurricane Visitor Center, 3.7. Heart O’ the Hills, 7.9 On the left side of the trail is a tall informational panel with black text. The top half is a green map of the Switchback Trail with the text, You Are Here, marking the trailhead on Hurricane Ridge Road. The map shows where Hurricane Ridge Trail, Heather Park Trail, and Lake Angeles Trail join the Switchback Trail. Below the map, text reads: Switchback Trail. From here the trail climbs steeply, 1,600 vertical feet in 1.5 miles, to Klahhane Ridge. From there trails continue to Heart O’ the Hills via Heather Park or Lake Angles. A spur trail to Hurricane Ridge lies one-half mile up this trail. A climb to the summit of Mount Angeles necessitates climbing steep scree slopes and should be done by experienced hikers only. Heart O’ the Hills via Heather Park, 7.7 miles. Heart O’ the Hills via lake Angeles, 7.6 miles. Hurricane Ridge, 3/2 miles Additional text reads: Ghost Forest. A fire in 1940 left the stand of silver tree trunks. Because of the slope’s steepness, the blaze travelled so quickly that only needles and outer bark were scorched. Most of the forest is Alaska yellow cedar, whose roots are very decay resistant. Now, new trees are beginning to obscure the burn. The final sign on the left side of the trail reads, No pets, weapons, or vehicles.

title: The Beaumont Cabin
listingDescription: Visit a historic cabin right behind the Olympic National Park Visitor Center!

images.altText: A small historic looking cabin.
images.caption: The Beaumont Cabin. Photo by J. Chao/NPS.

bodyText: Visit a historic cabin right behind the Olympic National Park Visitor Center!
audioDescription: The Beaumont Cabin. 3 minutes A concrete walkway encircles the cabin. The log cabin is a square building of weathered logs with interlocking dovetailed corners and a roof of weathered wood shingles covered in moss. On the front of the cabin, as you face the building, is a screen door offset to the right. To the left of the door is a window with six glass panes, three over three.
