On the right side of the cabin, a grey stone chimney rises up the wall from the ground level to about a foot above the roof line. The chimney is bottle shaped – wide at the bottom and narrow at the top. To the right of the door is a sign with a sepia toned photographic head-to-waist portrait of Elliott Beaumont. He has a white moustache and long white beard and appears happy as he looks at the camera. He wears a dark brimmed, rounded-crown straw hat, a black coat, vest and shirt. Rolled white papers protrude out from an inside coat pocket. Text to the right of the portrait reads, The Beaumont Cabin This log cabin was built in 1887 about a mile south of here by Mr. And Mrs. Elliott Beaumont as a home while “proving up” on a 160-acre Government homestead. They lived in this cabin for almost 40 years. The cabin was donated by Mr. Don Newman to the Clallam County Historical Society to be used as an exhibit of pioneer life on the Olympic Peninsula. It was moved from the original site on this property in 1962 by members of the society. They have restored the cabin with representative furnishings of the pioneer period 1850-1900. To the left of the cabin in the grass, is a low-to-the ground concrete platform upon which is a large bell and train whistle. The gold-colored metal bell is flared at the bottom and slimmer at the top and is suspended in a somewhat circular yoke. The train whistle sits atop the bell and is a tall, dark green metal cylinder with a cap at the top and two semicircular openings at the bottom. Text on a brass plague affixed to the front of the platform reads, Baldwin Locomotive whistle and bell. Lyon and Hill’s Train Number 4, hauled first load logs, Sol Duc Valley to Port Angeles, 1926. To Clallam County Historical Society from Harry LeGear, 1970.

title: The Lost Resort Lodge
listingDescription: The Lost Resort is a general store, deli, and camping resort just outside of the Ozette area of Olympic National Park.

images.altText: A large log cabin style building with a front porch and cars outside.
images.caption: The Lost Resort. Photo by D. Sullivan/NPS.

bodyText: The Lost Resort is a general store, deli, and camping resort just outside of the Ozette area of Olympic National Park.
audioDescription: The Lost Resort Lodge. 1 minute A brown wooden sign with white text reads, The Lost Resort General Store. Campsites and Cabin. A second sign reads, No Pets Allowed. General Store. Espresso. Deli. Dining. Ice. Beer. Camping. Cabin Rentals. The store faces the gravel parking lot and is a two-story brown wooden clapboard building with a shingle roof and a 5-window roof dormer. In the center of the building is a staircase with side railings has five steps up to a covered front porch. The entry door is directly in front of the stairs. Seating is to the right of the door on the porch. On the right side of the building at parking lot level is a ramp that leads to an entrance behind the building.

title: Third Beach

images.altText: Sea stacks and ocean waves
images.title: Third Beach
images.caption: Sea stacks beyond the waves at Third Beach

bodyText: One of the spectacular beaches in the Mora coastal area
audioDescription: Third Beach. 45 seconds A brown and white metal sign in the parking area reads, Warning. Parked vehicles are subject to thefts. Secure and protect valuables. Pets, bicycles, weapons, and motorized vehicles are not allowed. Backcountry permits required for overnight camping. Where the forest transitions to dune grasses and sandy beach, lay jumbled piles of driftwood. Then, the beach slants slightly down to the water’s edge. At low tide, rocks may jut out of the ocean near the shore. In the distance rocky sea stacks stand tall, some close to shore, others further out to sea.

title: Third Beach Trailhead
listingDescription: The trailhead is located on La Push Road, 12 miles (19 km) west of US 101. The trail descends 270 feet over 1.4 miles (82 meters over 2.3 km) through forest to a scenic, sandy beach.

images.altText: Sea stacks and ocean waves
images.title: Third Beach
images.caption: Sea stacks beyond the waves at Third Beach

bodyText: The trailhead is located on La Push Road, 12 miles (19 km) west of US 101. The trail descends 270 feet over 1.4 miles (82 meters over 2.3 km) through forest to a scenic, sandy beach.
audioDescription: Third Beach Trailhead. 1 minute Parking is along the side of the road in a dirt and gravel lot. The trailhead is at the far-left end of the lot. A garbage and recycle bin are located at the trailhead on the right behind large boulders. About 15 feet up the flat, gravel path on the right is a brown sign with white text that reads: Warning. Parked vehicles are subject to thefts. Secure and protect valuables. Pets, Bicycles, Weapons, and Motorized vehicles are not allowed. Backcountry permits Required for overnight Camping. Further up trail on the left is a bulletin with posted notices about coastal safety, marine debris, tsunamis, backcountry safety, pet regulations, hiking, and to contact a park ranger or dial 911 in an emergency. Straight ahead on the left is an all gender, single stall, accessible restroom building with a vault toilet. Enter on the right front side beneath an open alcove. The door to the restroom is on the left. Beyond the restroom on the left and right sides of the trail are kiosks with interpretive panels.

title: Trailhead from NatureBridge to Moments in Time Trail
listingDescription: The main trailhead for Moments in Time is near Lake Crescent Lodge.

images.altText: A black and white symbol for trailhead with a figure of a person with a walking stick and backpack.

bodyText: The main trailhead for Moments in Time is near Lake Crescent Lodge.
audioDescription: Moments in Time Trail Wayside. 1 minute The color image on this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel is a lake with still water flanked on the right by a hill with tall dark pine trees and on the left and rear by the slope of a tall mountain. Text reads: Moments in Time Trail. Shaped by time and water, Barnes Point punctuates the south shore of glacially carved Lake Crescent. This quiet delta, with its mantle of old-growth forest, continues to grow and change. For thousands of years, American Indians lived and traded here. Later, settlers homesteaded this area and entrepreneurs developed hotels and lodges. Today, Lake Crescent is protected in Olympic National Park for all to enjoy. As you walk this trail, you follow the footsteps of many who shaped this landscape. This accessible one-half mile loop has several entrances and exits. A trail map is provided below and at four other entry points. Please return it after use. These interpretive exhibits were provided by the Rob Reed and Lena Sharpe Memorial Foundation.

title: Vault Toilet at Graves Creek Campground

images.altText: A brown outhouse in the rain forest
images.title: Vault Toilet Graves Creek
images.caption: Behold

bodyText: Perhaps the most famous attraction at Olympic National Park, the vault toilet at Graves Creek Campground.
audioDescription: Vault Toilet. 30 seconds On the side of the road atop a concrete pad is an all gender, single stall, accessible restroom building with a vault toilet. Enter on the left front side beneath an open alcove. The door to the restroom is on the right. A path of three stone pavers leads to the restroom. Be advised, there are large stones on the ground to the left and right of the restroom.

title: Water Journey Overlook
listingDescription: A small trail leads to this hidden away view of the Olympic Mountains.

images.altText: A view of green mountainsides with a heavy layer of clouds above.
images.caption: View from the overlook. Photo by E. Goode/NPS.

bodyText: A small trail leads to this hidden away view of the Olympic Mountains.
audioDescription: Water Journey Wayside/Overlook. 2 minutes At this fenced area overlooking a deep, forest filled gorge and steep mountains is a three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel with text at top right that reads: Water Journey. Follow a droplet of water. Standing here you can view most of its route. Restless. Hitchhiking a ride on Pacific breezes, moisture blows inland. Fog breathes through the forest turning trees dark green. Drifting upslope, the drop cools and condenses, freezes, and floats down on white peaks. From the highlands melting snow tumbles down this steep-walled canyon and join other torrents to form a stream on its way to the sea. Saltwater surrounds three sides of the Olympic Peninsula. Viewed from the air the glaciated mountains are the heart; streams and rivers are veins and arteries. Water flows so steadily here that people once thought the source must be a great lake in the unexplored center of the mountains. On the left side of the panel is a black and white drawing of two mountains with white snow fields. At the V-shaped base of the mountains, a white line represents a stream. High on the left, an arrow extends upward from a snowy slope, pointing to a white cloud in the sky. On the right, a second arrow next to a snow field points downslope, and a third arrow above the stream, points downward, indicating the streams direction of flow. Below the text, a black and white drawing shows a low, front view perspective of a winding forest stream, swollen with water, tumbling over rocks and boulders. Trees line the stream banks, and one fallen tree spans the stream like a bridge.

title: Welcome Sign at Olympic National Park Visitor Center/Hurricane Ridge Road
listingDescription: Pause for a photo with our Port Angeles area welcome sign! In addition to the English message, it features the phrase "ʔənʔá č’ə́yəxʷ" which means "come, enter" in the Klallam/S'Klallam language. Here is a short video about the meaning of this sign: youtube.com/watch?v=PTmbFBlvbG0

images.altText: Sign with the arrowhead logo that reads "Welcome, ʔənʔá č’ə́yəxʷ Olympic National Park."
images.title: ONPVC welcome sign
images.caption: Welcome sign.

bodyText: Pause for a photo with our Port Angeles area welcome sign! In addition to the English message, it features the phrase "ʔənʔá č’ə́yəxʷ" which means "come, enter" in the Klallam/S'Klallam language. Here is a short video about the meaning of this sign.
audioDescription: Park Entrance Sign - Hurricane Ridge Road. 2 minutes This large brown wooden sign is attached to two bark-less log support structures, one on each side of the sign. The base is constructed of colorful, round river rocks in various hues of pink, grey, green, and blue. A concrete sidewalk leads to the sign. Large text on the sign reads, Olympic National Park. Above this, the word, Welcome, is followed by the same word translated into the Klallam language. The symbols and lower-case letters that form this written word are described as: Inverted question mark. An upside-down inverted letter e. The letter n. Inverted question mark. The letter a with a left pointing accent mark above. A space. The letter c with a V-shaped accent mark above. An apostrophe. An upside-down and inverted letter e with a left pointing accent mark above. The letter y. An upside down and inverted letter e. The letter x. A small letter w at the top right corner of the preceding letter x. On the right side of the sign is the National Park Service logo. It is shaped like an arrowhead with a scalloped edge, pointed at the bottom, with sides that widen out toward the top, before curving slightly inward, then flaring out to create a rounded top. The arrowhead is brown with etched words and images. On the right side are the words, National Park Service, in white letters. To the left, in green, a tall tree towers above smaller trees and the ground below and a section of lake in white. Behind the tree, a white outline of snowcapped mountains. Below the trees, text in white reads, Department of the Interior, and below this, an outline of a bison in profile facing left with a large head and shoulders and smaller hind area.

title: Whiskey Bend Trailhead
listingDescription: The Whiskey Bend trailhead is located 4.6 miles (7.4 km) up a narrow gravel road (for 6.9 miles/11.1 km total, walking up the road from Madison Falls), turning left just past the ranger station. This trailhead is a primary access point for day hikes and backpacking routes.

images.altText: A black and white symbol for trailhead with a figure of a person with a walking stick and backpack.

bodyText: The Whiskey Bend trailhead is located 4.6 miles (7.4 km) up a narrow gravel road (for 6.9 miles/11.1 km total, walking up the road from Madison Falls), turning left just past the ranger station. This trailhead is a primary access point for day hikes and backpacking routes.
audioDescription: Whiskey Bend Trailhead. 1 minute A brown and white rectangular wooden sign on the right has the heading, Whiskey Bend, Elevation 1273 Feet, then a list of sites along the trail with their mileage from the trailhead. These read: Rica Canyon 1.7 Michael’s Ranch 1.8 Humes Ranch 2.3 Dodger Point 13.5 Dosewallips Road 40.5 Elkhorn R.S. 11.5 Hayes River R.S. 16.8 Hayden Pass 25.2 Low Divide 28.4 North Fork, Quinault Road 44.0 Behind this sign is a tall, covered bulletin board with changing park information and notices. On the left of the trailhead is a second tall, covered bulletin board with changing park information and notices.

bodyText: Plaque recognizing Olympic National Park's designation as a World Heritage Site
audioDescription: World Heritage Sign. 30 seconds Attached on the wall to the right of the restrooms and to the left of the front entrance door is a square brown metal plaque with gold colored text that reads: Through the collective recognition of the community of nations expressed within the principles of the convention concerning protection of the world cultural and national heritage, Olympic National Park has been designated a World Heritage Site and joins a select list of protected areas around the world whose outstanding natural and cultural resources form the common inheritance of all mankind. October 27, 1981.

title: [SIGN] Staircase wayside #03

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: An informational wayside sign.
audioDescription: The Staircase Wayside. 90 seconds At the end of the parking lot on the right before crossing the bridge stands a three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel. A black and white drawing on the left shows a man leading two mules up a trail between forested mountain slopes. The man wears a brimmed hat, white shirt, and black pants. Bundles wrapped in cloth and rope are strapped across the back of each mule. Text reads, The Staircase. This area was first called the staircase in the 1890 diaries of the O’Neil Expedition. A “staircase” was the only possible route up certain slopes. On the way to map and explore the Olympic interior, O’Neil’s party cut zig-zag trails up ridges, felled trees against cliffsides and covered the logs with brush and dirt to create a stair-like path for pack mules. Today the name Staircase describes the rapids one mile upstream. Below the text is a map of the Olympic Peninsula with the blue Strait of Juan de Fuca to the north, and the blue Pacific Ocean to the west. On the peninsula, the text, You Are Here, marks your location along the O’Neil party’s route which is illustrated by a black dashed line that heads north to the Quinault River, bears west along the river, then turns south

title: [Sign] 3 Steps Into Wilderness #267a

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Three Steps Into Wilderness. Overview 30 seconds On the left, just before the flat, gravel trail begins is an all gender, single stall, accessible restroom building with a vault toilet. Enter on the right front side beneath an open alcove. The door to the restroom is on the left. On the right and left sides of the trailhead are wooden roof covered kiosks each holding two panels with information about planning and preparing for your hike and how to protect the wilderness. On the left side of the trail another sign reads, No Pets. Continue listening for a description of the kiosk panels. 6 minutes. Beginning with the kiosk on the right and the panel on the left, a text header across the top has white and green lettering on a black background that reads, Your first 3 steps into Wilderness. The remainder of the panel is color photograph of dark sea stacks silhouetted in front of a dark blue, pink, and yellow sky with pink reflections in the water. Text on the image reads: When you enter the Olympic Wilderness, you’re in for a wild time. Six hundred miles of trails link you to sea and sky. Are you hiking the coast, crossing creeks through old-growth forest or ascending mile-high peaks? Whatever your destination, Your First 3 Steps into Wilderness can lead to success or disaster. Attentive trip planning and preparation will help protect you and the future of wilderness. Step 1. Plan. Step 2 Prepare. Step 3 Protect The header on the second panel reads, Step 1. Plan. Below, are two columns of text. On the left is parkwide planning information. On the right, is planning information pertaining to South Coast. Text in the Parkwide column reads: Before your trip, contact the park’s Wilderness Information Center (WIC) or area ranger station for safety information, permits and regulations. Group size limit is twelve. Leave your trip itinerary, including date of return, with someone who expects you back. Observe all regulations, including those restricting pets, weapons, and wheeled vehicles and devices. Safely secure all food, garbage, and scented items 24 hours a day to protect wildlife and you. Contact the WIC for bear container loan locations. Text in the South Coast column reads: Outsmart thieving racoons and other wildlife by using required hard-sided food containers. Consult and carry a tide chart and detailed topographic map. Don’t attempt to round headlands without knowing the tides. You may get trapped as the tide rises against the cliffs. When necessary, ascend marked, but often steep, headland trails. Cross Goodman, Falls, and Mosquito Creeks at low tide. Storms or high tides may make these streams difficult. Below the text, a map of the coast with the text, You Are Here, includes trails, creeks, campgrounds, beaches, and other points of interest along the coast. Inset on the map are three photographs. One a red berry hanging from a stem, next a red five-pointed sea star on a bed of green seaweed, and last, a person on a trail with a yellow and red sunset in the background. Moving to the second kiosk on the left side of the trail, the header on the first panel reads, Step 2. Prepare. Text in the parkwide column reads: Carry backcountry essentials, including extra food, extra warm-when-wet clothing, topographic map, compass, flashlight, extra batteries, sunglasses and sunscreen, pocketknife, matches in waterproof container, firestarter. Prepare for hazards of weather, terrain, water crossing and wildlife. Prevent hypothermia in cool, wet weather by wearing wool and synthetic layers, a warm hat and raingear. Text for South Coast reads: Watch your step. Rugged headlands, sand ladders and rocky beaches can have challenging, wet, slippery footing. Adjust your expectations. Coastal hiking takes much longer than trail hiking. Boil, filter or chemically treat all drinking water to avoid infection by Giardia, a microscopic intestinal parasite. However, the tree tannins that darken coastal streams are harmless. Avoid dangerous driftlogs that roll in the waves and pound the beach during storms. There are three color photographs on the panel. Along the left side, the image shows a foggy, rocky coastline. In the foreground is a tidepool with orange and purple sea stars and barnacles clinging to the rocks. To the right is a photo of a red, round spiky sea urchin among a cluster of purple sea urchins. Below, a brown racoon with a black mask-like streak across its eyes stands atop seaweed. The header on the second panel reads, Step 3. Protect. Text in the parkwide column reads: Leave no trace of your stay. Think about how your actions impact wildlife, vegetation, and visitors. Use established campsites along the trail system. If hiking cross-country, camp on durable surfaces. Protect plants by observing restoration closures. Minimize use of campfires. Pack out everything you pack in. Properly dispose of human waste. Use privies where available or dig a 6-to-8-inch hole at least 200 feet from campsites and water. Do not urinate in composting or vault toilets. Wash your dishes and yourself away from lakes and streams. To protect water quality, avoid using soap. Leave natural objects and cultural artifacts where are you find them to help protect this irreplaceable wilderness. A photograph to the right of the text shows a person descending a sand ladder to the beach below. White waves roll onto the shore. In the distance seastacks rise out of the ocean. In the center of the panel a photograph shows a blue ribbon of water winding across the brown sandy beach to meet the ocean. A finger of land with dark trees juts out into the ocean on the left. Mist rises. In the distance are offshore islands. At the bottom of the panel, text in the South Coast column reads: Use a stove to eliminate impacts of fire and wood gathering. Build campfires only on the beach and use driftwood to protect the forest. Be sure your fire is out cold as winds can reignite embers. Never feed wildlife for their health and your safety. Backpackers and day hikers should always keep food secured from wildlife. Do not climb on offshore islands and seastacks. They are protected havens for nesting seabirds and resting marine mammals. On the left is a photograph of a tall, wide waterfall in a green forest, its water cascading into the stream below.

title: [Sign] 3 Steps Into the Wilderness Interpretive Panels #274a

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Overview. 1 minute A roof covered open air post and beam building houses seven interpretive panels attached to a semi-circular wooden half wall structure in the center of the building. The ground surface in and around the building is gravel. The panels provide information about three steps to take to help ensure a successful visit parkwide and here at Ozette: Plan, Prepare, and Protect; the Makah people and their relationship with the sea; Ozette pioneers who settled in the area, and how island habitats create sanctuaries for many species of seabirds. Continue listening for a description of each panel. 10 minutes. Attached to the front entrance on the left, a brown sign with white text reads, Wedding Rock Petroglyphs. Petroglyphs are protected archeological resources. It is illegal to excavate, remove, damage, or deface them. Please help to protect these resources. Use only lighting to enhance your photographs and report any disturbance or damage to park personnel. To the right of the sign on the wall is a white bone of an ocean mammal which you may touch. On the right side of the entrance, is the first panel. Filling the background of the panel is a color image of tall cliffs at oceans edge along a rocky shoreline and sea stacks in the distance. A person wearing red walks in the tidepool area. Text along the top reads, Your First 3 Steps into Wilderness. Below, text continues, Step 1, Plan. Step 2, Prepare, Step 3, Protect. Text continues, when you enter the Olympic Wilderness, you’re in for a wild time. Six hundred miles of trail link you to sea and sky. Are you hiking the coast, crossing creeks through old-growth forest or ascending mile-high peaks? Whatever your destination, your first three steps into wilderness can determine the success or disaster of your trip. Attentive planning and preparation will help protect you and the future of wilderness. Entering the building, the first panel on the left wall is titled, Step 1 Plan. Text reads, Parkwide. Before your trip, contact the park’s wilderness information center (WIC) or area ranger station for current safety information, backcountry permits and regulations. Leave your trip itinerary, including date of return, with someone who expects you back. Be aware of the regulations that restrict pets, weapons and wheeled vehicles and devices. Limit your group size to twelve. To their detriment, wild animals can become accustomed to human food. Store all edibles, garbage and scented items in hard sided food containers. Ozette. Reservations are required for overnight trips spring through fall. Check at the ranger station or call the WIC. Be prepared to outsmart thieving raccoons on the coast by observing parkwide food storage practices. Consult and carry a tide chart and detailed topo map. Don’t attempt to round headlands without knowledge of high tides. You may not be able to escape the tides that rise against cliffs. When necessary, ascend marked headland trails with extreme caution. The Ozette River should be crossed at it mouth at or near low tide. During winter or heavy rains, the river may not be fordable. Down the right side of the panel is a green and white map of Olympic National Park North Wilderness Coast. Sites of interest are labeled with mileage between the points. Two trails beginning at the Ozette Ranger Station and ending at the coast are marked on the map: the 3.1-mile Cape Alava Trail and the 3-mile Sand Point Trail. North of the trails, the Ozette Indian Reservation is outlined. To the left of the map at the bottom is the map key. Next to a red exclamation mark text reads, Caution Headland. Hiker must use Overland Trail mark with trail sign during higher tide levels. Next to the word, Danger, text reads, Hiker must always use Overland Trail to round headland. As the wall begins to curve, the next panel to the right is titled, Step 2 Prepare. Text reads, Parkwide. Prepare for hazards of weather, terrain, water crossings and wildlife. Prevent hypothermia in cold, wet weather by layering wool and synthetics. Keep hat and rain gear handy. Carry backcountry essentials, including extra food, map, compass, flashlight, extra batteries, sunglasses and sunscreen, pocket knife, matches in waterproof container, firestarter, first aid kit and extra clothing. Boil, filter, or chemically treat all drinking water. Ozette. Watch your step. The boardwalk is slippery when wet. For good traction, wear tennis shoes or lightweight hikers with soft rubber soles. Tree tannins that darken streams are harmless but remember to sterilize all water for contaminants. Avoid dangerous driftlogs that roll in the waves and pound the beach during storms. A photo at the bottom shows a wooden boardwalk with stairs winding through a forest dense with green understory. A second photo shows jumbled piles of bark less bleached logs covering the length of a beach. Continuing, the next panel on the right is titled, Step 3. Protect. Text reads, when hiking and camping, think about how your actions impact wildlife, vegetation, or visitors. Respect the wilderness experience of others. Leave no trace of your stay. Along the trail system, use established campsites. If traveling cross-country, camp on durable surfaces. Observe revegetation closures to allow plants to recover. Minimize use of fire. Pack out everything you pack in. Wash yourself and your dishes away from water sources. Use small amounts of biodegradable soap or none at all. Properly dispose of human waste. Use privies where available or dig catholes at least 200 feet from campsites and water. Leave what you find, including natural objects and cultural artifacts. Ozette. Along the coast, camp on the beach above high tide line or in established forest sites. Note: Cannonball and Ozette Islands are closed for day or overnight use. Observe campfire bans. Where permitted, small beach fires may be constructed away from driftlogs. In the forest, preestablished fore rings must be used. For forest and beach campfires burn only driftwood, the smaller the better. Be sure your fire is out cold, as winds can reignite fires. When exploring tidepools, walk on bare rock or sand. Leave all organisms where you find them. Do not approach seal pups. Help protect prehistoric Makah Indian rock art and Ozette pioneer homesteads. A photograph at the bottom shows starfish clinging to the side of a rock at low tide. Three are purple and three are orange. Each have five spine covered arms. Green leafy seaweed hangs on the rock and other tidepool animals cling to its side. The panel titled, People of the Sea, is next. Filling the top and left side is a blue and white illustration of a whale in the foreground, its fluked tail above the water. In the background is a canoe carrying eight people atop a rough sea. Three hold harpoons. A harpoon line extends from the canoe to the whale. Text reads, When the whale surfaces again they are already there, matching its speed. Eight men backpaddle the cedarlog canoe as the harpoon strikes. One flick of the tail flukes could interrupt their hunt forever. Like huge balloons, sealskin floats attached to the harpoon line slow the diving whale. A 3.7 mile hike from here is the Ozette Site now closed where archeologist have unearthed village upon village of the Makah people, a North American culture as old as the Pharaohs, yet continuing today. Recovered from buried cedar plank longhouses, the robes of migrating fur seals, ingenious fishhooks and baskets of cedar bark express a ceremonious life of bounty. Objects from the site are on display at the Makah Cultural and Research Center in Neah Bay. Visitors are welcome. The next panel is titled, Ozette Pioneers. An illustration filling the top of the panel shows a brown wooden cabin with a stone chimney in a forest clearing. Standing in front of the cabin, a man holds a long pole. He has a dark beard and moustache and wears a brown wide brimmed hat, blue long-sleeved shirt, and black pants with suspenders. In the bottom left the illustration continues with the end of a split rail fence. Text to the right reads, to reach Ozette lake in 1890 you might have journeyed by steamer to Neah Bay and then by Makah canoe around Cape Flattery to the mouth of the Ozette River. Hauling belongings on your back, you still had to trek several miles through dense forest. The Makah tribe occupied the Ozette Lake area for centuries. By 1892 settlers had built over thirty homesteads around the lake. They hoped for a road. Most of the settlers left before the road was finally completed in the 1930s. Today, as nature reclaims the land, the Roose and Ahlstrom homesteads still stand as reminders of Ozette’s unique history. The final panel is titled, Island Sanctuaries. Text in the lower right corner reads, many species of seabirds coexist on the offshore rocks and islands. Because their food and nesting preferences differ - cormorants perch on ledges, puffins burrow, gulls nest in the grass on top – there is little competition. Without the islands, these birds would cease to exist. Nowhere else can they nest close to abundant ocean food yet stay removed from predators and human disturbance. But seabirds are still vulnerable to chemical pollutants even in surf-washed isolation. A blue and white side view cut-away illustration of a tall rock island extends down the left side. It shows different bird species and their preferred perching and nesting spots. From the top, a Bald eagle stands on a tree branch. A Western gull and Glaucous-winged gull fly above the grassy top of the rock. A Cassin’s auklet sits in the back of a burrow. Then, another burrow with a Rhinoceros auklet. Two tufted puffins sit on a small ledge in front of their long deep burrow with one egg. Two Common murres stand on a ledge followed by other birds on ledges: a Peregrine falcon, Double-crested cormorant, Pigeon guillemot, and Black oystercatcher. Rock islands rise in the distance.

title: [Sign] A Window in Time Wayside #107i

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: A Window in Time Wayside. 2 minutes On the edge of the trail in a forest of moss-covered trees, is a three-foot-tall angled wayside panel titled, A Window In Time. Filling the background is a color illustration of a ferry boat on a blue lake with mountains in the background. The ferry is long with a railing around the edge. In the center is an enclosed cabin with windows. Along the side of the cabin is a wooden water wheel. In the foreground on the lake shore, is a woman, her back to us, with long dark hair, wearing an ankle length red skirt, long sleeved white bouse and a white wide brimmed hat. She stands under a tall, wooden-lattice gate-like structure looking out toward the ferry. At the top of the structure is the word, Rosemary, reversed, so it may be read correctly from the water. Text reads: Imagine yourself here in 1920, traveling by paddle wheel ferry across lake Crescent. From the deck you view a gateway announcing “Rosemary,” a rustic inn bordered by several handcrafted cabins. Today, Rosemary houses Nature Bridge, and educational facility offering environmental learning programs for students of all ages.

title: [Sign] A Different Community Wayside #258h

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: A Different Community Wayside. 45 seconds Filling most of this three-foot-tall, angled wayside panel is a green and white illustration of mosses, ferns, and a fallen tree on the forest floor. In the background, a tree stands, its roots spread like fingers on the ground. Text reads: A Different Community. The lower ground was once a riverbed. As a result, you are stepping down into a different plant community where water flowed more recently. Compare this vegetation with the older forest you’ve just experienced. Surrounding the wayside is a lush forest where moss hangs like tattered curtains from tree branches and tall green ferns and other low growing plants carpet the ground. In places, the dirt trail may be muddy and uneven.

title: [Sign] Aerial Gardens Wayside #107q

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Aerial Gardens Wayside. 1 minute A color image of moss-covered branches fills the entire panel on this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside. Text on the left reads: Aerial Gardens. How many kinds of plants grow overhead? This bigleaf maple supports some 20 species of mosses, liverworts and lichens. All are epiphytes, plants that grow on other plants but do not rely on them for nutrients. Researchers discovered that maples and other hardwoods actually sprout roots into these thick epiphytic mats to clean extra moisture and nutrients. On the right side and bottom of the image is a thick tree limb with many thinner side branches, all covered with yellowish green hanging moss and clumps of ferns.

title: [Sign] Age of the Forest Wayside #258f

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Age of the Forest Wayside. 1 minute On the left side and across the bottom of this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel is a drawing showing a section of tree trunk with branches on its left and right. A Pileated woodpecker with black and white feathers and a red crest atop its head clings to the left side of the trunk. A gray Douglas squirrel with upright ears, dark eyes, long whiskers, and a curved bushy tail stands on a branch. On the right side of the trunk, bright green Lichen lettuce grows on the tree bark. A brown and black bird called a Pine siskin perches at the end of a moss draped branch, and in a tangle of mossy branches below, sits the round empty nest of a Goldfinch. Text at the top right reads: Age of the Forest . On this trail you have seen a mature forest, some of its trees many centuries old. As they age the living towers seem to support more and more life, mosses, lichens, squirrels, woodpeckers. At death they leave a legacy of nutrients. The Spruce Trail steps down to the Hoh River through younger stages of forest, a variety of habitats tempered by the shifting course of the glacial stream.

title: [Sign] Alien Plants Wayside #107g

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Alien Plants Wayside. 1 minute The color background image on this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel shows a man in a green grassy area using a tool to remove a small tree. Text on the right reads: Alien Plants. Can you identify any non-native plants here? When settlers came to Lake Crescent, they brought their favorite flora. Other exotics were accidentally introduced and now nearly a quarter of the Olympic Peninsula’s plant species are non-native. Park biologists monitor the spread of these plants and try to remove those that present the greatest threat to natural ecosystems. The man has dark hair and beard and wears a green National Park Service ballcap, a white sweatshirt, green pants, brown boots and leather gloves. He is grasping the top of an orange, long handled tool with a horizontal hook at the end. Standing with his feet apart, he hooks the trunk of the small tree at its base. The tree is a little taller than the man and has many branches with yellow leaves. It is labeled, Scot’s broom.

title: [Sign] All in a Row Wayside #258j

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: All in A Row Wayside. 30 seconds On the left side and across the bottom of this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel is a black and white drawing of a moss-covered tree trunk lying on the ground. Across the top of the fallen tree, a group of small tree seedlings grow. Text at the top right reads: All in a Row. This colonnade of Sitka spruce and western hemlock straddles the remains of its nurse log. Even if the nurse log had moldered completely away, the buttressed roots of the trees standing in a straight line would tell how growth began. Farther along the trail view the colonnade from other angles.

title: [Sign] Beach Trail Wayside #170a

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Beach Trail Wayside. 1 minute Filling the left side of this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside is a blue and white drawing of long, grass-like seaweed draped over unsubmerged rocks at low tide. One tall frond with a thick stem and bulbous top stands erect. In the distance, a person stands in the surf holding a long-handled net. Text at the top right reads: Beach Trail. At the end of the path search the shore for strange, half-buried objects. Sand dollars, iron fittings from shipwrecks, driftwood, or green glass Japanese fishing floats blown in by winter storms. Fish in the surf. At low tide explore tidepools alive with sea creatures, but please leave them undisturbed. Below the text, is a smaller drawing that includes a hermit crab with its head and claws outside its cone shaped shell, a dark spotted Sea star lying flat, and a cylinder-shaped Sea anemone with many thin tentacles encircling the top of its body.

title: [Sign] Blow Down Wayside #258p

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Blow Down Wayside. 45 seconds On the left side and across the bottom of this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel is a black and white drawing of a fallen tree, its base, with a tangle of exposed roots on the left, and its trunk, with deeply furrowed bark extending to the right. Text at the top right reads: Blow-Down. Like dominoes, a few falling giants topple the trees around them. Notice the shallow roots. In this climate the big trees don’t need taproots to get moisture, but they are vulnerable to winter storms. As the trunks begin to decay, they provide a hothouse environment for spruce and hemlock seedlings. In a few hundred years a new stand may disguise this blow-down.

title: [Sign] Blow-Down Wayside #36

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside informational sign.
audioDescription: Blow-Down Wayside. 2 minutes A black and white aerial drawing of the sunken Hood Canal Bridge fills the left side of a three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel. At the top of the image, one side of the bridge extends out from the shoreline to cross the Canal then disappears into the water. At the bottom of the image on the opposite shoreline, the other half of the bridge spans out to cross the canal but ends abruptly. In between, water flows freely. Text at the top right reads: Blow-Down. On the night of February 12, 1979, a windstorm blew across the Olympic peninsula. Along the coast, gusts reached 96 miles per hour. Trees fell like toothpicks, 92 toppled in this campground alone, leaving a quarter mile-long corridor of downed trunks. The same storm sank the Hood Canal Bridge. Blow-downs are only a phase in the forest’s life-cycle. In the new clearing seedlings thrive on sunlight, and can begin life on the decaying trunks of storm-downed trees. Below the text is a blue and tan weather map of the Northwest Coast showing closely spaced circles within circles with the letter L in the middle, all centered over the Olympic Peninsula. A straight black line with arrows stretches across the blue Pacific Ocean from south to the north ending at the letter L. A caption reads: Path of storm, February 12, 1979.

title: [Sign] Cirque Wayside #44

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Cirque Wayside. 30 seconds Along the Hurricane Ridge Loop Trail overlooking a meadow, valley, and distant mountains, a black and white drawing of a deep and wide bowl-shaped landscape feature with a mountain in the background fills most of a three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel. In the bottom of the bowl and along the rim, trees grow. Text on the right reads: Cirque. The hollow, scooped out of the hillside, is the headprint of a glacier. During daylight thaw, snow and ice seeped into rock cracks, refroze and expanded at night, fracturing the slope. Gradually the glacier steepened and quarried the cliff into a bowl-shaped amphitheater called a cirque.

title: [Sign] Coho in the Creek Wayside #258b

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Coho In the Creek Wayside. 2 minutes On the left side of this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel is an underwater color illustration of two salmon. They swim in shallow water, their bodies just above the rocky stream bed. They have bright red sides with green and black spotted backs. Their heads are green and red. One salmon has a hook nose that overhangs its mouth while the other has a pointed nose. Text at the top right reads: Coho in the Creek. Look into the clear waters of Taft Creek. In late fall and winter, coho salmon spawn in stream gravels. The fry emerge in spring and feed in the river for a year before swimming to sea. Surviving salmon return as three-year-olds to spawn and die. Over 130 wildlife species benefit from salmon, and the remaining fish carcasses decompose and nourish the forest. In their remarkable journey, salmon unite mountains, forest and sea. Below the text is an underwater color illustration of two small fish swimming above a rocky stream bed. Their backs are light reddish-yellow with dark spots and two fins and their bellies with three fins are white with a horizontal line of dark spots. Along their sides are vertical black stripes. Their tails are V-shaped.

title: [Sign] Cultures Carved in Cedar Wayside #189a

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Cultures Carved in Cedar Wayside. 2 minutes A color illustration of five men paddling a long, brown canoe fills the right side of a three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel that stands in front of an authentic wooden canoe on display. The men have brown skin, long black hair, muscular arms, and are bare chested. In a synchronized pose, they each hold a brown wooden long-handled paddle, partially submerged along the right side of the canoe. The water around them is dark blue and in the near distance is a shoreline with pine trees. Each end of the canoe rises up to a squared off tip, the front being twice the height of the back. Attached to the front is a bright red figure shaped in the form of an animal head with two ears and a snout. Text on the left side of the panel reads: Cultures Carved in Cedar. In traditional Northwest Native American style, skilled craftsmen carved an entire canoe from a single western red cedar log. Artisans added a precisely aligned bow and stern to ready their river and ocean canoes for fishing, whaling or extended voyages at sea. Imagine the challenges of blustery rains, enveloping fogs and aching arms endured by tribal paddlers on Northwest waterways. The wooden canoe on display is actual size, gray in color, and has been carved from one log. It sits about three feet above the ground under a roof covered structure that has a flat walking surface. The canoe may be touched.

title: [Sign] Decor of the Rainforest Wayside #255e

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Décor of the Rainforest Wayside. 45 seconds On the left side of this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel is a black and white drawing of a shelf-like fungus growing on a section of tree trunk. Text at the top right reads: Décor of the Rain Forest. Here youth and age are entwined. Shelf fungus fruits on a dying spruce trunk, a colonnade of trees straddles a decaying nurselog. Your senses detect the unique atmosphere of the rain forest: wind in the upper story barely riffling the lower floor; air plants growing green upon green; or subtler features like the light filtering from tree-tops down through the tapestries of moss. Below the text, a black and white drawing shows three mature trees, their roots draped over a decaying log.

title: [Sign] Douglas Fir Wayside #258d

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Douglas Fir Wayside. 45 seconds On the left side of this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel is a black and white drawing of a section of tree trunk with rough bark. Text at the top right reads: Douglas-Fir. The two big trees in the clearing ahead are Douglas-firs. You can identify them by their red-brown, deeply furrowed bark. Unable to reproduce in deep shade, young Douglas-firs are scarce in the rain forest. They need a disturbed, open area created by a blow-down or fire. Below the text is a drawing of a Douglas fir tree trunk and a close-up view of a branch of pine needles with a downward hanging cone attached in the middle. The cone is oval shaped, its scales wide and round with mouse-like tails protruding beyond each cone scale.

title: [Sign] Drift Logs and Riptides Wayside #180b

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Drift Logs and Riptides Wayside. 1 minute Filling the left side of this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel is a blue and white aerial view drawing showing the churning water of a rip current rolling perpendicular to the shoreline through a narrow gap between the shore and a sandbar. Text in the top right reads: Drift Logs and Riptides. Beach logs are the bones of a rain forest picked clean by the sea. They begin in river valleys—giant conifers like Sitka spruce. When a day’s downpour adds to glacial melt the stream may rise six feet, undermining the bank and toppling trees into the flood, washing them down to river mouth and beach. Some fall from eroding headlands. Numbered trunks are strays from tug-pulled log rafts. Drift logs are dangerous. At high tide they may suddenly roll. Unwary people have been crushed and killed by drift logs. Riptides make swimming and wading dangerous. There are no lifeguards. Swimmers beware. Below the text is a smaller drawing at beach level of a jumbled pile of drift logs.

title: [Sign] Drift Logs and Riptides Wayside #188d

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Drift Logs and Riptides Wayside. 1 minute Filling the left side of this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel is a blue and white aerial view drawing showing the churning water of a rip current rolling perpendicular to the shoreline through a narrow gap between the shore and a sandbar. Text in the top right reads: Drift Logs and Riptides. Beach logs are the bones of a rain forest picked clean by the sea. They begin in river valleys—giant conifers like Sitka spruce. When a day’s downpour adds to glacial melt the stream may rise six feet, undermining the bank and toppling trees into the flood, washing them down to river mouth and beach. Some fall from eroding headlands. Numbered trunks are strays from tug-pulled log rafts. Drift logs are dangerous. At high tide they may suddenly roll. Unwary people have been crushed and killed by drift logs. Riptides make swimming and wading dangerous. There are no lifeguards. Swimmers beware. Below the text is a smaller drawing at beach level of a jumbled pile of drift logs.

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Drift Logs and Riptides Wayside. 1 minute Filling the left side of this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel is a blue and white aerial view drawing showing the churning water of a rip current rolling perpendicular to the shoreline through a narrow gap between the shore and a sandbar. Text in the top right reads: Drift Logs and Riptides. Beach logs are the bones of a rain forest picked clean by the sea. They begin in river valleys—giant conifers like Sitka spruce. When a day’s downpour adds to glacial melt the stream may rise six feet, undermining the bank and toppling trees into the flood, washing them down to river mouth and beach. Unwary people have been crushed and killed by drift logs. Riptides make swimming and wading dangerous. There are no lifeguards. Swimmers beware. title: [Sign] Drift Logs and Riptides wayside #170c

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Drift Logs and Riptides Wayside. 1 minute Filling the left side of this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel is a blue and white aerial view drawing showing the churning water of a rip current rolling perpendicular to the shoreline through a narrow gap between the shore and a sandbar. Text in the top right reads: Drift Logs and Riptides. Beach logs are the bones of a rain forest picked clean by the sea. They begin in river valleys—giant conifers like Sitka spruce. When a day’s downpour adds to glacial melt the stream may rise six feet, undermining the bank and toppling trees into the flood, washing them down to river mouth and beach. Some fall from eroding headlands. Numbered trunks are strays from tug-pulled log rafts. Drift logs are dangerous. At high tide they may suddenly roll. Unwary people have been crushed and killed by drift logs. Riptides make swimming and wading dangerous. There are no lifeguards. Swimmers beware. Below the text is a smaller drawing at beach level of a jumbled pile of drift logs.

title: [Sign] Early Logging Wayside #107j

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Early Logging Wayside. 1 minute A color image of two men sawing down a huge tree fills this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel. Text on the left reads: Early Logging. Can you find the clues? Notched springboard holes and flat-topped stumps indicate these ancient giants were cut during the early 1900s. Using only hand tools, woodsmen relied on springboards to lift them above the buttressed bases of large trees. Steam donkeys, horses or ox teams pulled the downed logs along greased skid roads. The image shows two men, one on each side, of an extremely large reddish-brown tree, standing on boards that have been inserted into the tree above ground level. The men wear brimmed hats, button-down long-sleeved shirts, pants, and brown leather boots. Each man holds one end of a long saw that spans the inside of a large, angled notch cut into the tree. Scattered on the ground in front of the tree are pieces of wood sawn from the notch. To the left of the men is a tree stump, its top smooth on one side and jagged on the other. Bits of woods lay around the stump. In the background is a dense forest of uncut trees, green moss hanging from the limbs.

title: [Sign] Elk in the Forest Wayside #258e

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Elk and the Forest Wayside. 1 minute On the left side of this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel is a black and white drawing of an Elk standing in a forest of tall trees and ferns. On the top of its head is a wide set of antlers with five points on each antler beam. It has large, pointed ears, oval shaped dark eyes, and a wide snout tipped with a large black nose above its mouth. The fur on its chest and head is darker than the rest of its body. Text at the top right reads: Elk and the Forest. Young shoots are cropped off, herbs are trampled. In the clearings ahead look for signs of browsing elk. The herds keep the forest floor from becoming a dense jungle of shrubs, salmonberry and vine maple. Below the text are two black and white drawings. On the left, a Vine maple branch with clusters of broad, seven-lobed leaves. On the right, a Salmonberry branch with three, jagged edged, oval shaped leaves, two side by side, and one at the tip. A round berry consisting of many small ball-like segments, hangs above the leaves on a separate branch.

title: [Sign] Elwha River Valley Upright Wayside #80

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Elwha River Valley Upright Wayside. 6 minutes At the edge of a parking lot near a grassy area with picnic tables is a six-foot-tall metal upright frame holding two informational panels. A blue toned photograph of the river with mist rising up the green forested slopes is the background that spans across both panels. Beginning with the panel on the left, text at the top reads: Welcome to Olympic National Park. With nearly one million acres, the park protects rugged coasts, old-growth forests, wild rivers, snowy peaks, diverse wildlife, and rich human stories. Experiencing the major ecosystems of this internationally recognized wilderness is within easy reach. Enjoy exploring, whether for a few hours or a lifetime. Below, is the text, Elwha River Valley, then two side-by-side maps. The small map on the left shows the entire Olympic Peninsula. In the center, a large green roundish area indicates the park. Place names ring its outer edge with the Elwha area on the north side of the park highlighted. Below the map, text reads: A Wilderness Portal. In the mountains before you, the mighty Elwha River is born of snow melt, then flows 45 miles (72 kilometers) before emptying into the Strait of Juan de Fuca. For millennia this valley, the largest watershed in Olympic National Park, has sheltered old-growth forests, abundant wildlife, and massive salmon runs. Walk a trail or two. Discover the Elwha wilderness. To the right, is a larger map showing the Elwha area trail system. A black box with an arrow and white text reading, You Are Here, points to your current location. Below the map is a list of eleven trails each with a description, its one-way distance, and elevation change. Along the left side of the panel is vertical text that reads, Olympic National Park. Below, is a vertical row of three color photographs. From top to bottom, Madison Falls, its white water cascading straight down over green moss-covered rocks. Next, Humes Ranch, a small one-story log cabin with a wooden shingled roof and covered front porch, sits in a green grassy opening in the forest. Lastly, Glines Canyon, showing a section of old concrete spillway on the right and the winding, free flowing river passing forested hillsides on the left. The panel on the right begins with the text, Follow the paths travelled by Elwha Klallam Indians, homesteaders, hikers, and industrialists. Those who came before you each found something of value here – home, adventure, work. What will you discover? Down the right side of the panel, four sepia toned historic photographs in round frames are aligned vertically. A text header reads, Many Have Come Before You. The photograph at the top labeled, Native Americans, Ernie Sampson, 1914, shows a man with dark hair facing left with a slight smile on his face. He wears a white cap, white shirt and dark overalls and shoes. His left hand is placed on his waist. His right hand holds a pole balanced atop his right shoulder. A fish as tall as the man is attached to the front of the pole and a fish half the size is attached to the back of the pole. Next to the man on the ground is the front half of a canoe. A caption to the left of the photograph reads, For the Elwha Klallam, the valley is not only their home and source of food, but also the place of their creation. The next photograph is labeled Homesteaders, Chris and Christina Lollick, 1890s. The image shows a smiling robust woman with tightly pulled back hair and a round white face. She wears a light colored button-down long-sleeved shirt tucked into the waist of a long black skirt. To her left is a bearded man wearing a dark colored brimmed hat, white shirt with rolled up sleeves, a black vest, dark pants and a tan apron tied around his waist. He holds the handle of a tool perched on his left shoulder. In front of the couple is a black dog that stands knee high to the man. Behind the couple is a wooden building with two large windows on the left and a door on the right. A bench holding four buckets lined up in a row sits against the front of the building. A caption reads, In the late 1800s, European Americans began exploring these forests and mountains, followed by homesteaders who made a living farming, ranching, and guiding people through the valley. The third photograph, labeled Hikers, Heading to Mount Olympus, 1913, shows a group of women in single file walking across a fallen tree toward a dark forest. The women wear brimmed hats and carry tall hiking poles. Two of the women are dressed in brown long-sleeved jackets belted at the waist and baggy pants tucked into knee high boots. Several other women wear white jackets, mid-calf brown skirts, and knee-high boots. A caption reads, Hikers and mountain climbers sought wilderness challenges. Others came seeking fish and game. The last photograph is labeled, Industrialists, Building Glines Canyon Dam, 1926. It shows the scaffolded face of the tall dam under construction flanked on either side by brown rocky slopes. Beyond the dam is the river. A caption reads, Entrepreneurs built two dams in the early 1900s to power growth on the Olympic Peninsula. A century later the dams were removed and the Elwha River began to heal.

title: [Sign] Era of Elegance Wayside #133a

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Era of Elegance Wayside. 3 minutes This three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel stands in a grassy area to the right of the Sol Duc Hot Springs Resort entrance. An old black and white photograph of a large four-story hotel and adjacent buildings fills the panel. The photo shows one side and the front of the building. The windows on the top floor are encased in dormers that protrude off the roof, five on the front of the building and two on the side. The third and second floors each have twelve windows flush to the building across the front and six windows on the side. The first floor is wrapped in a covered porch with large windows spanning each side. In the distance, in line with the hotel, are smaller buildings. In front of the hotel is a manicured lawn with a few bushes and trees. Text across the top reads: Era of Elegance. Excitement and bustle fill the air as passengers board a steamship on a misty Seattle morning in 1912. They cruise seventy-five miles to Port Crescent, shuttle twenty miles by auto stages, ferry across Lake Crescent on the steamboat Betty Earles, and travel the final fourteen miles via Stanley Steamers to celebrated Sol Duc Hot Springs Hotel. Michael Earles built the original hotel on this site between 1910 and 1912. He was convinced the hot mineral waters offered cures for rheumatism, liver diseases, alcoholism and other disorders. Rustic yet elegant, the 165-room hotel sported a large veranda encircling three sides. The nearby sanitorium featured a medical staff, operating room and sun parlor. As many as 10,000 guests each summer sipped mineral waters and soaked in hot baths. Horseback riding, tennis, croquet, bowling and dancing ensured a full agenda. After only four years of grandeur, sparks from a defective flue set the cedar roof afire. Within a few hours much of this magnificent resort had burned to the ground. On the left below the text are two old color advertisements for the Sol Duc. Each ad shows massive snow-covered mountains rising up behind the red roofed hotel with its large green front lawn where people are walking. A banner across the bottom of the ad on the left reads, Magnificent Hotel and Playground, and across the ad on the right, Baths and Sanitorium. Below the ads is a quote from Chicago, Milwaukee and Puget Sound Company, circa 1912 that reads: The mail lobby, capacious and ornate, with massive columns running through the center greets the eye of the guest while near the front entrance is a great fireplace, lending an air of comfort and cheeriness.

title: [Sign] Extended Family Wayside #107k

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Extended Family Wayside. 1 minute. A color image of a forest fills this entire three-foot-tall angled, metal wayside panel. Text on the left reads: Extended Family. Life and death form a continuum in the forest community. This fallen Douglass fir serves as a nurse log for new generations of trees. Western redcedar and western hemlock seedlings sprout on the log, above the competition of the forest floor. In time, these trees may survive as a colonnade, their roots encircling the shape of the vanished nurse log. In the foreground of the image on the left and right are lower trunk sections of light brown trees, their bases not flat to the ground. Instead, like curved fingers touching a flat surface, long, thick, downward arched roots ring the bottom of the trees, elevating them above ground level. Green moss grows on the roots and green ferns dot the ground. In the background, the dense green forest extends into the distance.

title: [Sign] First Residents Wayside #107e

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: First Residents Wayside. 1 minute A color illustration of a woman standing next to a body of water fills this entire three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel on the shoreline of Lake Crescent. Text on the left side reads: First Residents. The Klallam name for Lake Crescent sounds like tsulthmut. Stories and traditions of the Klallam and Quileute people tell us that American Indians maintained a long and intimate association with Lake Crescent. The lakeshore served as a meeting place, and area tribes gathered here to trade and join in ceremonies. On the right, a woman facing left stands on the lake shore. She has long dark hair pushed to the back, light brown skin, dark eyebrows and high cheekbones. She stares forward with a look of determination on her face. She wears a brown and black woven shawl, a mid-calf length skirt of the same material, and dark boots. A large open weave basket holding a piece of wood hangs down her back, supported by a decorated strap wrapped across her forehead. To the woman’s right at the water’s edge is a wooden canoe. Beyond, is the green-blue lake and mist shrouded mountains in the distance.

title: [Sign] Flute in the Forest Wayside #107s

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Flute in the Forest Wayside. 1 minute A color image of a hollow tree and flying birds fills the entire panel on this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside. Text on the left reads: Flute in the Forest. Shaped by wind and fire, this fluted western redcedar snag remains standing because of its long-enduring buttressed base. Snags play an important role in the forest ecosystem. Vaux’s swifts nest exclusively in hollow trees. Owls, bats, flying squirrels, martens and wood ducks all find shelter in large snags. The image shows the wide dark opening in a tan tree trunk from which about a dozen birds are exiting. The birds have a cigar shaped body that is mostly brown but with a paler belly. They have round dark eyes, a short pointed black beak, and short squared off pale tail feathers. Their arched wings are long, each about twice the length of the bird’s body.

title: [Sign] Forest Disturbances Wayside #258l

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Forest Disturbances Wayside. 30 seconds On the left side and across the bottom of this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel is a black and white drawing of a choppy river with waves across its entire surface. On the left, a group of trees stand in water that has overtaken the banks. Text at the top right reads: Forest Disturbances. You have seen how the forest responds to the forces of windstorm and wandering river. On a slightly higher terrace you can walk the three-quarter mile Hall of Mosses Trail through an older, more stable section of rain forest.

title: [Sign] Forest Elders Wayside #107n

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Forest Elders Wayside. 1 minute A color image of a forest fills this entire three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel. Text on the left reads: Forest Elders. Ancient trees, grand and majestic, contribute to the wealth of wildlife habitats found here. Large standing dead trees and downed logs provide homes and feeding sites for dozens of animals. The mixture of different species and ages of trees creates a multi-layered canopy that shelters wildlife from rain, wind and sun. These essential characteristics of old-growth community may take 250 years to develop. In the foreground of the image on the left is the wide base and lower trunk section of a large tree. It has rough textured dark brown bark, speckled with green moss and is labeled, Douglas-fir. To the right and further back in the center of the forest is a tree labeled Western redcedar. Its bark is reddish-brown and stringy in texture. On the right, is the trunk of a Western hemlock, its bark grey and rough. On the forest floor, green ferns grown between pieces of scattered wood.

title: [Sign] Forest Fire Scars Wayside #40a

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside informational sign.
audioDescription: 232 words Forest Fire Scars. 2 minutes Along the 2-foot-high stone wall edging the visitor center patio overlooking a sloping meadow, a valley with dense tall green pine trees, and layers of overlapping mountain ridges in the distance sits this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel. A black and white drawing on the left shows two mountain ranges, the one in the foreground labeled, Long Ridge. On the face of the mountain slope are irregular patterns of black and white. Text at the top right reads: Forest Fire Scars. Across the valley below you the lighter-colored vegetation defines the boundaries of old burns, which have occurred over the last two centuries. Lightning probably sparked most of the fires. Gradually at this elevation, new trees re-covered the ridge. The landscape’s pattern of colors, different shades of green, can be hieroglyphics of natural disasters, part of the forest’s life-cycle. Other scars mark the slopes: the narrow, vertical clearings of winter avalanche, and the landslide above the lower end of Long Ridge. Below the text is a black and white drawing of a man in profile from the waist up. He has a dark beard and moustache and wears a hard hat and jacket. Strapped to his back is a tank with a hose that is attached to a sprayer the man holds in his right hand. In the background, trees grow on a steep slope.

title: [Sign] Forest Healers Wayside #107m

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Forest Healers Wayside. 1 minute. A color image of a two tree stumps in the forest fills this entire three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel. Text on the right reads: Forest Healers. Red alders have reclaimed this skid road, a relic of past logging activity. Alders are pioneer species on distributed soils. These quick-growing trees add valuable nitrogen and humus to forest soils and prevent erosion. Eventually, western hemlock and western redcedars will tower above these short-lived hardwoods. Several centuries from now, a mature old-growth forest could stand here. The image shows two short, dark tree stumps, one on the left and one on the right, partially covered with green moss. The top of each stump is flat and horizontal exposing the reddish- brown wood on the inside. On the right-side edge are jagged, vertical splinters ripped from the tree as it fell. Reddish-brown wood chips are piled up at the foot of each stump. On the forest floor, green ferns grow around remnants of fallen trees. In the background, a sparse forest of tall and short trees is shrouded in a gray-white mist, a blue-sky peeking through.

title: [Sign] From Mountains to Sea Wayside #54

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: From Mountains to Sea Wayside. 2 minutes A color, panoramic photograph of the forested valley and layered mountain landscape before you fills most of panel on this three foot tall, angled metal wayside. Fifteen locations are labeled on the photograph. Text below the image reads: From Mountains to Sea. In the valley below, Morse Creek carries snowmelt from the Olympic Mountains to Port Angeles and the Strait of Juan de Fuca. Rivers and streams born in the mountains provide essential water to plant and animal communities in the park as well as residents in the surrounding lowlands. When skies are clear, look for Puget Sound and the snowy Cascade Mountains in the distance. From left to right, the location labels read: Sunset Point. Trail to Klahhane Ridge. Mt. Angeles, 6,454 feet. Hurricane Ridge Road. Klahhane Ridge. Rocky Peak 6,218 feet. Strait of Juan de Fuca. Cascade Mountains in the background. Port Townsend. Glacier Peak 10,541 feet. Morse Creek. Puget Sound. Blue Mountain 6,010 feet. Deer Park. Steeple Rock 5,567 feet

title: [Sign] Giant Dimensions Wayside #255g

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Giant Dimensions Wayside. 30 seconds On the left side and across the bottom of this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel is a black and white drawing showing four views of a tree falling to the right. From its upright twelve o’clock position, it tilts to the one o’clock position, then two o’clock, and finally at three o’clock, it is on the ground. Text at the top right reads: A Giant’s Dimensions. The trunk is 190 feet long. But this huge trunk is only a portion of the originally standing tree. In the rain forest Sitka spruces average 220 feet tall, and some grow to over 300 feet.

title: [Sign] Glaciers in Peril Wayside #40d

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Glaciers in Peril. 3 minutes Along the 2-foot-high stone wall edging the visitor center patio overlooking a meadow, valley, and mountain landscape, is a three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel with two sets of black and white photographs comparing snow abundance on glaciers over time. Text at the top left reads: Glaciers in Peril. Abundant snow and cool summers create ideal conditions for Pacific Northwest glaciers. These rivers of ice, once considered permanent, are disappearing in our warming climate. A healthy glacier receives enough snow in winter to offset its summer melt. Now this sustaining snow often falls as rain. Olympic Mountain glaciers lost over 30 percent of their surface area from the 1970s to 2010. Blue Glacier retreated three football fields in length and lost over 74 feet of thickness, the height of a seven-story building, between 1987 and 2010. Some smaller glaciers in the park have completely disappeared. Glaciers have carved and adorned these mountains for millennia. Their meltwater feeds rivers that nurture life downstream, from forests to fish to people. As we continue to change our climate, the choices we make today will affect the future of these icy Olympic icons. To the right of the text, are two small, stacked photographs with the caption, Lillian Glacier, near Obstruction Point, was nearly gone by 2010. The image on top dated 1905 shows a mountain area with a large glacier filling in a wide bowl-shaped expanse between two peaks. In the bottom photo dated 2010 the bowl-shaped area is empty except for a few areas where snow clings to the sides of the bowl. Below the text are two larger side-by side black and white photographs showing a wide mountain range with Blue Glacier on the left and Carrie Glacier on the right. The photo on the left dated 1889 has an arrow pointing to the end of Carrie Glacier. In the second photo dated 2009, the arrow remains in place, but the end of Carrie Glacier has retreated up the mountain. Blue Glacier has also been reduced in size. A caption reads: From Hurricane Ridge, you can see Blue Glacier on Mount Olympus and Carrie Glacier to the southwest. The historic late summer photograph of Carrie Glacier shows a thick, healthy glacier. By 2009 the glacier had thinned dramatically and retreated far upslope.

title: [Sign] Goatsbeard Lichen Wayside 57

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Goatsbeard Lichen Wayside. 30 seconds On the left side of this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel is a black and white drawing of a deer facing right, in profile, extending its long neck to reach lichen hanging down from a tree branch. Text at the top right reads: Goatsbeard Lichen. The wispy, pale-green threads take nothing from the tree. Goatsbeard fastens to boughs but produces its own food. Because the bunched firs hold humidity, the lichen thrives. Occasional browse for deer. Below the text is a small black and white close-up drawing of long hair-like strands of lichen hanging from a tree branch.

title: [Sign] Green Draperies Wayside #258n

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Green Draperies Wayside. 1 minute On the left side of this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel is a black and white drawing of a moss-covered tree, its branches draped with hanging moss. Text at the top right reads: Green Draperies. Some rain forest trees are more luxuriantly clothed than others. Notice the rough bark and spreading boughs of bigleaf maple. The clinging mosses and moss-like plants don’t drain their host but catch moisture and minerals from the breeze. Sometimes the added weight breaks branches. Below the text is a drawing of a Bigleaf maple leaf hanging on the tip of a stem. It has five lobes with jagged edges.
