Beginning at the base of the leaf, the two smallest lobes extend out to each side like open wings, then two larger wing-like lobes extend downward. The fifth and largest lobe fills the tip of the leaf.

title: [Sign] Greener Slopes Wayside #56

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Greener Slopes Wayside. 1 minute On the left side of this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel is a black and white drawing of a mountain slope with trees on the back side and large bare areas on the front side. Text on the right reads: Greener Slopes. At this altitude climate may differ from slope to slope. Notice how plant and tree growth responds to variations in steepness, moisture, and exposure to wind and sun. Either trail on the left returns to the lodge. The short upper trail on the right heads to a spectacular view. The lower right trail goes to Mount Angeles (2 ¼ miles).

title: [Sign] Groundcover Wayside #258m

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Groundcover Wayside. 1 minute On the left side of this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel is a black and white drawing of a section of ground covered with plant life. Text at the top right reads: Groundcover. There is almost no bare ground. Herbs, mosses, ferns and shrubs grow so dense they leave little room for new sprouts. In their struggle for growing space, young spruce trees are starting life on a unique nursery, a nearby fallen log. In the drawing, a spruce tree growing atop a nurse log, stands above four different plants. From left to right, Horsetail, with its whorled branches of thin leaves on a main center stem. Salmonberry shrub, with three leaves at the tip of each stem and round raspberry-like berries. Sword fern, its long thin fronds spread wide like a seven-pointed star, and Water parsley, with an A-shaped stem having many leaves and a second stem with a cluster of leaves at the tip. In the bottom center is a black and white close up drawing of Oxalis, a plant with three heart shaped leaves at the tip of a stem.

title: [Sign] Growing Gradually Wayside #59

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Growing Gradually Wayside. 1 minute On the left side of this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel is a black and white drawing of tall, A-shaped pine trees, their limbs heavy with snow. To the right of and in front of the trees is a low-lying rounded mound of pine limbs and needles covered in snow. Text at the top right reads: Growing Gradually. Bent by snow. Pruned by mountain winds. Stunted by brief summers. Subalpine firs only six inches thick might be over a hundred years old.

title: [Sign] Hall of Mosses Trail Wayside #255a

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Hall of Mosses Trail Wayside. 45 seconds On the left side of this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel is a map of the Hall of Mosses Trail with the text, You Are Here, pointing to a location in the lower right corner. Text at the top reads: Hall of Mosses Trail. Ascending this bank beginning the ¾ mile loop, you have climbed to a higher river terrace, and are now entering an older part of the forest. Here there is a primeval spirit—moldering logs, trunks shaggy with moss, and giant trees that seem old as the earth. Below the text is a drawing of the base of a tree, its thick finger like roots rising from the ground to quickly form a solid trunk.

title: [Sign] Hall of Mosses Wayside #255c

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Hall of Mosses Wayside. 1 minute On the right side of the trail before it passes underneath an arching branch of a moss-covered tree, is a three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel. Filling the left side is a black and white drawing of a mass of thick, thread-like moss attached to a tree limb. Text at the top right reads: Hall of Mosses. Lush beards of clubmoss are attached to boughs but feed only on air and light. The rain forest atmosphere supplies enough moisture and wind-borne nutrients. Certain trees like these bigleaf maples support denser clusters of air plants or epiphytes (lichens and hanging mosses.) Compare different types of limbs, available sunlight, and relative dampness. Please stay on the trail. Below the text, a black and white drawing shows a wider view of a tree, each branch draped in long strands of moss.

title: [Sign] High Ridge Trail Wayside #51

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: High Ridge Trail Wayside. 1 minute A map of the High Ridge Trail fills the right side of this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel. The trail is marked by a green dashed and dotted line, the dashes representing a paved trail and the dots representing a dirt trail. Only the first one-third of the trail is paved. The text, “You Are Here,” indicates your location. Text on the left reads: High Ridge Trail. This 0.5-mile loop climbs nearly 200 feet to a dry, wind-swept ridge where wildflowers hug the ground and trees are stunted. A short spur trail ends at Sunrise Point where clear days offer panoramic views. With less moisture-giving snow, this ridge can be a challenging place for plants to survive. Please help by staying on the trail.

title: [Sign] High Ridge Trail Wayside #52

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: High Ridge Trail Wayside. 1 minute A map of the High Ridge Trail fills the right side of this three-foot-tall angled, metal wayside panel. The trail is marked by a green dashed and dotted line, the dashes representing a paved trail and the dots representing a dirt trail. Only the first one-third of the trail is paved. The text, “You Are Here,” indicates your location. Text on the left reads: High Ridge Trail. This 0.5-mile loop climbs nearly 200 feet to a dry, wind-swept ridge where wildflowers hug the ground and trees are stunted. A short spur trail ends at Sunrise Point where clear days offer panoramic views. With less moisture-giving snow, this ridge can be a challenging place for plants to survive. Please help by staying on the trail.

title: [Sign] How Big Do They Grow Wayside #255f

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: How Big Do They Grow Wayside. 45 seconds On the left side of this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel is a black and white drawing of an A-shaped spruce tree with branches of drooping needles. Text at the top right reads: How Big Do They Grow? Pace the length of this fallen Sitka spruce and guess its height as a living tree. In the heavy annual rainfall and fog off the Pacific, vegetation in this valley can reach giant proportions. Below the text is a black and white drawing of a white cloud with a curvy top and flat bottom above a forest growing on a slope. Dense lines depicting falling rain extend from the bottom of the cloud to the forest.

title: [Sign] Layers of the Forest Wayside #258g

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Layers of the Forest Wayside. 1 minute On the left side and across the bottom of this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel is a black and white drawing of a section of forest. On the left, a tree stands above ferns, lichen and moss on the forest floor. Spanning the scene, the trunk of a fallen tree lays on the ground, small trees growing on its top. Trees with branches draped in hanging moss are in the background. Text at the top right reads: Layers of the Forest. Look through many levels of life: matted groundcover, festooned maples, conifers looming high above. The different layers are thickly interwoven. On a fallen moss-covered log young Sitka spruces try to survive the competition. Clubmoss clings to bigleaf maple boughs, and the floor is strewn with lettuce lichen blown down from treetops.

title: [Sign] Lonesome Hatchery Wayside #263a
listingDescription: Quileute Fisheries Department

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Quileute Fisheries Department
audioDescription: Lonesome Hatchery Wayside. 3 minutes On this tall panel, text reads: Lonesome Creek Hatchery. Quileute Fisheries Department. This facility supplies fresh spring water to the Quileute Indian Tribe’s fish hatchery at nearby Lonesome Creek. Each year the tribe raises thousands of salmon and steelhead for release into the wild streams and rivers of the North Coast. The Quileute people have long depended on strong runs of fish for their survival. At the top of the panel is a black, white and red drawing of a fish in profile, its head facing left. It has an arched back and a tail that curves down and under its body. The entire body, including fins and tail, is outlined by a bold black line. The head of the fish is mostly black. It has a white dot at the tip of the nose followed by a horizontal white and red U-shaped design across the top of the nose. A red, four-point star-shaped eye is encircled by a white oval line. Under the eye, a red and white J-shaped design curves down the cheek and along the jaw line ending below the mouth with its long, red tongue Behind the head, the body of the fish is mostly white. It is segmented into sections, the first a D-shaped area defined by a thick black line. Inside, a thin red line follows the inside curve of the D-shape ending at the bottom with a row of seven vertical black lines topped by an upward curving red line. In the center is an eye outlined in red with a round, black pupil. Above and below this section on the outside of the body are fins. On the back of the fish is a white fin with a red elongated M-shape in the center. On its belly, the white fin is mostly filled in by a red design with a white four-point star shape in the center. The next section follows the curve of the body. A thin, red line, begins at the top and bends downward, ending above the tail fins. A row of red dots follows the curve of this line. Along the belly, are three red upward arched markings. The final sections are two, white, side-by-side tail fins, both oval shaped and pointed at the tips. Inside each fin is a red circle segmented into four pieces creating a white four-point star in the center.

title: [Sign] Lower Story Plants Wayside #254d

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Lower Story Plants Wayside. 45 seconds On the left side and center of this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel is a green and white drawing of low-growing forest plants. From left to right, a bulbous burl encircles a section of tree trunk. A Salmonberry shrub with many leaves and berries grows near the tall fronds of Sword ferns. The mottled colored trunks of Red alder rise above pillows of mosses growing low to the ground, and the thin, crooked trunks of Vine maple reach out above the forest floor. Text at the top right reads: Lower Story Plants The rainforest has many levels of green. Often the lower story is elk food, vine maple leaves, and low tree branches. Bigleaf maples filter the light through arching moss-draped boughs.

title: [Sign] Marymere Falls Trail Wayside #100a

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Marymere Falls Trail Wayside. 1 minute In this six-foot-tall upright two-legged brown metal frame is a large informational panel with a green map across the top showing the black dashed line for the Marymere Falls Trail. Text below reads: Marymere Falls Trail. Through more than a half-mile of lowland forest the trail climbs gradually, then steeply for the last eight-mile to Marymere Falls. Average hiking time round trip is one and one-half hours. The path takes you to the edge of the Olympic wilderness. From a human-shaped world you are about to step into terrain dominated by other forces. There are five other short, easy Touch of Wilderness hikes in the park at Staircase, Pioneer Visitor Center, Soleduck, La Push and Ozette. Each trail enters a different environment: coastal, river and lowland forests, waterfalls and tidepools. To the left of the text is a black and white drawing of a tall waterfall cascading down a dark rocky slope to a pool below. Below the text, is the black and white pine branch and pinecone graphic logo for touch of wilderness.

title: [Sign] Meadow Hill Wayside #63
listingDescription: Wayside same as #41 and #58

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Meadow Hill Wayside. 1 minute At this trailhead is a five-foot-tall upright wooden frame with two informational panels. The panel on the left has an illustration of a person feeding a deer. Text reads: Keep Wildlife Wild. Human food spoils wild animals. They lose their desire for natural foods by becoming beggars and easy prey for car wheels and predators. No matter how appealing, all park animals are potentially dangerous. They may bite or scratch and can spread disease. Please don’t feed the animals. The panel on the right has an illustration of a hiking boot with deeps treads about to step on grass, wildflowers, a hidden mouse nest, and an adult mouse. Text reads: Meadow Damage. Your feet are a threat to meadows. Without realizing, people crush fragile plants and flatten nests and small creatures hidden in the grass. Help preserve the meadows. Please stay on maintained trails. Shortcuts leave lasting scars.

title: [Sign] Meadow Invasion Wayside #49

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Meadow Invasion Wayside. 1 minute On this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel along the Hurricane Ridge Loop Trail are two green and white side-by side computer simulation images showing changes to the mountainside landscape over time. Text across the top reads: Meadow Invasion. Change is constant. Imagine this scene as a silent movie spanning a century. Research shows that wetter summers beginning in the 1940s allowed subalpine firs to invade open meadows in this area. In 100 years, this scene may be a dense forest. In national parks, processes like climate, wind, fire, and avalanches are the directors. The result is a dynamic landscape where the line between meadow and forest is in constant flux. Below the text, the image on the left, dated 1945, shows the mountainside with one dense area of trees and several thin lines of trees. The image on the right, dated 2045, shows the same mountainside but the thin lines of trees have now filled in creating larger areas of dense forest spanning the hillside.

title: [Sign] Meadow Recovery Wayside #47

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Meadow Recovery Wayside. 1 minute Along the Hurricane Ridge Loop Trail in an area devoid of ground cover is a three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel with two black and white drawings, one the feet of a hiker and the other, a footprint pattern from a hiking boot. Text at the top right reads: Meadow Recovery. This dirt patch is many years old. In thin soil, drying winds, unfiltered sun and summer frost, meadow plants thrive, but grow very slowly. When trampled they cannot survive. Below the text, is a two-dimensional drawing showing the tread pattern from the sole of a hiking boot. In the center, diamond-shaped treads cover the heel, ball, and arch of the foot, while a pattern comprised of a small circle attached to three lines edges the entire sole. On the left, a drawing shows the lower legs and feet of a person walking on a bare trail. The person wears hiking boots and is shown mid-stride to reveal the deep, patterned treads on the soles of the boots.

title: [Sign] Meadow Wildlife Wayside #60

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Meadow Wildlife Wayside. 1 minute On this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel overlooking a meadow landscape are two black and white drawings of wildlife. Text at the top right reads: Meadow Wildlife. In a kinship of survival, the plants scatter seeds, meadow voles harvest them, a gliding kestrel (sparrow hawk) snatches a vole from the grass. At midday most meadow animals are inactive. Your best chance of spotting them is dawn or dusk. Below the text is a cut-away view drawing of a small section of meadow, above and below ground. A mouse sized vole with a long snout, crouches in tall grass next to a tunnel leading to an underground burrow, a horizonal void in the earth. To the left of the text, a drawing of a Kestrel with long tail feathers and black spotted wings, is perched sideways on a branch eating a small rodent held tight in its talons.

title: [Sign] Mini Trail Trailhead Wayside #254f
listingDescription: Perhaps the shortest trail in Olympic, the Mini Trail takes you into the rain forest with just a few steps. Perfect for little ones and anyone else with love for the forest but limited mobility.

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Perhaps the shortest trail in Olympic, the Mini Trail takes you into the rain forest with just a few steps. Perfect for little ones and anyone else with love for the forest but limited mobility.
audioDescription: Mini Trail Trailhead Wayside. 90 seconds At the Hoh River Trailhead, the Mini Trail branches off to the right. At its trailhead is a three-foot-tall, angled wayside panel. On the right side of the panel is a map of the accessible Mini Trail marked by a brown looping line. Branching off the Mini Trail near the top left of the loop is the Hall of Mosses Trail in green and at the top of the loop the Spruce Trail in gray. The trail, if started here, will end at the Visitor Center. Text on the right reads: Mini Trail. Paved and level, only one-quarter mile long, this loop trail opens a window on the rain forest. As you explore, consider what qualities make this forest unique: size of trees, types of plants, the climate, mosses, the mood of the place. Below the text is a green and white illustration of a Sword Fern with many fronds, some lying flat to the ground, some extending upward. The trail passes through a lush forest of young and old trees, many draped with green moss. Ferns and other low growing plants create a carpet of green on either side of the trail.

title: [Sign] Momentary Meadows Wayside #107r

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Momentary Meadows Wayside. 2 minutes A color image of an old homestead fills the entire panel on this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside. Text in the bottom right corner reads: Momentary Meadow. Why is this meadow here? Cleared as a homestead pasture in the early 1900s, the meadow is kept open by grazing Columbia black-tailed deer. Such openings are brief interludes in the life of the forest. Along the meadow’s edge, young Douglass-fir trees have already begun to reclaim this site. The image shows a green field in the foreground with rows of plants, bordered on the left by a dirt road that curves up, then to the right, ending in front of a horizontal row of buildings at the top of the panel. Near the buildings on the left, a brown automobile is parked facing left. Its rectangular body has a tall, square drivers’ compartment in the center and large arched bumpers above black wheels with white sidewall. Behind the auto, is a house with white wooden siding and a large front door flanked by windows. Its A-frame roof is topped with dormers on either side of the peak and a chimney. A small white shed with a peaked roof sits beside the house near two brown barn structures with wooden fencing. A green lawn, shrubs and trees grow around the buildings. Tall pine trees stand behind the homestead, and in the distance, are tree covered hills.

title: [Sign] Moments in Time Trail Wayside #107a

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Moments in Time Trail Wayside. 1 minute The color image on this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel is a lake with still water flanked on the right by a hill with tall dark pine trees and on the left and rear by the slope of a tall mountain. Text reads: Moments in Time Trail. Shaped by time and water, Barnes Point punctuates the south shore of glacially carved Lake Crescent. This quiet delta, with its mantle of old-growth forest, continues to grow and change. For thousands of years, American Indians lived and traded here. Later, settlers homesteaded this area and entrepreneurs developed hotels and lodges. Today, Lake Crescent is protected in Olympic National Park for all to enjoy. As you walk this trail, you follow the footsteps of many who shaped this landscape. This accessible one-half mile loop has several entrances and exits. A trail map is provided below and at four other entry points. Please return it after use. These interpretive exhibits were provided by the Rob Reed and Lena Sharpe Memorial Foundation.

title: [Sign] Moments in Time Wayside #107h

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Moments in Time Trail Wayside. 1 minute The color image on this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel is a lake with still water flanked on the right by a hill with tall dark pine trees and on the left and rear by the slope of a tall mountain. Text reads: Moments in Time Trail. Shaped by time and water, Barnes Point punctuates the south shore of glacially carved Lake Crescent. This quiet delta, with its mantle of old-growth forest, continues to grow and change. For thousands of years, American Indians lived and traded here. Later, settlers homesteaded this area and entrepreneurs developed hotels and lodges. Today, Lake Crescent is protected in Olympic National Park for all to enjoy. As you walk this trail, you follow the footsteps of many who shaped this landscape. This accessible one-half mile loop has several entrances and exits. A trail map is provided below and at four other entry points. Please return it after use. These interpretive exhibits were provided by the Rob Reed and Lena Sharpe Memorial Foundation.

title: [Sign] Mountain Travelers Wayside #40c

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Mountain Travelers Wayside. 2 minutes Along the 2-foot-high stone wall edging the visitor center patio overlooking a meadow, valley, and mountain landscape, a black and white drawing of two right-facing women in profile, fills the left side of a three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel. The woman on the left wears a black and white hooded jacket that extends to her waist and a dark colored mid-calf-length skirt. A basket hangs down her back, supported by a strap that wraps across her forehead. She carries a brown and black satchel. She is barefoot. The second woman wears similar clothing with the addition of a long, brown fur draped across the front of her body. She holds a walking stick in her right hand. She is also barefoot. The women stand upon a green and white section of ground. Plants rise up in the foreground of the image and a mountain range spans the background underneath a blue sky. Text on the left side of the panel reads: Mountain Travelers. Why did you come to the mountains? People have been traveling to these peaks for millennia. Ancestors of local tribes hunted elk and deer and collected plants for food, fiber and medicine across these ridges. Tribal elders tell of using the mountains as travel routes, and for spiritual and social pursuits. People have come to these slopes for centuries for the same reasons that visitors journey to Hurricane Ridge today. Wilderness that provided survival necessities like food and tools also nourished the soul. The mountains continue to offer solitude and renewal to anyone who travels here.

title: [Sign] National Treasure Wayside #149

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: National Treasure Wayside. 3 minutes On the edge of the parking area lined with horizontal logs stands this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel. A color illustration that assembles, in one scene, many of the plants and animals living in this old-growth forest habitat before you fills the panel. Text on the top left reads: National Treasure. Mingle with the centuries-old giants of Olympic National Park’s old-growth forests and become a part of history. Many of these western hemlock and Douglas-fir trees were thriving before Columbus set sail in 1492. They greeted guests at Sol Duc Resort in 1912 and stood stately when Olympic National Park was established in 1938. From seedlings to 750-year-old sentinels, this multi-layered forest harbors countless residents, from black bears and banana slugs to birds of many songs. In death, old growth takes on vital new roles. Standing snags serve as nesting sites for owls and small mammals. Fallen trees become nurse logs where saplings can sprout above the crowded forest floor. Decomposing leaves and logs provide refuge for salamanders, beetles and a bustling unseen world. This magnificent old-growth forest offers adventure and solace for wilderness enthusiasts from around the globe. It is a finely tuned system that ties the past to the present. Will this national treasure be a link to our future?” The illustration is a ground level view of an old growth forest. On the forest floor, a fallen tree dominates the foreground. It is covered with moss, white wildflowers, and plants with red berries. A snake, with its red tongue extended, slithers up the side of the tree. On top, are two yellow slugs with black spots and antenna, a black and orange bird, and two small pine tree saplings. Attached to the side of the tree are orange and white shelf-like fungi. On the ground, a small brown and white squirrel holds a pinecone. Next to the fallen tree on the left, the head of a small grey animal with dark eyes, short snout, and small rounded ears, peeks out from behind a moss-covered tree stump. In the forest background, a black bear walks by a tall plant with wide green leaves and red flowers. A brown elk with two five-pointed antlers stands near the wide base of tree. A brown and whited spotted owl is perched at the top of a dead tree, while below, a black and white woodpecker with a bright red head, clings to the bark. A small bird sits on its nest on a high moss-covered tree branch as a brown bird flies into the forest. On the left, a group of hikers walk through the forest.

title: [Sign] Night Shadows Wayside #147

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Night Shadows Wayside. 2 minutes At this roadside pull off, horizontal logs line the edge of the parking area. In the grass opposite one of the logs, is the three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside. A color illustration assembling many of the plants and animals that live in the forest habitat before you, fills the panel. Text on the left reads: Night Shadows. Enter Olympic’s old-growth forest at twilight and share the darkening hours. A Columbia black-tailed deer unveils her silhouette through the evening curtain. Elusive cougars stalk deer by scent and sound. Songs of owls and frogs quicken the air. Fiery shadows leap from tree to tree as the setting sun kindles an intricate night world. One night creature, the northern spotted owl, needs old growth for survival. This threatened species nests in broken treetops and trunk hollows far above the forest floor. Flying squirrels, favored prey of spotted owls, scurry down to the forest floor to dig for truffles and spread the spores of future fungi. At this moment of opportunity, a vigilant spotted owl swoops down to snag a squirrel. Northern spotted owls, flying squirrels and truffles weave a unique tapestry in the old-growth forest night. What other vital connections can you discover? The illustration is a ground level view of a forest of tall trees, its floor covered in a lush carpet of green ferns, moss and decaying wood. Above the ground is an owl in flight with outstretched, upward curved brown wings edged with individual finger-like feathers and fanned out tail feathers. It has a white and brown chest and round head with two large dark round eyes and a thin white downward curved beak. A thin line of dark feathers shaped like a heart encircles its face. Clawed feet hang from its legs. On the ground, a grayish-brown squirrel crouches near a fallen tree, and a brown deer with large ears stands sideways as a brown cougar walks nearby.

title: [Sign] North Wilderness Coast Hike Wayside #164c

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Wild Coast Wayside. 1 minute Be advised. Driftwood may be scattered on the beach blocking clear access to the wayside. On this 4-foot-tall upright wayside panel, text in the bottom right corner reads: Wild Coast. The sea makes the rules. Hiking this long stretch of wilderness beach, you may have to climb headlands, cross numerous streams, enter a cocoon of fog, or follow animal tracks in the sand. There are no sheltered lagoons. If you ignore the tides, storm waves may trap you against a sheer cliff. Find solitude, or a whale’s jawbone, or a kind of bird you’ve never seen before. Filling the top half of the panel is a blue and white drawing of a wave hitting the rocky shoreline below high tree topped hills. A sea stack is offshore. In the bottom left corner, a blue and white drawing shows a hiker holding a hiking pole while traversing a jumble of rocks at the base of a hill, the ocean in the background. DONE – EG ..................Column Break..................Site Number: 164c – North Wilderness Coast Hike Wayside 152 words North Wilderness Coast Hike Wayside. 1 minute A map of the North Wilderness Coast Hike fills this 4-foot-tall upright wayside panel. The land is brown, and the ocean is blue. Ozette Lake also in blue is inland. The trail hugs the coast from Rialto Beach in the south to Cape Alava in the north. The text, You Are Here, marks your current location at Rialto Beach. In between the beginning and end of the trail, are marked locations for Hole-in-the-Wall, Cape Johnson, Norwegian Memorial, Yellow Banks, and Sand Point. Inland trails are marked by dashed lines at Sand Point and Cape Alava. The Ozette Ranger Station at the northern tip of Ozette Lake is marked with a Ranger and tent logo. Text reads: Caution: If no headland trail exists, wait until low tide before rounding Point. Leashed pets allowed only from Rialto Beach to Ellen Creek. Backcountry permits required for overnight camping.

title: [Sign] Nurselogs Wayside #255d

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Nurselogs Wayside. 45 seconds On the left side of this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel is a green and white drawing of a small pine tree growing atop the trunk of a moss-covered fallen tree. Text at the top right reads: Nurselogs. When a big tree falls it can provide a stage for new life. Hemlock and spruce seedlings, unable to survive on the tangled forest floor, absorb minerals, moisture and warmth from the decaying trunk. Even on this perch competition is fierce. Only a few seedlings last. After their roots reach soil, new trees often seem to stand on stilts as the nurselog moulders away. Below the text is a drawing labeled, Nurselog colonnade, showing the roots of a tree draped over a decaying downed tree.

title: [Sign] Olympic Elk Wayside #254c

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Olympic Elk Wayside. 1 minute On the left side of this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel is a green and white drawing of an elk standing in a forest clearing. It has a large set of antlers with six points on each antler beam. The fur on its chest and head is darker than the rest of its body. Text at the top right reads: Olympic Elk. You might not see them now, but all around there is evidence of the resident elk herd. Look for tracks in the soft ground — elk have trampled a path near here. Observe cropped-off shoots along the trail. Despite the lush growing conditions, browsing elk keep the forest floor relatively open Below the text, a drawing of a left and a right Elk track shows the split hooved characteristic of an Elks foot that resembles a circle split down the center. The length of each side of the split is about twice its width.

title: [Sign] Our Coastal Heritage Wayside #170b

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Our Coastal Heritage Wayside. 1 minute A blue and white drawing of two people at the edge of the ocean each carrying a long-handled net, fills the left side of this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel. Text at the top right reads: Our Coastal Heritage. This coastal strand with its beaches, intertidal life, and offshore seastacks attracts increasing numbers of people each year who enjoy scenic vistas and recreation. However, damage is occurring to the intertidal areas from people trampling and collecting tidepool life. Enjoy, appreciate, and help us preserve this irreplaceable treasure by not collecting any specimens from the intertidal zone. The store at Kalaloch sells bait for those who wish to surf fish. In midsummer you can catch smelt with a net. Below the text is a drawing of two types of fish. The largest, labeled Perch, has a wide oval body that is dark across the top with a white side and belly. A spined fin runs along most of its back with a shorter fin along its underside. Smaller fish called Smelt are long and thin and about one-sixth the size of the Perch. Their bodies are dark on top and white on the sides and belly.

title: [Sign] Plant On Plant Wayside #258a

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Plant On Plant Wayside. 45 seconds On the left side of this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel is a black and white drawing of a tree trunk topped with branches draped in moss. On the trunk, the long fronds of Licorice fern hang down. Text at the top right reads: Plant on Plant. The atmosphere of the rain forest is so fertile that some plants thrive on air. Dining on moisture and nutrients from rain and windborne particles, clubmoss and licorice fern fasten to trunks and branches but do not harm their hosts. Below the text, a drawing shows the side view of a tree trunk and branch with moss of varying lengths hanging from the branch like an uneven curtain of ragged fabric.

title: [Sign] Primeval Fir Wayside #107L

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Primeval Fir Wayside. 1 minute A color image of a tree falling in the forest fills this entire three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel located in front of a weathered, decaying stump of a large tree. Text on the right reads: Primeval Fir. Before it crashed to the ground, this Douglas-fir measured 35 feet in circumference. Can you guess how tall it grew? Across the trail, its contemporary still stands. Both trees took root in the ashes of fires that burned here 500 to 700 years ago. Douglas-fir seedlings often sprout after fire or wind has swept through the forest. The image shows a stormy forest scene with heavy rain falling diagonally. On the left, the trunk of a dark brown tree has split away from its base and is dropping to the right. At the break, the inside of the tree is revealed, its tan wood splintering under the force of the collapsing trunk. In the background, stand trees with long, thin branches and green needles.

title: [Sign] Protect Salmon Wayside #139

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Protect Salmon Wayside. 1 minute On the left side of the path leading to the amphitheater stands this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel. Filling the panel is a color illustration showing a cutaway view of a creek with salmon. Text reads: Protect Salmon. Please Don’t build dams or disturb the creek. Any disturbance to the gravel in this creek can be fatal to salmon. Coho salmon assume many different forms throughout their life. In the fall, adult salmon return from the ocean to spawn and deposit their eggs in the gravel. The young emerge in the spring and eventually swim back to the ocean beginning the cycle again. In the illustration, red salmon eggs deposited on the gravelly creek bottom are hatching. Several young orange-red salmon with yolk sacs attached to their bodies swim above the gravel in the blue green water. Other small salmon swim nearby, their egg sacs gone, and in the background, two adult salmon with spotted backs and red sides swim side-by-side.

title: [Sign] Pulse of the River Wayside #128a

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Pulse of the River Wayside. 3 minutes Half-buried logs laid horizontally define the edge between this narrow parking area along the river and a narrow grass surface picnic area with a table. At the far end of the grassy section is a three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel with a brightly colored illustration that assembles, in one scene, many of the plants and animals living in this river habitat. Green ferns, pillows of yellow-green mosses, and plants with purple berries grow low to the ground. Bright red shrubs growing beneath green pine trees and deciduous trees with yellow, red, and green leaves line the riverbanks. Slim gray river otters and brown beavers with rounded flat tails are on the bank and in the water. A brown frog hides among fallen leaves while a gray bird pulls a worm from the ground. A blue, white and red Kingfisher perches on a branch, a brown and white Osprey watches for fish from a dead tree branch, a red-headed duck with a gray body stands on a river rock, and a bald eagle with a white head and white tailfeathers, flies above the river, its long black wings extended. In the river, red and yellow trout keep to a deep pool, and schools of salmon with bright red markings swim upstream. On the top left of the panel text reads: Pulse of the River. The Sol Duc River launches its conversation with the landscape at 5,000 feet near High Divide. A trickle of mountain water feeds tiny rivulets that merge into streams. The route steepens, waters plunge down hanging paths carved by Ice Age glaciers. Fallen old-growth leaves, logs and branches change the course of the river, crafting pools that provide crucial habitat for beaver, mink, river otter, salmon and salamanders. Tumbling rocks and abrasive sediments create fresh rhythms as the river flows to sea. The Sol Duc River begins and ends with gentleness, but its overriding temperament is vigorous. It is rarely hushed, never resting in one pool for long. Time is its vehicle, change a constant companion. Text in the lower right reads: Coho Cadence. A unique stock of coho salmon with unusual behavior inhabits the Sol Duc River. While most stocks of coho swim up western Washington rivers in October and November, when water levels are high, summer coho enter the Sol Duc in July when stream flows are low. They spawn from late September to November. Winter steelhead and cutthroat trout also swim in these silvery waters.

title: [Sign] Queets River Trail Wayside #200a

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Queets River Trail Wayside. 2 minutes On this upright interpretive panel, text at the bottom reads: Queets River Trail. To begin the hike up the Queets Valley you must ford the river, an important habitat for Pacific salmon and trout. The river bottom is slippery, and the water is often too deep and swift to wade, particularly in the fall, winter, spring, or after heavy rains. This rain forest trail winds along the river at an easy grade. The last five miles are primitive and difficult to follow. Text continues: How to Cross the Queets. Check up and down river to find the best spot for fording. Wear sturdy sandals, tennis shoes, or hiking boots. Loosen shoulder straps and unbuckle hip belt if you are carrying a pack to shed it quickly if you slip. Use a stout pole, held in both hands, to brace against the current. To the left of the text is a black and white illustration showing a hiker wearing a backpack and holding a pole while crossing a river. In the center of the panel is a map with the text, You Are Here, and the trail marked with white dashes. Park boundaries, campgrounds, and other trails are marked on the map. At the top of the panel is a trail grade profile showing the trailhead elevation at 300-feet and the end of the trail a little less than 1000 feet.

title: [Sign] Quinault Area Park Entrance Sign #204

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Park Entrance Sign
audioDescription: Quinault Park Entrance Sign. 1 minute On the right shoulder of the roadway, a large brown wooden sign supported on each side by vertical logs has words in white that read, Entering Olympic National Park. To the right of the text is the National Park Service logo. It is shaped like an arrowhead with a scalloped edge, pointed at the bottom, with sides that widen out toward the top, before curving slightly inward, then flaring out to create a rounded top. The arrowhead is brown with etched words and images. On the right side are the words, National Park Service, in white letters. To the left, in green, a tall tree towers above smaller trees and the ground below and a section of lake in white. Behind the tree, a white outline of snowcapped mountains. Below the trees, text in white reads, Department of the Interior, and below this, an outline of a bison in profile facing left with a large head and shoulders and smaller hind area. There is a narrow pull-off for cars along the road. Be advised, large rocks line the right edge of the pull-off.

title: [Sign] Rain Forest Threshold Wayside #254b

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Rain Forest Threshold Wayside. 45 seconds On the left side of this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel is a green and white drawing of a dark forest scene. In the foreground, a long branch completely covered in draping moss extends to the center of the panel. Text at the top right reads: Rain Forest Threshold. Green drapery softens the outlines of the forest. With your senses discover how this environment is special; damp smells, a mix of decay and fresh new growth; sounds of water from streams or dripping leaves; different textures of a variety of plants, the cool breath of fog against your cheek.

title: [Sign] Razor Clams Wayside #188c

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Razor Clams Wayside. 1 minute Filling the left side of this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside is a blue and white drawing of an oval shaped razor clam, upright in the sand, its siphon extending out of the top of its shell and its foot extending from the bottom of the shell. Text at the top right reads: Razor Clams. Razor clams dine on a floating banquet, siphoning microscopic plants and animals from the surf. At low tide dimples in the sand reveal their position. But with a sharp, powerful foot clams can submerge rapidly beneath soft, damp sand to escape crabs and people. The clams are fattest just before spawning in April or May when the water temperature rises. For razor clams to survive, digging season and catch are limited. Check the current posted regulations. Below the text, a drawing shows a razor clam in a five-step sequence as it moves from laying horizontally atop the sand to turning vertically and burying itself completely in the sand.

title: [Sign] Salmonberry Wayside #258o

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Salmonberry Wayside. 1 minute On the left side of this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel is a black and white drawing of a plant with stems along its branch, each having three, jagged edged, oval shaped leaves, one at the tip, the other two side by side. A round berry comprised of many small ball-like segments, hangs from the branch. Text at the top right reads: Salmonberry. Where elk are rare, salmonberry can grow fifteen feet high, but in the Hoh it seldom reaches four feet. Look for elk-browsed shoots along the trail. The berries were eaten by Indians and are an important wildlife food. Below the text is a drawing of an elk. On the top of its head is a wide set of antlers with five points on each antler beam. It has large, pointed ears, oval shaped dark eyes, and a wide snout tipped with a large black nose above its mouth. The fur on its chest and head is darker than the rest of its body.

title: [Sign] Sea Stacks Wayside #166a

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Sea Stacks Wayside. 1 minute On the left side of this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel is a black and white drawing showing two outcrops of rock standing in the ocean with the headlands in the distance. Text at the top right reads: Sea Stacks. A link between land and sea, offshore islands provide sanctuary for ocean birds to breed and raise their young. Cormorants and murres nest on ledges; pigeon guillemots and petrels nest in crevices. Ranging far out to sea for all their food, many birds come no closer to the mainland than these rocky outposts. Some offshore islands are ghosts of former headlands. Surf gnaws islands out of the shoreline. Harder rock is all that remains. Below the text, is a comparative illustration showing three side-by-side slices of tall headland jutting into the ocean, each slice representing a different stage in sea stack creation. On the left, the headland is solid. In the center, an arch has formed at the tip of the headland, and on the right, the arch is gone, leaving a tall vertical column of rock standing alone in the ocean.

title: [Sign] Shortened Seasons Wayside #41

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Shortened Seasons Wayside. 1 minute On a three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel are two illustrations of flowers growing in the snow. Text at the top right reads: Shortened Seasons. At this elevation the snowline determines the calendar. Spring and summer are so brief that some meadow flowers start to bloom within melting drifts. Along a snowbank May and August exist side by side. Below the text is a Glacier lily with its three long green leaves rising out of the snow. To the left, in black and white, a dense patch of blooming wildflowers surrounded by snow grow at the base of a hill. A near branchless tree stands in the middle of the hill and an A-shaped pine tree stands on top.

title: [Sign] Signs of Wildlife Wayside #46

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Signs of Wildlife Wayside. 2 minutes On this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel along the Hurricane Ridge Loop Trail are black and white illustrations of a bear and a marmot. Text at the top right reads: Signs of Wildlife. Most animals seek shelter in the heat of the day. But you can discover their signs. Deer trails criss-cross the hillsides; excavations are marmot burrows. Listen for the whistle of the marmot or the booming sound of the male blue grouse. Below the text is a drawing of the top half of a standing Marmot. Its horizontal, oval shaped head faces right. A small ear sits far back on the side of its head and a dark oval eye sits high and centered. It has a flat nose and a wide closed mouth. Its body is stout, and its two front legs and four-toed feet hang in front of its belly. On the left side of the panel, is a larger drawing of a forward-facing bear standing on all four long-clawed feet. The bear has dark fur, a broad, bulky body and a small round head with two upright oval shaped ears. Closely spaced eyes are set on either side of the snout which extends out from its face. At the tip of the snout is a large black round nose and the bear’s mouth.

title: [Sign] Spring Water Wayside #258k

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Spring Water Wayside. 45 seconds On the left side and across the bottom of this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel is a black and white drawing of a pool of water bordered by a forest of ferns and moss draped trees. Close to the water’s edge on the right, the calm surface of the pool is broken by a series of concentric circles caused by spring water bubbling up in the center. Rain falls upon the scene. Text in the top right corner reads: Spring Water. The clear waters of Taft Creek come from springs and seeps just upstream. Filtering down through forest soil rainwater slowly percolates through deeper layers of sand and gravel and supplies the springs with a steady flow. Compare this stream to the cloudy, glacial waters of the Hoh River.

title: [Sign] Spruce Railroad Wayside #107d

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Spruce Railroad Wayside. 2 minutes A color illustration of a train and tracks along the near shore of a lake fills this entire three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel. Text on the left reads: Spruce Railroad. Imagine the continuous clank of steel upon steel echoing across Lake Crescent. To secure spruce lumber for World War 1 warplanes, a railroad was built in 1918 along the far shore of the lake. Soldiers and civilians toiled for five months, cutting two tunnels and laying rails in record time. The war ended just weeks before the railroad was completed, but it was used to haul timber until 1954. Today, a hiking and biking trail follows this route. On the right side of the panel, the front of a gray metal tube-shaped steam train emerges from a dark tunnel cut through a brown rocky mountain slope. The tunnel opening is framed on the top and sides with thick wooden timbers. The train travels towards us on two metal rails atop many squared off wooden beams laid perpendicular to the rails. On top of the train, a smokestack belches thick dark grey smoke. The flat face of the train is round with a smaller round door and headlight in the center. Below, is a platform with handrail, both the width of the train. On the bottom, a forward angled metal grill with vertical bars, slightly wider than the train tracks, almost touches the tracks. On the left side of the panel is the lake, its blue water and surrounding mountains partially obscured by thick light gray mist.

title: [Sign] Spruce Trail Wayside #258c

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Spruce Trail Wayside. 1 minute On the left side of this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel is a map of the Spruce Nature Trail with the text, You Are Here, pointing to a location in the lower left corner. Taft Creek intersects the center of the map in a north and south direction. Text at the top right reads: Spruce Trail. You are standing on top of a former riverbank, a more open area where big Douglas-firs have enough light to grow old. Along this 1 ¼ mile loop trail is a lush variety of plants, representing different ages and stages of forest affected by the wandering power of the Hoh River. Below the text is a black and white drawing of three trees submerged in water and more trees along the bank in the distance.

title: [Sign] Stand Still Wayside #107p

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Stand Still Wayside. 1 minute A color image of a squirrel standing on a tree branch fills the entire panel on this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside. Text on the left reads: Stand Still. Listen for the scolding chatter of the Douglas squirrel and bird song filtering through the forest canopy. You may hear juncos, varied thrushes and winter wrens. Look for deer droppings along the trail or black bear claw marks on trees. Alder groves, wet meadows and small forest openings provide the cover and open feeding areas preferred by many species of wildlife. On the right side of the image, a reddish-brown squirrel, facing right, stands on all four legs atop a tree branch draped with strands of light green moss. The squirrel has a round head, two fur tipped ears, a dark oval eye encircled by tan fur, and a small dark nose flanked by long black whiskers above its mouth. Its bushy tail is brown with black streaks and curves up and away from its body. The squirrel’s feet each have four toes ending with a claw. The branch is attached to a dark colored tree trunk with rough bark. More trees stand in the background.

title: [Sign] Still Standing Wayside #107o

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Still Standing Wayside. 2 minutes In front of this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel, stands a large, wide tree that is hollow in the center. The outer walls of the tree trunk flare out at the bottom to form a solid base. There is a large opening in the front of the tree and two small openings in back. The opening in front is large enough for people to enter. Be advised, there are protruding tree roots in the ground between the wayside and the tree opening, so please use caution. On the panel, a color image shows the inside of tree on fire. Bright red and orange flames flare up from the base through the core of the trunk. The reddish-brown outer bark is not on fire. On the ground around the tree and in the forest beyond, are burning trees and branches that have fallen. Whitish grey smoke fills the forest. Text on the left reads: Still Standing. Natural forests evolved in the presence of fire. The heart of this western redcedar was consumed by fire. Why is the crown still green? Live tissue still survives under the bark, transporting food down from the needles and water and nutrients up from the roots.

title: [Sign] The Giving Tree Wayside #107c

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: The Giving Tree Wayside. 2 minutes A color illustration of a Pileated Woodpecker clinging to a tree in the forest fills this entire three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel. Text on the left reads: The Giving Tree. When a tree dies, insects and fungi invade. This grand fir has been chipped away by woodpeckers and other insectivores searching for insects and larvae. Large rectangular holes made by pileated woodpeckers often serve as homes for other animals. More than one third of the bird species common to Northwest forests, as well as other small animals, nest in these cavities. Can you think of any? On the right side of the panel, a right-facing, mostly black, pileated woodpecker is vertically anchored by its four toed clawed feet to a light brown tree trunk with several holes. Crowning the birds entire head is a cap of bright red feathers that end at the back of the head in an upward pointing crest. Its round eye is yellow, and its tan beak is long and pointed. Above the eye is an upward curving white stripe. Below the eye, beginning at the beak, a bold white stripe runs to the back of the head, then curves downward ending at the chest. Under this stripe on the bird’s cheek is a patch of red, then below this, another white strip on the underside of the head. The scene in the center and left side of the panel, shows a dark, dense green and brown forest. Green moss grows on some of the trees.

title: [Sign] The Olympic Mountains Wayside #40b

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: The Olympic Mountains Wayside. 2 minutes Along the 2-foot-high stone wall edging the visitor center patio, a color panoramic illustration of the landscape before you fills most of a three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel. The downward sloping meadow has clumps of purple and white wildflowers and short, green grasses. On the far edge of the meadow, lines of pine trees descend down slope. Then, snow-free forested mountains in the near distance and snowcapped mountain peaks in the far distance. Nineteen peaks are labeled by name and elevation. Below the mountain peaks in two valleys separated by a ridge are the Lillian River on the left and Elwha River on the right. Text below the illustration reads: The Olympic Mountains. On a clear day you can gaze far into the Olympic Wilderness, from deep valleys to deep ridges. This young mountain range is made of basalts and sedimentary rocks uplifted from their birth on the seafloor and later sculpted by glaciers and erosion. Winter snow lingers on the mountains well into summer. By autumn, only permanent snowfields and glacial ice cling to the highest peaks. From left to right, the names and elevations of the mountains read: Steeple Rock 5567 feet. Obstruction Peak 6450 feet. Mt. Deception 7788 feet. Mt. Cameron 7190 feet. McCartney Peak 6784 feet. Mt. Anderson 7321 feet. Crystal Peak 6896 feet. Chimney Peak 6917 feet. Mt. Dana 6209 feet. Dodger Point 5764 feet. Mt. Seattle 6246 feet. Ludden Peak 5854 feet. Mt. Ferry 6195 feet. Long Ridge no elevation provided. Stephen Peak 6418 feet. Blue Glacier no elevation provided. Mt. Olympus 7980 feet. Mt. Carrie 6995 feet. Mt. Fitzhenry 6050 feet

title: [Sign] The Upper Story Wayside #254e

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: The Upper Story Wayside. 1 minute On this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel text reads: The Upper Story. Many of the big trees are over two hundred feet tall, their tops in an upper atmosphere. Unlike tropical rain forests this forest is coniferous: Sitka spruce, with needles sharp to the touch; Western hemlock, with drooping top; Douglas-fir, with think, deeply furrowed bark. Notice the burl on the Sitka spruce trunk, a tumor caused by early insect damage or virus. To the left of the text is a dark green and white illustration showing a section of tree trunk and branches covered in different types of plant life. On the trunk, a flat plant is labeled, Lichen, on lower branches, a stringy hanging plant is labeled, Selaginella moss, and on the side of the trunk, a plant with multiple long fronds is labeled, Licorice fern. Below the text, an illustration showing a round, bulbous growth encircling a section of tree branch is labeled, Spruce burl.

title: [Sign] Three Steps Into Wilderness Wayside #223a

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Three Steps Into Wilderness Wayside. 7 minutes On the left side of the trail, and facing the trail, stand two roof covered kiosks each holding two interpretive panels. Beginning with the kiosk on the left and the panel on the left, a text header across the top with white and green lettering on a black background reads, Your first 3 steps into Wilderness. The remainder of the panel is an image showing a tangle of moss-covered tree roots curving above the ground carpeted with red and yellow leaves and green ferns. In the background are more roots and leaves. At the bottom, white text reads: When you enter the Olympic Wilderness, you’re in for a wild time. Six hundred miles of trails link you to sea and sky. Are you hiking the coast, crossing creeks through old-growth forest or ascending mile-high peaks? Whatever your destination, Your First 3 Steps into Wilderness can lead to success or disaster. Attentive trip planning and preparation will help protect you and the future of wilderness. Step 1. Plan. Step 2 Prepare. Step 3 Protect The header on the second panel reads, Step 1. Plan. Below, are two columns of text. On the left is parkwide planning information. On the right, is planning information pertaining to Graves Creek. Text in the Parkwide column reads: Before your trip, contact the park’s Wilderness Information Center for safety information, permits and regulations. Group size limit is twelve. Leave your trip itinerary, including date of return, with someone who expects you back. Observe all regulations, including those that restrict pets, weapons, and wheeled vehicles and devices. Safely secure all food, garbage, and scented items 24 hours a day to protect wildlife and you. Contact the WIC for bear cannister loan locations. Text in the Graves Creek column reads: Check local conditions before heading out. Even when it is early summer in the Quinault rain forest, higher elevations may still be snow covered, making route finding and travel difficult. Bears commonly forage in this valley, especially in the spring. For their safety and yours, follow food storage requirements by using bear cannisters or bear wires. Observe stock regulations that help protect you, your animals, and the Olympic wilderness. Above 3,500 feet, stay on trails and only use designated stock camps. Pack non-viable pellets or rolled grain. Below the text, is a Trail Grade Profile illustrating the elevation for locations along the Graves Creek trail. Elevation at this trailhead is 615 feet. Lake Sundown is just below 4000 feet, and Anderson Pass is around 4500 feet. A map at the bottom shows the Graves Creek trail system with the text, You Are Here. Four small color photographs are inset into the map. A tan slug with two antennae on a bed of red, yellow, and green moss. A stream with a waterfall in the background. A small brown bird with brown spots on a white belly stands on a branch. A green fern frond hovers over green clover. Moving to the second kiosk to the right, the header on the first panel reads, Step 2. Prepare. In the center of the panel is an image of white water flowing down a rocky streambed. Green trees line the banks, and a snowcapped mountain rises in the distance. Above the image, text reads: Parkwide. Carry backcountry essentials including extra food, extra warm-when-wet clothing, topographic map, compass, flashlight and extra batteries, sunglasses and sunscreen, pocketknife, matches in waterproof container, candle or Firestarter and first aid kit. Prepare for hazards of weather, terrain, water crossing and wildlife. Prevent hypothermia in cool, wet weather by wearing wool and synthetic layers, a warm hat and rain gear. Boil, filter or chemically treat all drinking water to avoid infection by Giardia, a microscopic intestinal parasite. A small photo to the right of the text shows dark tree trunks standing in front of trees with red and yellow leaves. Below the image, text reads: Graves Creek. Wear sturdy, waterproof boots and gaiters. The trail often remains muddy, even during dry weather, and becomes more steep and rugged upriver. Rely on basic gear and skill, not electronics. Cell phones, GPS units and other electronic devices might not work, especially in valleys and forested areas. Be prepared to travel inclement weather. Always check the weather forecast but also prepare for the unexpected. Use shelters for emergencies only – rain is not an emergency. To the left of the text is a photograph of an elk. It has no antlers, a brown head with a long snout facing right, and its body is tan. It stands among ferns in a forest. The header on the second panel reads, Step 3. Protect. An image filling the right side of the panel shows a high alpine area with yellow-green moss and lichen growing on a rocky slope with snowcapped mountain peaks in the background. On the left, text reads: Parkwide. Leave no trace of your stay. Think about how your actions impact wildlife, vegetation, and visitors. Use established campsites along the trail system. If hiking cross-country, camp on durable surfaces. Observe revegetation closures to protect plants. Minimize use of fire. Pack out everything you pack in. Properly dispose of human waste. Use privies where available or dig a six-to-8-inch hole at least 200 feet from campsites and water. Do not urinate in composting or vault toilets. Wash dishes and yourself away from lakes and streams. To protect water quality, avoid using soap. Leave natural objects and cultural artifacts where are you find them to help protect this irreplaceable wilderness. Graves Creek. Use a stove to eliminate impacts of fires and wood gathering. Campfires are prohibited above 3,500 feet. If you build a fire at lower elevations, keep it small and use an existing fire ring. Gather, don’t cut, only small pieces of dead and down wood. Be sure your fire is out cold as winds can reignite embers. Hike in the center of the trail even if it is muddy. Walking around mud damages plants and widens the trail. Never feed wildlife for their health and your safety. Backpackers and day hikers should always keep. Their food secured from any wildlife. Below the text are three color photographs. Pink and white flowers with five petals grown among rocks. A side view of a red and yellow fern before it opens, its head curled in a spiral. Two red mushrooms with tops like open umbrellas grow in the ground.

title: [Sign] Three Steps Into Wilderness Wayside #253a

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Three Steps Into Wilderness Wayside. 6 minutes Beyond the trailhead on the right and left, stand two roof covered kiosks each holding two interpretive panels. Beginning with the kiosk on the right and the panel on the right, a text header across the top with white and green lettering on a black background reads, Your First 3 Steps Into Wilderness. A color image of a green grassy meadow with pine trees in the background fills the panel. Over the image at the bottom, white text reads: When you enter the Olympic Wilderness, you’re in for a wild time. Six hundred miles of trails link you to sea and sky. Are you hiking the coast, crossing creeks through old-growth forest or ascending mile-high peaks? Whatever your destination, Your First 3 Steps into Wilderness can lead to success or disaster. Attentive trip planning and preparation will help protect you and the future of wilderness. Step 1. Plan. Step 2 Prepare. Step 3 Protect The header on the second panel to the left reads: Step 1. Plan. Below, are two columns of text. On the left is parkwide planning information. On the right, is planning information pertaining to Hoh. Text in the Parkwide column reads: Before your trip, contact the park’s Wilderness Information Center (WIC) or area ranger station for safety information, permits and regulations. Limit your group size to twelve. Leave your trip itinerary, including date of return, with someone who expects you back. Observe regulations that restrict pets, weapons, and wheeled vehicles and devices. Storing edibles, garbage, and scented items in hard sided food containers 24 hours a day will protect wildlife and you. To their detriment, wild animals can become accustomed to human food. Text in the Hoh column reads: Reservations are required for overnight trips to CB Flats, Hoh Lake and Sol Duc. Contact the ranger station or call the WIC. Mount Olympus is a technical climb that involves glaciers and requires specialized gear including rope, ice axe and crampons. Use a topographic map and compass. Ask a ranger for information. Stock regulations help protect you, your animals, and the wilderness. To travel or camp with stock, pack non-viable pellets or rolled grain. Above 3,500 feet, stay on trails and only use designated stock camps. Observe all other guidelines. Below the text, is a Trail Grade Profile illustrating the elevation for locations along the Hoh River Trail. Elevation at this trailhead is 600 feet. Glacier Meadows is just above 4000 feet. A map at the bottom shows the Hoh River trail system with the text, You Are Here, in the far left. Three small color photographs are inset into the map at top left. Tree roots covered in moss. A green fern frond curled at the tip. A snow-covered mountain peak. Moving to the second kiosk about 15 feet up trail on the left, the header on the first panel on the left reads: Step 2. Prepare. Parkwide text reads: Carry backcountry essentials including extra food, extra warm-when-wet clothing, topographic map, compass, flashlight and extra batteries, sunglasses and sunscreen, pocketknife, matches in waterproof container, candle or Firestarter and first aid kit. Prepare for hazards of weather, terrain, water crossing and wildlife. Prevent hypothermia in cool, wet weather by wearing wool and synthetic layers, a warm hat and rain gear. Boil, filter or chemically treat all drinking water to avoid infection by Giardia, a microscopic intestinal parasite. In the center of the panel is a color photograph showing five brown elk crossing a river. Below the image, Hoh text reads: Wear good hiking boots and gaiters. The trail often remains muddy, even during dry weather, and becomes more steep and rugged upriver. Use water from smaller creeks to prolong the life of your water filter. The gray glacier flour in the Hoh River is harmless but will quickly clog your filtering equipment. Be prepared to travel inclement weather. Always check the weather forecast but also prepare for the unexpected. Use shelters for emergencies only. Rain is not an emergency. The header on the second panel reads, Step 3. Protect. Parkwide text reads: Leave no trace of your stay. Think about how your actions impact wildlife, vegetation, and visitors. Use established campsites along the trail system. If hiking cross-country, camp on durable surfaces. Observe revegetation closures to protect plants. Minimize use of fire. Pack out everything you pack in. Properly dispose of human waste. Use privies where available or dig at least 200 feet from campsites and water. Do not urinate in composting or vault toilets. Wash dishes and yourself away from water sources. Use small amounts of biodegradable soap or none at all. Leave natural objects and cultural artifacts where are you find them to help protect this irreplaceable wilderness. In the center of the panel are two color photographs. A black bear eating berries and a closeup of a blue berry and red leaves. Below the photos, Hoh text reads: Use a stove to eliminate impacts of fires and wood gathering. Campfires are not permitted above 3,500 feet. If you build a fire at lower elevations, keep it small and use an existing fire ring. Gather, don’t cut, only small pieces of dead and down wood. Be sure your fire is out cold as winds can reignite embers. Hike in the center of the trail even if it is muddy. Walking around mud damages plants and widens the trail. Camp on gravel bars if no established campsites are available. Your careful camping protects vegetation. Along the right side of the panel is a color photograph of a stream, its white water tumbling over rocks.

title: [Sign] Tidepool Life Wayside #170d

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Tidepool Life Wayside. 2 minutes Here, on the side of the stairway, is a three-foot tall, angled wayside titled, Tidepool Life. Between a Rock and a Hard Place. Filling the right side of the panel is a color illustration of stacked rocks covered with sea life. Tree-like seaweed with many branches reach upward. Red and yellow five-pointed sea stars cling to the rocks. Cone shaped barnacles and ring-shaped sea urchins, some red and with long spikes, cover the rocks. Round, flat sea anemones edged with short green tentacles, a crab with two large front pinchers, and a striped fish with a spikey top fin are also on the rocks. In the top left corner, text reads, Human disturbance has severely impacted most Pacific Coast tidepools. This brilliant collage of plants and animals can easily be destroyed. Tubeworms, seastars, sea anemones and other tidepool creatures, along with all wildlife, are protected in Olympic National Park. Please leave intertidal plants and animals undisturbed in their natural habitat. To the left of the text is an illustration of tubeworms standing erect, their feathery gills extending above the top of their long, thin bodies like open umbrellas. The final illustration in the left bottom corner shows a person standing in the surf at ocean’s edge holding a fishing rod. Text reads, Surf fishing? Any natural bait native to Olympic National Park can be used only during its legal harvest season – check park regulations regarding crabs, fish, and shellfish. It is never legal, however, to remove or possess tidepool life. Removing only a few tubeworms weakens the entire colony.

title: [Sign] Tidepool Life Wayside #170e

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Tidepool Life Wayside. 1 minute On this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel, text in the right top corner reads: Tidepool Life. Twice a day, drowned in seawater, then exposed to frying sun. Hammered by storm waves. Tidepools are home to a variety of sea creatures surviving ingeniously. Notice their shapes. Many are low and rounded to withstand pounding surf. Anemones cluster, reducing evaporation, crowding competing organisms, and amassing more tentacles to catch, sting and hold prey. Find the best pools at low tide near the large rock to the north. Look and enjoy, but please don’t disturb. Filling the left side and bottom of the panel, an illustration provides a cross section view of a tidepool. Above the water on a seaweed covered rock are two white Glaucous-winged gulls, one pecking at a cup shaped limpet attached to a rock. A Black oystercatcher with a black body, long, wedge shaped bill, white eye and log legs stands on a rock. Underwater, a thick bodied Ochre star and triangle shaped Black turban shell are attached to a rock. A hermit crab extends out from its shell. A Green sea anemone, its short, round body topped with a ring of tentacles sits beside the sac shaped body of a Solitary tunicate. A small fish called a Sculpin swims among the rocks.

title: [Sign] Tidepool Life/Drift Logs and Riptides wayside #166b
listingDescription: 2 waysides
