images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational signs
audioDescription: Tidepool Life and Drift Logs and Riptides. 3 minutes Two three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panels stand side-by-side. Beginning with the panel on the left, text in the top right reads, Tidepool Life. Twice a day, drowned in seawater, then exposed to frying sun. Hammered by storm waves. Tidepools are home to a variety of sea creatures surviving ingeniously. Notice their shapes. Many are low and rounded to withstand pounding surf. Anemones cluster, reducing evaporation, crowding competing organisms, and amassing more tentacles to catch, sting and hold prey. Find the best pools at low tide near the large rock to the north. Look and enjoy, but please don’t disturb. Filling the left side and bottom of the panel, an illustration provides a cross section view of a tidepool. Above the water on a seaweed covered rock are two white Glaucous-winged gulls, one pecking at a cup shaped limpet attached to a rock. A Black oystercatcher with a black body, long, wedge shaped bill, white eye and log legs stands on a rock. Underwater, a thick bodied Ochre star and triangle shaped Black turban shell are attached to a rock. A hermit crab extends out from its shell. A green sea anemone, its short, round body topped with a ring of tentacles sits beside the sac shaped body of a Solitary tunicate. A small fish called a Sculpin swims among the rocks. The wayside panel on the right, has text that reads, Drift Logs and Riptides. Beach logs are the bones of a rain forest picked clean by the sea. They begin in river valleys, giant conifers like Sitka spruce. When a day’s downpour adds to glacial melt the stream may rise six feet, undermining the bank and toppling trees into the flood, washing them down to river mouth and beach. Some fall from eroding headlands. Numbered trunks are strays from tug-pulled log rafts. Drift logs are dangerous. At high tide they may suddenly roll. Unwary people have been crushed and killed by drift logs. Riptides make swimming and wading dangerous. There are no lifeguards. Swimmers beware. On the left side of the panel, an aerial view illustration shows the churning water of a rip current rolling perpendicular to the shoreline through a narrow gap between the shore and a sandbar. In the center of the panel, is a smaller drawing at beach level of a jumbled pile of drift logs.

title: [Sign] Tilting Coast Wayside #170f

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Tilting Coast Wayside. 1 minute Filling the left side of this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel is a blue and white drawing showing a hillside of rock, tilting upward from left to top right. Text at the top right reads: Tilting Coast. The rocks are at odd angles –tilted, almost overturned. Younger layers are underneath the older stone. Originally, these sediment layers settled in a deep ocean basin to the west. But continental movement has shifted things during the last 15 million years. Earth’s outer crust consists of vast mobile plates carried along by convection currents. As the ocean floor collided and dipped beneath the land plate, the rocks which form the Olympic peninsula were skimmed off and added to the continent. Below the text is a diagram illustrating the geologic process of land building. To the right, is a cross section illustration of clams buried in sandstone with text that reads: The holes in the rocks around you were drilled by piddock clams. These clams use a rocking motion to burrow into the sandstone.

title: [Sign] Together They Stand Wayside #258i

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Together They Stand Wayside. 45 seconds On the left side of this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel is a black and white drawing of three closely spaced trees rising out of a single base. Text at the top right reads: Together They Stand. This western hemlock is actually composed of several individuals. Originally many seedlings took root on a rotting stump. The seedlings near the edge grew roots down the sides of the stump and reached the ground first. Eventually the soil-rooted hemlocks crowded out the others and joined together, giving the appearance of a single tree. Below the text, a black and white drawing shows three small trees growing atop a rotting stump.

title: [Sign] Trails of the Hoh Wayside #254a

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Trails of the Hoh Wayside. 2 minutes To the right of the Hoh Rainforest Visitor Center is a three-foot-tall angled wayside panel titled, Trails at the Hoh. Filling the panel on the left and center is a map of the trail system with the text, You Are Here, adjacent to the Visitor Center. The accessible Mini Trail is marked by a yellow line that loops from the Visitor Center to the Hoh River Trailhead near the parking lot. The looping Hall of Mosses Trail branches off the Mini Trail to the left and is marked by a green line. The Hoh River Trail, marked by a blue line, branches off the Mini Trail at the top of the loop. The looping Spruce Nature Trail which is marked by a grey line branches off the Mini Trail loop at the top. All trails except the Mini Trail cross Taft Creek. Text on the right side of the panel reads: Nature trails of varying length and difficulty penetrate the rain forest. Here, plants grow upon plants, woven together in a dense tapestry. Don’t break the vital web by picking vegetation. Mini-Trail. This level, paved one-quarter mile trail is easily travelled by small children, the handicapped, or people who can spend only a brief time in the rain forest. Average hiking time is 10 minutes. Hall of Mosses Trail. Three quarters of a mile long, with dramatic draperies of clubmoss, this trail is mostly level except for a short ascent near the beginning. Average hiking time is 1 hour. Spruce Trail. Through a great variety of rain forest vegetation, this one-quarter mile trail leads to the Hoh River. Average hiking time is one and one-half hours. Hoh River Trail. Travel miles of forested river valley before beginning the ascent to Blue Glacier and Mount Olympus, 17.3 miles away. Overnight hikers should register at the Ranger Station. Dogs are natural enemies to all creatures of the forest. For the protection of your pet, as well as yourself and other hikers, pets are not permitted on the trails. Wear proper foot gear – trails may be soggy.

title: [Sign] Tree Islands Wayside #43

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Tree Islands Wayside. 45 seconds Along the Hurricane Ridge Loop Trail overlooking a meadow, a tree filled valley, and partially tree-covered mountains in the distance, is a three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel with two black and white drawings of trees. Text at the top right reads: Tree Island. Nearby are stunted, snow-damaged trees. In the distance they stand in solitary clusters. The subalpine fir scatters many seeds, but foraging animals and a stern climate limit seed survival. Often lower branches take root, gradually growing upward into a circle of new trunks. To the left of the text, a drawing of a sloping hillside with scattered groups of pine trees. Below the text, a cross section drawing of the lower branches and root system of a large pine tree with a smaller tree growing from its roots.

title: [Sign] Tree Skirting Wayside #61

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Tree Skirting Wayside. 1 minute On the left side of a three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel is a black and white drawing of a pine tree covered in heavy snow. The shape of the tree resembles an upside-down funnel, tall and thin at the top, then flaring out at the bottom. Text at the top right reads: Tree Skirting. Snow shapes the trees. As drifts weight the lower boughs, insulating them from cutting winds, subalpine firs grow luxuriant, ground-hugging skirts. Below the text is a black and white close-up drawing of a single snowflake in the shape of a cross with four identical arms. Each arm resembles a tree that is thick at the bottom and thin at the top with branches reaching out on either side.

title: [Sign] Tree Survival Wayside #45

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Tree Survival Wayside. 1 minute On this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel along the Hurricane Ridge Loop Trail are two illustrations, one of snow-covered trees and the other, pinecones. Text at the top right reads: Tree Survival. Like A-frame chalets, stiff-limbed subalpine firs depend on their conical shapes to shed snow. Mountain hemlocks, with nodding tops and more flexible branches, spread their limbs in a broader pattern. Saplings of both trees are extremely flexible. In Spring they pop up from imprisoning drifts. To the left of the text is a black and white drawing of three snow covered trees, their tops bent over by the weight of the snow. Below the text is a black and white close up drawing of two types of pinecones. On the left, three Mountain hemlock cones hang down from the end of a needle covered branch. The cones are long and thin with overlapping scales. On the right, two Subalpine fir cones sit upright on a branch of fir needles. They are about the same length as the hemlock cones and have similar overlapping scales but are twice the width.

title: [Sign] Trees vs. Flowers Wayside #62

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Trees vs. Flowers Wayside. 1 minute On the left side of this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel is a black and white drawing of a mountain meadow surrounded by forest, then mountain ridges in the background. Text at the top right reads: Trees vs. Flowers. Note the distant pattern of tree groves and meadows. As subalpine firs struggle for territory, they shade out meadow plants. But avalanche, wildfire, and late-lying snow help keep slopes open. The line between trees and meadow ebbs and flows. Below the text is a black and white closeup drawing of a fir seedling. Two oval pinecones with overlapping scales sit upright atop the end of a needle covered branch.

title: [Sign] Treetop World Wayside #255b

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Treetop World Wayside. 2 minutes On the left side of this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel is a black and white drawing of three trees lined up horizontally. Text at the top right reads: Treetop World. The upper reach of the conifers – many well over 200 feet tall – is an environment apart. Birds and flying squirrels you might never see near ground level nest up there. Examine fallen cones and bits of lichen. Focus upward, learn to identify the trees: Sitka spruce with sharp needles growing all around the branch; drooping tops of western hemlock; Douglas-fir with thick, deep furrowed bark. The drawing shows three trees of different size and shape. The A-shaped tree on the left is the widest of the three. It has a flared base, long branches with drooping needles and a pointed top. The tree in the center is the tallest and thinnest of the three. It has a straight trunk with branches all of similar length with drooping needles. The tree on the right, the middle-sized tree, has a thin A-shape with a slightly rounded top, a straight trunk and needle covered branches, some upturned, some drooping. Below the text are drawings of cones from three different trees. On the left, a long, oval shaped Sitka spruce cone attached at the tip of a needled covered branch. It is covered with round, pointed scales. In the center, a smaller oval shaped Western hemlock cone, attached at the tip of a branch, its oval scales slightly turned up. On the right, a Douglass-fir cone, wide and round at the top and pointed at the bottom, its scales wide and round. It is attached near the center of a branch tipped with pine needles.

title: [Sign] Underwater Fire Wayside #69

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Underwater Fire Wayside. 2 minutes On this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel text reads: Underwater Fire. The rocks across the road are volcanic, but there are no volcanoes in the Olympics. Eons ago, underwater eruptions occurred in the Pacific Ocean forming pillow basalts. The rocks across the valley formed from sediments shed onto the ocean floor. Both kinds of rock were rafted towards North America by ocean floor movement, then uplifted and tilted by powerful forces. Below the text is a horizontal diagram showing a geological cross section of the Pacific Ocean on the left and the Olympic Mountains on the right. Two-thirds of the diagram is the Pacific Ocean, its blue water atop a layer of wavy black horizonal lines labeled Sediments, then a layer of black dots labeled New Ocean Floor. Below these layers is a white unlabeled area. At far left, a section of the New Ocean Floor layer is split by a fault line, each side pushed up through the sediment layer. In the center of the diagram, in the sediments layer, is a brown triangle-shaped underwater volcano, its pointed peak rising into the ocean. On the bottom of the volcano, a long, thin magma tube extends downward, deep into the earth. The last one-third of the diagram on the right shows the Olympic Mountains. Where the mountains begin, the ocean and sediment layers end while the New Ocean Floor layer dips under the mountains. On the face of the mountains are several brown areas of Basalts, dense vertical columns of stacked pillow-shaped rocks. The largest area spans from the tallest peaks to the base of the mountains where a text label reads, North America. To the right of the basalts on the mountain’s down slope is an area of horizontal wavy lines labeled Ocean Sediments.

title: [Sign] Visitor Information Panel #100b

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Visitor Information Panel. 30 seconds Along the flat, gravel path from the parking lot to the restrooms is a large visitor information panel in a roof covered kiosk on the right. In the center of the panel is a map of the Northern Olympic Peninsula in gray surrounded by blue water. Color coded symbols on the map are used to indicate visitor information locations in green; recreational opportunities in purple; commercial services in red; and 31 places of interest throughout the area in orange. Above and below the map is text providing information about the natural and cultural history of the peninsula, local communities and towns, trails, and other recreational opportunities.

title: [Sign] Washington Geology Wayside #164a

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Washington Geology Wayside. 3 minutes The header on this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel reads, Washington Geology. Below, text reads: Tsunamis. Devastating waves called tsunamis can strike Washington’s coast at any time. These giant waves are usually caused by great undersea earthquakes. Such earthquakes can occur along the Cascadia Subduction Zone, one of the largest active faults in North America. This fault zone lies 32 to 70 miles offshore and roughly parallels the coast. A tsunami on the Washing Coast may also result from an earthquake striking areas as far away as Alaska or Japan. Tsunamis are dangerous and destructive. They have struck the Washington coast repeatedly and will again in the future. Tsunamis can follow within minutes of an earthquake. They move rapidly, but quickly run out of water as they sweep inland and uphill. Flooding can occur several miles inland along rivers and streams. Remember, most tsunamis are not solitary giant waves; instead, many large waves. What to do to escape a tsunami. Drop, cover, and hold during an earthquake. After the earthquake, immediately move uphill or inland. Do not return to the beach after the first tsunami wave – more waves may arrive for several hours. Wait for official notice from authorities that the danger has passed before returning to the beach. For additional information, contact the Washington Emergency Management Division 1-800-562-6108 or your local Emergency Management Division: Clallam County 1-360-417-2305. In the center of the panel, a rectangular diagram illustrates this text: Cross Section. A portion of the Earth’s crust, called The Juan de Fuca Plate, is moving away from the Pacific Plate, several hundred miles off Washington’s coast. The Juan de Fuca Plate is being forced under the North American Plate. The geologic process is called subduction. On the left side of the panel is a map of the west coasts of Washington and Oregon. In the Pacific Ocean, a dark red line marks the location of the Cascadia Subduction Zone. A caption reads: The earth’s surface consists of a series of plates. These plates are constantly shifting and sliding over, under, or past each other. When a sudden movement occurs between two plates, we experience an earthquake.

title: [Sign] Welcome to the Whale Trail Wayside #188b

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Welcome to the Whale Trail Wayside. 5 minutes Text on the far-right side of this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel reads: Grab your binoculars and scan the horizon! Look for the heart-shaped blows of gray whales on their annual migration. Spot the distinctive dorsal fin of orcas. Search for sea otters in the kelp and seals on the rocky shores. Farther out, humpback, fin, and sperm whales feed in nutrient-rich waters. Olympic Coast National Marine Sanctuary, extending nearly 50 miles offshore, protects a wide array of marine life. Safeguarding species closer to shore, Olympic National Park shares 65 miles of wild Pacific coast with the sanctuary. Your stewardship is vital in preserving these diverse and fragile marine environments. Follow the Whale Trail to watch whales from shore. From the Pacific Ocean to the Salish Sea, what will you discover. On the left, a text header reads, Welcome to the whale trail. Kalaloch. Below, are images with information about five sea animals. Clockwise from top left, an Orca, its oval shaped body, mostly black in color with a white rear side panel, a white oval eye patch, and a white underside. Its V-shaped tail fins are black on top and white underneath. On its back is a tall, pointed black dorsal fin, and near its head on each side of its body are black flippers. Text reads: Orca (killer whale) (Orcinus orca). Length: adult male 26 feet; female 23 feet; calf 8 feet Orcas are the largest member of the dolphin family. Highly social and intelligent, they live in tightly bonded family groups called pods. Three pods of fish-eating orcas (J, K, and L pods) live in Washington waters. These iconic mammals were listed as endangered in 2005. Next, a Harbor seal on its side, its body robust and oval, with grayish white and dark spotted fur. A small head with dark eyes, a V-shaped nose, and wide mouth is angled upward. It has two, short front flippers and tail flippers folded together like hands. Text reads: Harbor Seal (Phoca vituline). Length: adult 6 feet; pup 3 feet. Harbor seals are the most common marine mammal in the Pacific Northwest. Pups are left on the beach for extended periods while their mother feeds; please stay at least 100 yards from the pups. Continuing, a sea otter floats on its back, its belly, head, front paws and back flippers above water. It has a light brown head and dark brown body. Text reads: Sea Otter (Enhydra lutris). Length: Adult male 5 feet; female 4 feet; pup 10 inches. Once hunted to nearly extinction for their warm fur, there is a thriving population of sea otters along the Olympic Coast. Sea otters rest on their backs and use rocks as tools to crush mollusks and shellfish. Next, a harbor porpoise, its oval-shaped body dark gray on top and white on the sides and belly. It has a small, sharp dorsal fin midway down its back, and dark gray front flippers and tail fins. Text reads: Harbor Porpoise (Phocoena phocoena). Length. Adult 5 feet. Calf 27 inches. Shy and elusive, when harbor porpoises surface you may briefly catch a glimpse of their triangular “chocolate chip” shaped dorsal fin. They travel in small groups of up to ten animals. Last, a gray whale, its long, sleek body a uniform mottled gray and white in color. It has two front flippers, small, raised bumps midway down its spine, and V-shaped tail fins. Text reads: Gray Whale (Eschrichtius Robustus). Length: adult 46 feet; calf 15 feet Gray whales migrate close to shore along this coast between April and May. They feed in Alaska in the summer, and swim to Baja California to give birth in the winter. To the right of the images is a map of the Olympic Peninsula. The boundary outline for the Olympic Coast National Marine Sanctuary is marked in the Pacific Ocean. A list of wildlife viewing sites along the Whale Trail is next to the map. Across the bottom of the panel are six additional images. From left to right, an adult and two children face the ocean, one child looks through binoculars. Two Orcas, one vertical and halfway out of the water, the other swimming, its tall dorsal fin above water. A harbor seal with long whiskers, pops its head above water. An aerial view of a spouting gray whale, a white cloud of air above its body. A pair of sea otters, one on top of the other, floating on their backs in the ocean. And two harbor porpoises swimming side-by-side.

title: [Sign] Whale Watching Wayside #180a

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Whale Watching Wayside. 3 minutes Here, at the edge of the beach, is a three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel with blue and white illustrations of whales. Text on the right reads: Whale Watching. Twice a year California gray whales swim past, sometimes between Destruction Island and this beach. In the fall they are migrating south to calve and nurse in the warm lagoons of Baja California. The gray whales return in early spring on their way to arctic feeding grounds where they comb clouds of shrimp-like creatures from the water. Somehow, across 4000 miles of ocean, the huge mammals navigate precisely, on a predictable timetable. Watch for signs. Fifteen-foot spouts of warm condensing breath punctuate the rhythm of diving and breathing. Occasionally gray whales breach, burst from the water, turn and fall back with a tremendous splash, just playing, or maybe checking their bearings. Filling the left side of the panel is a long, blimp shaped whale with dark skin and patches of white, its opened mouth revealing a curtain of hair-like baleen. A map to the right of the whale has a line of arrows marking the round-trip migration route of Grey whales from their northern summer feeding grounds in the Bering Sea off the west coast of Alaska, then along the west coast of the United States, to their southern mating and calving area in lagoons off the west coast of Mexico. In the center of the panel, three small illustrations show different whale behaviors. From left to right, a submerged whale points downward, only its V-shaped tail above water. Next, a whale underwater with only its head above water and the caption, Spyhopping. Sometimes whales stand nose-up to have a look around. Finally, a whale tail above water with the caption, Diving. As a whale begins a sustained dive, the flukes rise dramatically before disappearing beneath the surface. Spanning the bottom of the panel is a horizontal diagram showing nine positions of a swimming whale, underwater at times, then rising to the surface to breathe. A caption reads, Spouting. Gray whales swim in a pattern that makes them easy to spot. It usually consists of 3 to 5 spouts, followed by a dive that lasts 2 to 5 minutes as they swim along at about 5 miles per hour. After this dive they surface and repeat their breathing pattern.

title: [Sign] Wild Coast Wayside #164b

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Wild Coast Wayside. 1 minute Be advised. Driftwood may be scattered on the beach blocking clear access to the wayside. On this 4-foot-tall upright wayside panel, text in the bottom right corner reads: Wild Coast. The sea makes the rules. Hiking this long stretch of wilderness beach, you may have to climb headlands, cross numerous streams, enter a cocoon of fog, or follow animal tracks in the sand. There are no sheltered lagoons. If you ignore the tides, storm waves may trap you against a sheer cliff. Find solitude, or a whale’s jawbone, or a kind of bird you’ve never seen before. Filling the top half of the panel is a blue and white drawing of a wave hitting the rocky shoreline below high tree topped hills. A sea stack is offshore. In the bottom left corner, a blue and white drawing shows a hiker holding a hiking pole while traversing a jumble of rocks at the base of a hill, the ocean in the background.

title: [Sign] Wild Things Wayside #107b

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Wild Things Wayside. 1 minute A color illustration of a stream and otter fills this three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel here on the shoreline of Lake Crescent. Text on the left side of the panel reads: Wild Things. Elusive bald eagles, black-tailed deer, river otters and freshwater clams inhabit this area. Two unique varieties of trout, Beardslee (rainbow) and Crescentic (cutthroat), are found only in Lake Crescent. The interface of water and land creates a diversity of wildlife habitats. The illustration shows a narrow stream flowing from left to right between steep banks of moss-covered rocks and ferns. A small waterfall cascades over rocks, then the stream becomes flat. Here, a brown river otter crosses the stream from right to left, its two front feet in the stream and its hind feet on the stream bank. The otter is long and narrow with a long thin tail, flattened head with a small dark oval shaped eye, and a small, rounded ear set back on the side of the head. Its short flat snout has a black nose above the mouth and white whiskers on each side.

title: [Sign] Winter Play Wayside 48

images.altText: A black and white symbol of a hiker facing a sign.
images.title: Wayside/sign symbol
images.caption: Wayside/informational sign

bodyText: Wayside/informational sign
audioDescription: Winter Play Wayside. 1 minute Along the Hurricane Ridge Loop Trail is a three-foot-tall, angled metal wayside panel with two black and white illustrations, one of a snowshoe, and the other, a skier. Text at the top right reads: Winter Play. You don’t have to wait for the snow to melt. Travel these same trails on snowshoes and cross-country skis. Downhill skiing is also popular. Or go cold-weather camping and become an intimate of winter, another face of wilderness. Below the text, is a drawing of one-half of a snowshoe. The top rounded section is constructed of a stringed material woven in a crisscross pattern to create webbing that is attached to the frame. The center of the snowshoe is open and free of webbing. On the left, a drawing of a person on skis with a ski pole in each hand, faces left toward a downward slope. The skier wears winter clothing and a backpack. Mountain peaks are in the distance.
